column3:
'Don't spread chaos in Asia', China furious after being called a supporter of Ukraine war...

China on Thursday targeted the Western military alliance NATO. NATO had described China as a 'decisive supporter' in Russia's war against Ukraine. China lodged a diplomatic protest with the Western alliance for 'provocative' remarks and said not to bring 'chaos' to Asia.

Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lin Jian said in a media briefing that the paragraphs related to China in the NATO Washington summit declaration are 'biased, provocative and aimed at insulting Beijing'. Lin said, 'We strongly condemn this and firmly oppose it. We have lodged a serious diplomatic protest with NATO.'

'Don't bring chaos to Asia'

He also criticized NATO's Asia-Pacific effort and said that the organization is strengthening relations with China's neighbors and US allies. China asked NATO not to spread 'chaos' in Asia.

Lin said NATO's Asia Pacific strategy has harmed China's interests. China urged NATO to stop interfering in its internal affairs. He said, 'China will firmly safeguard its sovereignty, security and development-related interests.'

NATO targeted China

The NATO Washington summit has sharply criticized Beijing, saying that China has become a 'decisive supporter of Russia's war against Ukraine' through its partnership and massive support for Russia's defense industrial base.

In addition, China's military exercises with Russia's close ally Belarus were also sharply criticized by NATO. Especially because they are being conducted close to the border of NATO member country Poland.

British media is upset with India's growing threat: Trying to pit America against Ukraine, claims- Russia made secret purchases with money received in exchange for oil

Foreign media is trying to spoil India's peace efforts to end the Ukraine-Russia war. In this connection, just a few days after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Kiev, foreign media institution Financial Times has claimed that India is selling war equipment to Russia in the midst of this war.

Financial Times has published an article on this matter on August 4, 2024 titled 'Russia built covert trade channel with India, leaks reveal'. In this article, Financial Times has alleged that Russia has purchased many important electronics from India with the help of large reserves of Indian currency raised by selling oil.

Financial Times has been publishing anti-India articles many times before this as well. This time it has claimed that this alleged transaction between India and Russia was kept hidden from Western governments and this material was used in the war against Ukraine.

In this article, the Financial Times has based its claim on documents and sources that are not publicly available. The Financial Times alleged that Russia first classifies those goods as goods taken from non-friendly countries.

Purchase of crude oil from Russia has been a constant problem between India and America. On this issue, the US Deputy NSA had even asked India to face the consequences. However, India did not care and continued to buy oil from Russia.

column3:
Greenhouse Effect | Madhya Pradesh Climate Change Knowledge Portal

Climate Change Guide
So children, did you understand the things told so far? Now let us try to learn some new and very important things. See, when you read a book on any subject or learn a lesson, then some special words come again and again in that lesson.

Children, till now you have acquired a lot of information. You have also learned what climate change is, what are its causes and what are its effects on different aspects of human life. Now let us try to understand how to deal with climate change.

The greenhouse effect is actually caused by the heat coming from the sun getting trapped in the earth's atmosphere. This heat gets trapped in the atmosphere, but is unable to go back into the sky. As this heat gets trapped more, our atmosphere becomes hotter.

Climate change and increase in global temperature has become a big issue. We should also gain information about it, so let us try to know in simple language what is climate change? What are the main issues related to it?

Fossil fuels are not renewable sources of energy. They are available in limited quantities only. The remains of dead animals and plants turn into such fuels over a long period of time. This process takes millions of years to complete. It needs to be used very sparingly, otherwise it may end completely.

Water harvesting means storing or saving rainwater in various ways. Apart from ponds or lakes, rainwater can also be collected through tanks built underground. This water can be easily used for gardening and irrigation. It helps in maintaining the groundwater level.

Deforestation means cutting down forests or forest areas for urban activities. Deforestation is also called Nirvanikaran in Hindi. Cutting down forests for farming, mining or building construction etc. is an example of this. Trees play a very important role in the carbon cycle. They provide photosynthesis (photosynthesis)

Madhya Pradesh, the second largest state of India, has many national parks, where a large number of tigers live. These include Kanha National Park, Panna National Park, Pench Tiger Reserve, Madhav National Park, etc.

column3:
Worrying: Climate change and changing bird migration patterns

Birds migrate to find optimal breeding sites and feeding areas. Traditionally, these journeys are made in such a way that birds arrive at breeding sites when food sources—such as insects and plants—are abundant.

Climate change is not just a buzzword. It is a phenomenon that is causing significant changes in our natural world. One of the most noticeable impacts is the change in bird migration patterns. For centuries many bird species have followed predictable routes and timing, but these patterns are changing rapidly as global temperatures rise.
Birds migrate to find optimal breeding sites and feeding areas. Traditionally, these journeys are made in such a way that birds arrive at breeding sites when food sources—such as insects and plants—are abundant. However, due to rising temperatures these resources are now becoming available earlier in the year.
Changing bird migration
Warmer causes plants to bloom and insects to emerge earlier, forcing birds to alter their migration schedules. As a result, many species are now arriving earlier at their breeding grounds. However, not all species are able to adjust so quickly to these changing conditions.
For example, the Himalayan Monal, a beautiful pheasant found in the hilly regions of the Himalayas, is experiencing shifts in the timing of plant growth and insect emergence. This mismatch results in the Monal seeking food sources that are either depleted or not abundant, affecting their ability to breed and raise their young successfully.

Foreign::::: Zelensky calls for global action on Russia - Hindustan

Foreign::::: Zelensky calls for global action on Russia
- Said, Russian President is committing international crime, United Nations, agency. Ukraine
- Said, Russian President is committing international crime, United Nations, agency.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Tuesday rejected the notion of peace talks with Moscow. Also called for global action to force Russia to peace and follow the United Nations Charter.
The UN Charter states that every country should respect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of all other countries. Zelensky told the United Nations Security Council that Russian President Vladimir Putin is committing an international crime. He has broken so many international rules that he will not stop on his own. Zelensky said that this is why this war cannot end easily. It cannot be pacified by talks. Russia can only be forced to peace. Ministers from 14 of the council's 15 member countries attended a high-level meeting on the two-and-a-half-year-long war in Ukraine. Russia sent its low-level UN ambassador to the meeting.

At the start of the meeting, Vasily Nebenzya protested that Zelensky was again being given an opportunity to attract the attention of the UN. He also criticized Slovenia, which is chairing the council this month, for allowing the Ukrainian leader to repeat the same old things. At the same time, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres reiterated the UN's strong support for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity under the world body's charter.

column3:
Over 1,600 Scientists Deny Climate Emergency

A total of 1,609 scientists, including several Nobel Prize winners, have signed a declaration entitled “There Is No Climate Emergency”. This text was promoted by the Climate Intelligence Foundation (CLINTEL). “Climate science should be less political, while climate policy should be more scientific”, the text states.

“There is no climate emergency. Therefore, there is no reason for panic and alarm. We strongly oppose the harmful and unrealistic Net Zero CO2 policy proposed for 2050. Focus on adaptation instead of mitigation; adaptation works regardless of the causes”, said the group of scientists.

They argue that this gas is “essential” for our planet. They also argue that “the Earth’s climate has varied since the planet existed, and the planet has gone through several cold and warm phases”.

Two “Nobel Prize winners”

American physicists Ivar Giaever and John F. Clauser, Nobel Prize winners in 1973 and 2022 respectively, have joined the declaration against the climate change crisis.

They said that “the popular narrative about climate change reflects a dangerous corruption of science that threatens the global economy and the well-being of billions of people”.

A Spaniard among the signatories

The Mallorcan Luis Pomar, a geologist and professor emeritus at the University of the Balearic Islands, is on the list of scientists who reject climate change. The Spaniard was the first to win the Sorby Medal from the International Association of Sedimentology.

Points of the declaration

The text entitled “There is no climate emergency” includes the following points:

– The geological record reveals that the Earth’s climate has varied since the planet existed, with natural cold and warm phases. The Little Ice Age ended in 1850. So it is no surprise that we are now experiencing a period of warming.

– The world has warmed significantly less than predicted by the IPCC based on modelled anthropogenic impact. The gap between the real world and the modelled world tells us that we are far from understanding climate change.

– Climate models are deeply flawed and are not at all plausible as global policy tools. They exaggerate the effect of greenhouse gases such as CO2. Furthermore, they ignore the fact that enriching the atmosphere with CO2 is beneficial.

– CO2 is not a pollutant. It is essential for life on Earth. Photosynthesis is a blessing. More CO2 is good for nature, it makes the Earth greener: the extra CO2 in the air has boosted the growth of the world’s plant biomass. It is also good for agriculture, as it increases crop yields worldwide.

– There is no statistical evidence that global warming is making hurricanes, floods, droughts and similar natural disasters more frequent or more frequent. However, there is ample evidence that CO2 mitigation measures are harmful and costly.

There is no climate emergency. Therefore, there is no cause for panic and alarm. We strongly oppose the harmful and unrealistic policy of Net Zero CO2 emissions proposed for 2050. If better approaches emerge, and they undoubtedly will, we will have plenty of time to reflect and adapt. The goal of global policy should be “prosperity for all” through the provision of reliable and affordable energy at all times. In a prosperous society, men and women are well educated, birth rates are low and people care about the environment.

column3:
Zelensky admits the inevitability of the withdrawal of Kiev troops from the battlefield

In an interview with the Washington Post, the Ukrainian president acknowledged the shortage of weapons faced by Ukrainian forces and said that, without US assistance, the troops will have to retreat.

The Ukrainian Armed Forces will constantly retreat if the United States does not provide the necessary assistance. This was what Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky declared this Friday (29) in an interview with the Washington Post.

"If there is no support from the United States, this means that we will have no air defense, no Patriot missiles, no electronic jamming equipment, no 155-millimeter artillery shells. This means that we will retreat, step by step, small steps [from the battlefield]," Zelensky said.

He added that Ukraine is facing problems with air defense, and said that without support from the US Congress there will be a shortage of missiles.

"Without the support of the [US] Congress, we will have a serious shortage of missiles. This is a problem. We are building our own air defense systems, but this is not enough." According to him, the Ukrainian Armed Forces are trying to find a way to not retreat in the combat zone. "If the situation on the front remains stable, then in the rear Ukraine will be able to arm and train new brigades to launch a new counteroffensive attempt this year," the Ukrainian president said. Last summer, Ukrainian troops launched an attempted counteroffensive that turned out to be a failure. During this period, almost 166,000 Ukrainian soldiers were killed, 800 tanks were destroyed, including half of the German Leopard tanks, as well as 123 aircraft and 2,400 armored vehicles. Earlier, Fox News, citing a letter from White House Office of Management and Budget chief Shalanda Young to Senator J.D. Vance, reported that the US government has spent at least $113 billion on aid to Ukraine.

However, as CIA Director Robert Burns said in mid-March, without additional military assistance from Washington, the Kiev authorities will have to agree to peace talks on Russia's terms within a year. He stressed that the lack of American support would result in a further withdrawal and loss of territory for the Ukrainian Armed Forces.

column3:
Sanctions on Russia had little impact on war in Ukraine, study says

"The Russian economy is currently growing strongly thanks to the defence boom," says Vasily Astrov, a Russian affairs expert at the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies (wiiw).

However, he says, "sanctions can act as a slow-acting poison," the expert stressed in reference to the conclusions of the study commissioned by the German Ministry of Economic Affairs and Climate Action.

In 2023, a year after the start of the war, Russia's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) grew by 3.6%. This year, Prime Minister Mikhail Mishustin announced a 5% increase in the first five months of the year compared to the same period last year, with growth in the areas of industrial production, machinery and equipment and intellectual property.

"This figure is significantly higher than expected, despite all attempts from abroad to prevent us from doing so," Mishustin said at a meeting on economic issues, as quoted by the Tass news agency.

The Russia Monitor project, the result of a research cooperation between the Vienna Institute for International Economic Studies (WIIW, coordinator), the Kiel Institute for the World Economy (IfW), the Leibniz Institute for Economic Research (IFO) and the Austrian Institute for Economic Research (WIFO), covers data on Russian exports and imports (including sanctioned and dual-use goods), the state budget, the manufacturing sector, domestic demand, the labour market, price developments and financial markets.

It was developed in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine and the sanctions imposed by the European Union (EU) and other states on Moscow with the aim of restricting its ability to wage war and increasing the political and economic costs for the country's elites.

Russia's GDP growth has been attributed to increased government spending on weapons and military equipment, with wage increases and payments to families of war victims increasing the income of many families.

The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from its Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort.

The past few months have been marked by large-scale Russian airstrikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kyiv's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory close to the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014.

Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian Armed Forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of help from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
Zelensky plans second peace summit in November, says Russia should attend

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said Monday he aims to have a plan ready by November to allow Kiev to hold a second international summit on its vision for peace in the country's conflict, adding that representatives from Russia should attend.

Ukraine hosted delegations from 92 countries at a first summit in Switzerland last month to present its peace plan. Russia, which invaded Ukraine in February 2022, was not invited to the event and dismissed its relevance.

"I have set a goal that by November we will have a fully prepared plan," Zelensky told a news conference in Kiev. "I think that representatives of Russia should be present at the second summit."

Zelensky made the remarks after returning from a visit to Washington for a summit of the Western military alliance North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) last week.

Ukrainian officials have previously said Russian representatives could be invited to a new summit.

Russia’s deputy foreign minister said last week that Moscow would not participate in a new summit. The Kremlin was less categorical, saying there was “no precise substance” to the idea of ​​a second summit.

The first summit discussed three of the 10 points presented by Ukraine as Zelensky’s “formula” for peace, including food security, nuclear safety and the release of prisoners of war and children.

Ukrainian officials said the second summit would discuss a plan drawn up in advance by dozens of countries divided into working groups.

Zelensky said officials would likely meet in Qatar in late July or early August to agree on a position on energy security. A meeting on food security is expected to take place in Turkey in August, and another in Canada in September on prisoners of war and children, he said.

column3:
Agriculture Minister criticizes "green radicals" and wants to reduce bureaucracy in the sector

For the Agriculture Minister, this project will bring “competitiveness” to the region and will “help” territorial cohesion and sustainability

The Agriculture Minister today criticized the “green radicals” who are protesting against the construction of dams and warned that projects related to the sector need to be simplified and the existing bureaucracy done away with.

“What we have to do next is another job, which is simplification, which is to eliminate bureaucracy. I know that in this country there are a lot of people who are paid to create problems, basically, and not to solve them, but this is something that has to end,” said José Manuel Fernandes.

The minister, who was speaking at the signing ceremony for the contract for the construction of the irrigation network for the Xévora hydro-agricultural project in Campo Maior, in the district of Portalegre, gave as an example the slowness that often leads to obtaining, for example, an environmental impact statement.

“An environmental impact statement cannot take five years; it is a huge loss for that to happen. Fortunately, we have a prime minister who not only considers agriculture to be strategic and structural, but also has this objective of simplification, this objective of accelerating processes”, he stressed.

“Water is a priority for agriculture. It confuses me a bit that there are, for example, radicals, as I call them, green radicals, who are against the construction of dams, against water storage. This would promote deserts in a number of places, it would be against the environment”, he added.

Later, speaking to journalists, José Manuel Fernandes stressed that agriculture “is not an enemy” of the environment and that dams help biodiversity and the environment and combat climate change.

“There are those who want to eliminate dams, which would be a disaster, leading not only to the abandonment of the territory but also to an increase in drought and environmental problems”, he lamented.

The Government will move forward with the construction of the irrigation network for the Xévora Hydro-Agricultural Project, starting from the Abrilongo Dam, in an investment that could exceed 25 million euros.

The investment, financed by the Rural Development Programme (PDR) 2020, must be completed physically and financially by the end of 2025, followed by another phase of the project by 2026, which includes the construction of the irrigation pumping station and the reservoir.

The project, at this stage, involves an investment of over 17 million euros and will benefit an area of ​​1,560 hectares, with a pipeline network of 44 kilometres.

For the Minister of Agriculture, this project will bring “competitiveness” to the region and will “help” with territorial cohesion and sustainability.

During the ceremony, the president of the Xévora Beneficiaries Association, Luís Minas, explained that the association “must be a partner” in this project, recalling that it was the beneficiaries who bore the costs of the environmental impact study project.

Also present at the ceremony, the mayor of Campo Maior, Luis Rosinha, said that this was “a very important day” for the municipality, as this is a project “very much desired” by the entire population.

column3:
King Charles installs solar panels at Windsor Castle

Britain’s King Charles III, a lifelong campaigner on environmental issues, has installed solar panels at Windsor Castle and plans to convert the British royal family’s Bentley cars to run on biofuel, palace officials said.

Charles has installed solar panels on part of the Windsor Castle estate known as the Lord Chamberlain’s Upper Store, replacing the existing lead roof. More panels are planned to be added in the future, officials said.

The royal family owns Bentley limousines, which will be converted to run on biofuel next year as an interim step before the fleet goes electric, officials said. The king has long been outspoken on environmental conservation, and in 2020 described global warming and climate change as the greatest threat humanity has ever faced.

Palace officials made the announcement as they explained the details of the annual report on taxpayer-funded income and expenditure, known as the Sovereign Grant.

The document showed that official expenditure for 2023-24 was £89.1m (€106.4m), up from the £86.3m earmarked, forcing the royal household to dip into reserves to fund the deficit, albeit less than last year.

In total, travel costs amounted to £4.2m, with the biggest overseas expense being the king and queen's state visit to Kenya, which cost £167,000.

column3:
Two more dolphin carcasses found in Lake Tefé, Amazonas

The emergency monitoring and possible removal of dolphins from Lake Tefé, in Amazonas, found two carcasses of these animals, the Mamirauá Institute for Sustainable Development reported today (2). The mobilization, carried out over the weekend, occurred after the death of more than 100 aquatic mammals, such as the red dolphin and the tucuxi, which lived in the area.

On Saturday (30), the Chico Mendes Institute for Biodiversity Conservation (ICMBio) sent teams of veterinarians and staff from the Aquatic Mammal Center (CMA) and the Environmental Emergency Division to determine the causes of the extreme mortality of these mammals. In addition to the drought, the hypothesis is that the heat is causing the deaths of fish and mammals in the region.

The mobilization involves partner organizations, such as Mamirauá, with actions to monitor animals still alive, search for and collect carcasses, collect water samples for disease analysis and monitor the water temperature, which reached 40 degrees Celsius (ºC).

“We continue the operation to monitor the temperature of the lake. On the 28th, the temperature reached 39.1°C, dropped to 37ºC on Friday and 32ºC on Saturday. However, yesterday, at 4 pm, it rose to 37.8°C and we are very alert. There is still no major progress in determining the cause of death, but temperature continues to be the main candidate for the cause of mortality,” Mamirauá Institute member Ayan Fleischmann told Agência Brasil.

According to Fleischmann, there is still no update on the rescue of the animals still alive that are in the lake. On Friday (29), Mamirauá issued a warning to the population living near Lake Tefé to avoid contact with the lake's waters and also recreational use.

In an interview with the Viva Maria program on Rádio Nacional da Amazónia, the coordinator of the Mamirauá Amazonian Aquatic Mammal Research Group, Miriam Marmontel, stated on Saturday (30) that these animals end up acting as sentinels of water quality and are the first to be affected by changes caused in the environment.

"They gave us the warning and now we have to be aware of it. The tendency, if we don't change our habits, is for these events to continue happening. Global warming and changes in climate parameters are affecting an environment that we use a lot, especially in the Amazon. Water is essential for Amazonians and this water, which is currently not suitable for the boto, is also not suitable for humans", said the researcher.

column3:
COP-27: Brazil has chosen to "stop destroying the Amazon", says Al Gore, former US vice president

Nobel Peace Prize winner, former US vice president and climate activist, Albert Gore Junior, better known as Al Gore, stated this Monday, the 7th, that, a few days ago, Brazil “chose to stop destroying the Amazon”. In an impassioned speech at the summit of leaders of the Climate Conference (COP-27), he argued that global leaders have a “trust problem” when it comes to combating climate change and advocated investing in what he called a “sustainable revolution”.

Al Gore did not mention Jair Bolsonaro or Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva by name during his speech. However, on October 30, as soon as the PT candidate's victory was confirmed, the activist congratulated the president-elect on his victory and said that “the world expects renewed leadership from Brazil in driving solutions to the climate crisis and in containing biodiversity loss”.

“We are talking and starting to act, but we are not doing enough. It is a choice to continue this pattern of destructive behavior. I believe we have other options,” he said. He stressed that we are in the early stages of a “sustainable revolution,” which has the “magnitude of the Industrial Revolution” and the “speed of the digital revolution.” “If we invest in this and stop subsidizing the culture of death, we can save ourselves,” he argued. “Every dollar spent on renewable energy creates three times more jobs than dollars spent on fossil fuels. And this sustainable revolution is massively deflationary, just at a time when the world is trying to find new ways to fight inflation,” he argued.

column3:
Marina Silva receives award in Belo Horizonte and asks for Congress' support for the environment

Brazil's Minister of State for the Environment and Climate Change, Marina Silva, received the Hugo Werneck Award for environmentalist of the year at a ceremony held on Tuesday (2) at the Convention Center of the Belo Horizonte Shopkeepers' Club (CDL-BH). During the ceremony, the manager asked for the support of the National Congress with the agenda related to environmental preservation and revealed that the federal government hopes to double the resources available for the Climate Fund.

“The government needs to overcome the difficulties with Congress, which understands that certain structures are a cost. I think it is not a cost, it is an investment. The climate authority will help with the challenge of climate extremes. Right here in Minas Gerais, we are living with torrential rains and rising temperatures,” said the minister.

Marina Silva stated that the government of President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (PT) will work “within budgetary possibilities” to build “new structures” related to environmental preservation. “Civil society and the scientific community are doing their part. Those who are not doing their part are governments and companies,” she claimed.

Climate Fund

The minister also commented on the Climate Fund, a Brazilian government instrument created to finance projects, studies and ventures aimed at reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and adapting to the effects of climate change. The initiative already has 10 billion reais in resources and, according to Marina, the government expects to expand to 20 billion reais.

“The Climate Fund is for the entire country. It is 10 billion euros for projects in the area of ​​urban mobility, mainly electrification of urban fleets, reforestation and water resources, bioeconomy, infrastructure for sustainable development. We are investing in the new economy. Projects that aim to tackle climate change,” he stated.

Municipalization of environmental preservation actions

Journalist and environmentalist Hiram Firmino, creator of the Hugo Werneck Award, classifies the environmental issue as revolutionary and advocates the participation of municipalities in the agenda. “The world has changed, because pain is educational. People are feeling climate change firsthand. We are talking about the municipalization of environmental management,” he claims.

Hugo Werneck Award

The Hugo Werneck Award, created in 2010, is a national reference in the fight for environmental preservation. It recognizes and publicizes the best projects, cases and actions in favor of the environment and sustainability, with more than a thousand applications and 170 winners and honorees.

The award has become a landmark in the Brazilian environmental calendar, raising awareness in society about the importance of protecting the planet and fighting climate change.

Inspired by the legacy of Hugo Werneck (1919-2008), one of the pioneers of ecological awareness in Latin America, the award encourages society's participation in building a greener future.

column3:
The world's largest moving iceberg causes alarm in the international community. “Antarctica is waking up”

The world’s largest iceberg is moving for the first time in more than 30 years. The iceberg, called A23a, broke off the coast of Antarctica in the late 1980s and was until now a fixed “ice island” in the Weddell Sea, a region disputed between the United Kingdom and Argentina – a reality that has been changing in the last year.

With an impressive 4,000 square kilometers in area (more than 40 times the size of the city of Lisbon) and 400 meters deep, the recent movement of A23a has put the scientific community on alert.

“It had been stationary since 1986, but eventually it would shrink enough in size that it would lose adhesion and start moving,” Andrew Fleming, a specialist at the British Antarctic Survey, told the BBC, adding that the first movements of the shelf began to be seen “in 2020”.

In recent months, the intensity of this movement has increased, partly due to a change in winds and sea currents. A23a is now close to passing the northern tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. From there, it will probably set a course towards the South Atlantic – a path that has already been called “iceberg alley”.

Originally part of the Filchner-Ronne ice shelf, the ice mass broke away from the coast in 1986. At the time, it had a Soviet research station on its surface, which led Moscow to send an expedition to rescue the equipment and research.

A23a’s drift comes at a time when another round of international climate debates is expected – a fact that prompted a visit by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, to Antarctica, where he once again warned of the tragedy of climate change.

“What happens in Antarctica does not stay in Antarctica. (…) We are witnessing an acceleration that is completely devastating,” said Guterres, who described the upcoming COP28 meeting in Dubai as an opportunity to agree on a period for energy transition and the move away from fossil fuels. “Antarctica is waking up, and the world must wake up with it,” he added.

column3:
Russia restricts civilian access to villages in Ukraine-bombed border region

Access to 14 villages in the southern Russian Belgorod region bordering Ukraine will be closed to most civilians, Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said Tuesday, citing the “extremely difficult” situation due to Ukrainian shelling.

Announcing the new restrictions in a video posted on his Telegram channel, Gladkov said that starting next week, only adult men accompanying military or government officials will be allowed to enter the settlements. Men must travel in armored vehicles and wear bulletproof vests and helmets, he added.

“I hope you will agree that it is unacceptable to allow women and children to enter the settlements that are shelled every day,” Gladkov said.

“We have already lost too many civilians, we have too many wounded. And of course, our task is to maximize security measures.”

The Belgorod region has come under frequent fire from Ukrainian bombers and drones. Air raid sirens sound almost daily in the regional capital of the same name, just 40 km (25 miles) north of the border. Ukraine says Russian shelling of Ukrainian cities has been devastating, and after nearly two and a half years of war, Russian forces now control about a fifth of Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin said in May that Russian forces were working to create a buffer zone in northeastern Ukraine to protect Russia from attacks launched by Kiev’s forces across the border. Gladkov’s announcement is a sign that the security situation in the region may have become more dire, prompting authorities to do more to protect civilians. More than 200 civilians have been killed in the Belgorod region since the start of what Moscow calls its “special military operation” in Ukraine in February 2022, Gladkov told the state-run Tass news agency on Tuesday. More than 1,100 were injured.
column4: ['URW: Russia is the Victim']
column5: ['URW: Russia is the Victim: Other']

column3:
Spain detains three people for cyberattacks against countries supporting Ukraine

Spanish police arrested three people on Saturday (20) accused of having participated in cyberattacks by a pro-Russian group against public institutions and strategic sectors of the country and other NATO members.

The attacks were directed against countries supporting Ukraine in its fight against the Russian invasion, which began in February 2024.

Two of the suspects were detained in Huelva and Seville, in southern Spain, while the third was detained in the Balearic Islands, a statement from the Civil Guard said.

They were detained for “crimes of computer damage for terrorist purposes”. The three people are believed to have participated in attacks organized by the Russian-linked hacker group “NoName057(16)”, according to the statement.

“The main activity of this group is to carry out distributed denial of service (DDoS) attacks against websites of public and private organizations in the government sector, critical infrastructures and essential services,” the Civil Guard stated.

The security agency detailed that the group’s main activity consisted of organizing DDoS attacks with “software developed by the group itself (…), called DDoSia” and which can be “voluntarily used by individuals who support the purposes of this organization”.

The Civil Guard statement also indicated that the group’s objective was to respond to “hostile and openly anti-Russian actions by Western Russophobes”.

In mid-June, Swiss government websites suffered a wave of DDoS attacks ahead of a peace summit in Ukraine, in an operation claimed by NoName057(16).

The attack targeted the portals of the federal government and organizations participating in the peace summit, according to Bern.
column4: ['URW: Russia is the Victim']
column5: ['URW: Russia is the Victim: The West is russophobic']

column3:
Running Out of Time, Ukrainian Armed Forces Commander Announces Leadership Changes

The newly installed commander of Ukraine’s armed forces, Aleksandr Syrsky, said he plans to make further changes to the military leadership and general staff, bringing in more officers who have gained experience during the conflict.

According to Bloomberg, Syrsky said that “our headquarters must know all the needs on the battlefield and understand the situation on each part of the front. And for this, the skills of the officers who are part of the military administration come to the fore.”

The media reported that the commander did not say how many officers who served under his predecessor, General Valery Zaluzhny, would be replaced or provide any other details.

Ukraine’s military has struggled to make gains in recent months, as Russia outnumbers Ukrainian forces six to one in artillery shells.

Meanwhile, after a review of internal resources, the Ukrainian military plans to recruit “significantly” fewer people than the 500,000 initially discussed, Syrsky said, without providing a new figure.

“We hope to have enough people to protect the homeland, and we are talking not only about conscripts, but also about volunteers,” he said.

After Ukraine’s 2023 counteroffensive failed to break through entrenched Russian lines, Kiev is starting to build its own fortifications, with some critics questioning why this was not started earlier, media reports said.

In the commander’s interpretation, Russia “will continue its offensive along a wide front” and aims to reach the borders of the Donetsk and Lugansk regions “at any cost,” as well as reach more territories in Zaporozhye, Syrsky said.

“We are preparing solid defense lines in almost all threatened directions,” he added.

Last month, the fall of Avdeevka and several nearby towns fueled fears that Kiev's defenses may not be able to hold, with Ukrainian officials worried that Russian advances could gain significant momentum by the summer, as reported.

column3:
Climate change: the issue that Trump and the Republicans are not happy about

Climate change seems to be of little concern to participants at the Republican convention in Milwaukee, which met to endorse Donald Trump as a candidate for the US elections in November.

“I don’t believe in any of this,” says Jack Prendergast, a delegate from New York at the meeting, convinced that “volcanic eruptions” cause as much damage to the planet as “man’s actions.” He is impatiently awaiting Donald Trump’s return to the White House so that the United States “can become the world’s leading producer of oil and gas.”

Scepticism

The former president, who is running to oust Joe Biden from the White House, has the motto “drill, baby, drill,” which sums up his support for the exploration and use of fossil fuels.

Trump, who regularly makes skeptical comments about the climate, denounced the Paris Agreement during his first term.

This week, Republicans endorsed his candidacy for a second term. Trump has chosen Senator J.D. Vance, also a climate skeptic, as his running mate. The Ohio senator, who will become vice president if Trump is elected, has in the past accused Democrats of stoking fears about the “environmental crisis” for electoral gain. The platform that the two will defend in the elections was adopted on Monday by Republican delegates in Milwaukee. The 5,000-word document makes no mention of climate change or renewable energy, despite the country suffering from a heat wave. Instead, the text calls for an end to “green” measures, which it calls “socialist.” Trump himself opposes wind power, convinced that the turbines “kill birds.” Long-term work Environmentalists such as the Sunrise Movement have criticized the Republican platform, saying that the party “has made it clear that it is happy to make the climate crisis worse.” “We have to look at their words with a little perspective,” smiles Stephen Perkins of the American Conservation Coalition, which may have had the only booth at the Milwaukee convention discussing the preservation of the planet. “I think some of their comments are more intended to entertain than to express political positions,” the 29-year-old told AFP. His organization is present at this large Milwaukee sports center to advocate for a “conservative approach to climate policy,” which could allow Republicans to “win over” the youth vote, he believes. “It’s a long-term task,” admits Perkins, referring to a “natural aversion” to the issue, especially among older Republicans. Radical sect According to a Yale poll released Tuesday, more than two-thirds of Americans believe that climate change exists. However, this does not necessarily translate into support for Democratic President Joe Biden, who has promoted several initiatives to combat global warming during his term. Perkins, on the other hand, believes Biden is at the mercy of a “radical sect” of progressives “who don’t care about nuance.” His convention booth features the word “destruction” alongside images of left-wing environmental activists throwing soup at a work of art.
column4: ['CC: Downplaying climate change', 'CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities', 'CC: Criticism of climate policies', 'CC: Controversy about green technologies']

column3:
Kiev could lose all access to the Black Sea if it doesn't agree to negotiations with Russia, says Musk

American billionaire and businessman Elon Musk believes that if Ukraine doesn't agree to negotiate with Russia, the country could lose all access to the Black Sea. According to Musk, the longer the conflict lasts, "the more territory Russia will gain."

"If the war lasts long enough, Odessa will fall. In my opinion, the main question is whether Ukraine will lose all access to the Black Sea or not. I would advise resolving the conflict through negotiations before that happens," Musk said on the social network X.

According to the businessman, "attacking a larger army with deep defense, minefields and strong artillery, when Ukraine had no superiority in either armor or air, was a tragedy in terms of loss of life."

Moscow has repeatedly indicated that it is willing to negotiate, while Kiev has prohibited any dialogue to end the conflict. The West, which supports the government of President Vladimir Zelensky, is putting pressure on the country not to start negotiations.

The Russian government has previously stated that there are no prerequisites for a peaceful solution with the achievement of the objectives of the special operation, which can currently only be achieved militarily.

The situation in Ukraine can become peaceful only if the new realities and the actual situation are taken into account, and all of Moscow's requirements are well known.

Russia began military action in Ukraine on February 24, 2022. President Vladimir Putin justified the measure by the need to "protect people who have been subjected to abuse and genocide by the Kiev regime for eight years." According to Putin, this involves "demilitarizing and denazifying Ukraine" and bringing to justice all war criminals responsible for "bloody crimes against civilians."

column3:
In 2024, Ukraine will implement over 200 reforms in accordance with Western recommendations

Moscow, June 4. TASS. The Ukrainian government has approved a plan for 2024, which includes over 200 reforms and about 400 indicators of their implementation, which were developed in accordance with the recommendations of Western partners. This was reported at a cabinet meeting by Ukrainian Prime Minister Denis Shmygal.

"We have officially approved the reform matrix and the procedure for monitoring compliance with the recommendations and conditions that our international partners provided us. Over 200 reforms are planned for 2024. About 400 indicators of their implementation have been formed," Shmygal said on the cabinet website.

According to the Prime Minister, the framework is a “huge plan for change”, which includes reforms, as well as officially approved recommendations and documents from the European Commission, structural beacons from the IMF, a plan for the EU aid program Ukraine Facility and the conditions of the World Bank, with the help of which this framework was developed. He added that the reforms cover both the economic sector and institutional changes, including law enforcement reform and anti-corruption policies. 

Western allies, on whose aid Ukraine depends, are increasingly linking the continuation of this support, as well as the country’s European integration process, to the fulfillment of a number of conditions, including changes in legislation. In the fall of 2023, a great resonance in Ukraine was caused by the leak of a letter from the US Deputy Assistant to the President for National Security Michael Pyle to the Ukrainian leadership. The document presented a list of priority reforms that Kiev must implement in order to receive assistance from Washington. Verkhovna Rada deputy Yaroslav Zheleznyak called this approach “money for reforms,” and the head of the parliamentary faction of the pro-presidential party Serving the People, David Arachamiya, acknowledged that bills will be a priority for the Rada, the approval of which will depend on continued funding from Western donors.

column3:
10 days after protests against Lula with Ukrainian flags, André Ventura shares photo with Putin's ally

It still seems like yesterday that 3 Chega MPs carried posters with Ukrainian flags in protest against Lula da Silva, but in fact it was 10 days ago.

Perhaps to celebrate this initiative in defense of the Ukrainian people, André Ventura shared a photo today with the President of Hungary and one of Putin's main allies in Europe, as proven by his statements and positions, much more denouncing in defense of Russia against Ukraine than Lula da Silva.

In January 2023, Viktor Orbán stated that “Ukraine cannot win even with Western help”, in February the Hungarian Prime Minister accused the EU and NATO of being in favor of war in Ukraine and in March of this year his Government declared that it does not intend to comply with the ICC's arrest warrant against Putin if the Russian leader visits Hungary.

André Ventura shared a photo of Viktor Orbán wearing his jersey today and wrote:

This morning I met with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and we talked about the European elections, the future of the right and the European Union. We also talked about football but I can't reveal that conversation ????

column3:
Former Russian president says Ukraine joining NATO would mean ‘war’

Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said Ukraine joining NATO would be a declaration of war against Moscow and that only “prudence” on behalf of the alliance could prevent the planet from being torn apart.

North Atlantic Treaty Organization leaders pledged at their summit last week to support Ukraine on an “irreversible path to full Euro-Atlantic integration, including NATO membership,” but left open the question of when that membership might happen.

Medvedev, deputy chairman of Russia’s Security Council and a leading voice among Kremlin hawks, told the Argumenty I Fakty media outlet that Ukraine’s accession would go beyond a direct threat to Moscow’s security.

“This would essentially be a declaration of war – albeit a belated one,” he said in comments published on Wednesday.

“The actions that Russia’s opponents have been taking against us for years, expanding the alliance, are bringing NATO to a point of no return.”

In a standard Kremlin line since Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Medvedev said Russia was not threatening NATO but would respond to the alliance’s attempts to advance its interests.

“The more such attempts there are, the harsher our responses will become,” Medvedev said. “Whether this will tear the entire planet apart depends solely on the prudence of the (NATO) side.”

column3:
Moscow accuses Kyiv of wanting to open the Black Sea to NATO

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a decree on Wednesday on the new Maritime Security Strategy, which envisages "changes and innovations", especially in the Black Sea, and which is accompanied by a strategy with international partners.

The Kremlin (Russian presidency) spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, commenting on the Ukrainian initiative, warned that Moscow will take measures to ensure the country's security due to the "additional threats" posed by the presence of NATO ships in the area.

"The concentrated presence of NATO ships - and we take into account Bulgaria and Romania, which are NATO littoral states - poses additional threats to Russia, especially in the current situation," he said.

Peskov referred, in particular, to the "direct involvement of NATO countries in the conflict over Ukraine", according to the Spanish news agency EFE.

"Of course, Russia will take all necessary measures to ensure its own security," he said.

Peskov also recalled that "the presence of non-Black Sea states" in those waters "is regulated very strictly by the Montreux Convention".

"Turkey is, in this case, the administrator and performs its functions very clearly", he added, quoted by the Spanish agency Europa Press.

Dated 1936, the Montreux Convention gives Turkey control of the Bosphorus and Dardanelles straits that connect the Black and Mediterranean Seas.

Merchant ships enjoy freedom of passage, but warships are subject to restrictions "that vary depending on whether or not these ships belong to the Black Sea states", according to the Turkish government.

The representative of Crimea in the Russian parliament, Mikhail Sheremet, also accused Zelenskyy today of wanting to prolong the conflict with Russia, according to the Russian agency TASS.

Sheremet said that Kiev's new maritime security strategy is aimed at building up Ukrainian naval forces and ensuring the presence of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in the Black Sea. According to the Crimean MP, if Ukraine's military pressure weakens, Zelensky will no longer be needed by the West and NATO countries will stop supporting him as Ukrainian leader. Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula from Ukraine in 2014 and, since the February 2022 invasion, has added the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporizhia to the list.

column3:
Local elections cannot ignore climate agenda

The effects of climate change have been part of Brazilians' daily lives for some time now. In May, the country was moved by the plight of the people of Rio Grande do Sul who faced unprecedented devastation caused by inclement rains, which killed more than 180 residents, left cities submerged, destroyed infrastructure and caused billions in losses. In recent months, amid severe droughts and scorching temperatures, fires have spread, destroying vegetation and causing problems for the population. One would expect that such a reality would make climate change one of the main themes of the local government campaign throughout the country. However, this is not the case.

As shown in the GLOBO series of reports “Resilient Cities”, the candidates for mayor seem to ignore the concern, despite the fact that measures to adapt to and mitigate the effects of global warming are mainly a municipal issue. All candidates should address the issue in their government proposals and plans. However, with the exception of the South, where the scars of the rains are still present, the report reveals that most programs deal with the issue vaguely, relegating long-term measures to the background.

The most common promises concern Civil Defense actions (warning systems), drainage works, creation of parks or planting trees. Not that such initiatives are unimportant. But the climate emergency demands more. Candidates should clearly explain their policies to avoid the occupation of areas susceptible to disasters (such as hillsides and riverbanks) and strategies to relocate vulnerable families. Even if unpopular, these are essential measures to minimize the effects of tragedies resulting from extreme weather events, which are increasingly frequent.

As municipalities are responsible for regulating land use, they bear a fundamental responsibility in preventing catastrophes. The tragedy in Rio Grande do Sul showed that the occupation of cities needs to be rethought. There is no way to prevent rivers from overflowing or hillsides from sliding under torrential rain, but it is possible to reduce the effects of tragedies by better planning for occupation. Certain areas, due to obvious risks, cannot be used for housing. However, only 13% of Brazilian cities have a specific plan to reduce the risk of disasters, according to a survey by the Iyaleta Research Association. Less than a third have a master plan for flood prevention. Only 8% have warning systems in place.

In a scenario of more intense extreme events, candidates should present proposals that include reforestation of hillsides, street trees, cooling of transport and schools, and preparation of health networks, with particular attention to children and the elderly. This is no longer a matter of projections for the future. In the middle of winter, Brazilian cities have recorded temperatures above 40 degrees.

Campaigns cannot be so disconnected from reality. It is not unlikely that torrential rains, heat waves, prolonged droughts and devastating fires will occur in the coming weeks, months or years. Cities need to be prepared to respond. During the campaign, candidates may even avoid the issue. But once elected, they will certainly be exposed to it. They cannot claim surprise.

column3:
Bushy moustaches versus activists, in the era of climate scandals

Eduardo Oliveira e Sousa from Ribatejo, the bearer of the most lush and bushy moustache in this election campaign, caught the eye last week, and not just because of his well-trimmed hair above his lips. The AD candidate for Santarém spoke of “false climate reasons” that hinder investment, an opinion that, unfortunately, many people do not tolerate these days. Or, if they do, they are afraid to proclaim it in the middle of the hunting season, in search of votes, so as not to upset the most sensitive souls, such as the swarm of political commentators who have been lashing out at the agroforestry entrepreneur who is now running for deputy.

The AD candidate, who until a year ago led the powerful Confederation of Portuguese Farmers (CAP) and the CNEMA in Santarém, limited himself to sharing what was on his mind and which is his full conviction. Of him and many other people, it must be said. And to his rescue, in a gesture of solidarity that suggests that the news about climate change is clearly exaggerated, was also Saint Peter. In the days following Oliveira e Sousa's fearless statements, the saint in charge of climate matters gave us rain, wind, cold and snow in the highlands, as if to show that tradition is still what it used to be, and so is winter. What climate change, what a hood! It even rained during Carnival, remember?

In that election rally in Ourém, Oliveira e Sousa emphasized, in fact, that extreme weather phenomena have always existed. And he emphasized it very well, too! Those more delicate and picky spirits would have had to deal with an ice age when there were no Alentejo samurai, salamanders or hot water bottles; or that they had faced a flood of biblical proportions without having life jackets, flippers and rubber boats and would have seen what was good for their cough.

Manel, I have a past as an activist that I was unaware of until relatively recently, which ends up reconciling me with my rash and climate-irresponsible youth. For years I nurtured the idea, and the remorse, that I had committed many misdeeds and jokes of dubious taste, for which I would have to answer on the day of judgment. But in the meantime I discovered that little or nothing separated me from those who today are called climate activists (and those of other causes) and who even enjoy a certain sympathy and social reputation, especially among young people.

People today do a lot of things along the same lines - from blocking roads, vandalizing facilities, throwing eggs and paint at people - and all these practices, which some people would once have called vandalism, delinquency or rioting, are now manifestations of activism because they are carried out by the euphemistically designated activists. In short, semantic freedoms that help me to ease my conscience and to think better about who to vote for...
column4: ['CC: Criticism of climate movement', 'CC: Downplaying climate change', 'CC: Criticism of climate movement']

column3:
The energy transition

Extreme weather events are on the rise. Huge forest fires, severe droughts, torrential rains, major floods, violent heat waves, etc. are occurring one after the other. Some of the unpleasant effects of climate change are already being felt in Portugal, and they are also being felt in other European countries, such as the United States, Canada, China...

How can such clear signs be ignored and the energy transition be halted by consuming more fossil fuels? This is a regrettable reaction that is taking shape in several European countries.

This is a way of denying what is obvious. Years ago, it was still possible to consider the imperative of reducing CO2 emissions a fantasy. Now, denying what is obvious requires greater effort, which some people are making in order to avoid being bothered.

The energy transition has costs, which are easier to ignore. Those who react this way probably think that the final tragedy will only happen when they are no longer around. This is how they condemn future generations. This is irresponsible selfishness.

Unfortunately, political leaders are not always up to the challenge of the crisis that is unfolding. They prefer not to upset people and so avoid taking the drastic measures that are necessary.

Therefore, hope lies in the capacity of the younger generations to protest, so as to force politicians to assume their responsibilities, instead of continuing to calmly act as if the energy transition were not extremely urgent.

Young people protest because they see their lives at risk. They are right. All of us, young and old, should be grateful to those who do not resign themselves to passively waiting for the worst to happen.

column3:
Heat kills too many Portuguese people. Housing code should change

More than 600 deaths per year: “The summer plan should have been created in January and it doesn’t exist, as well as the contingency plan”.

Portugal is one of the countries with the highest excess mortality due to heat. It exceeded 600 deaths per year between 1990 and 2019.

Carlos Cortes, president of the Portuguese Medical Association, believes that prevention could be more effective: “The summer plan should have been created in January and it doesn’t exist, as well as the contingency plan, which should have been known in April. They are essential for preventing deaths associated with excessive heat and, every year, this is never done”.

“There is a lack of prevention measures and information campaigns for the population. The sensation of thirst is lost with age and older people have to force themselves to drink in times of greater heat”.

The president told Diário de Notícias that the Directorate General of Health (DGS) is responsible for creating prevention plans.

Carlos Cortes warns that heat waves have been increasing year after year, “with an increasingly longer summer period”.

“The most vulnerable groups, such as children, the elderly and people with chronic illnesses that may decompensate, must implement some measures and there is a lack of literacy in this area. Campaigns should have been more intensified”, he adds.

Excessive heat brings several disadvantages. One of them is the change in our ecosystem: “There are diseases that were typical of Africa that are beginning to appear in Southern Europe. The diseases we have are not the same because viruses and bacteria that live in a warmer environment develop differently, compared to how they do in a temperate climate”.

Precisely in this context, doctor Luís Cadinha points out that mosquitoes that carry Zika or dengue fever have stopped reaching “just one part of the Algarve and have spread throughout the area and have already been detected in Lisbon”.

“Although mosquitoes only transmit diseases when infected, we have a new population in Portugal. This change in temperature makes our country a more suitable habitat for mosquitoes”, warns the public health doctor.

There are also more ticks. “Ticks remain active for longer and not only in the summer – and these are the ones that carry diseases that affect us. They start earlier and stop being active later. They used to be active between May and September and now they start in March and remain until November”.

Luís Cadinha also warns about the increased frequency of heat waves. For comparison: there were only “two or three” between 2000 and 2005, and in 2023 alone there have been three heat waves.

column3:
Portugal must demand the release of Captain Paul Watson, the whale protector

Captain Paul Watson has been tirelessly sailing the world's seas for decades to defend whales. The founder of Sea Shepherd does nothing more than ensure compliance with the law, since whales are supposedly protected by international law. Whaling has been officially banned since a moratorium adopted by the International Whaling Commission (IWC) came into force in 1986. The aim of this organization is to defend life at sea through a unique strategy of aggressive non-violence and intervention against illegal operations that exploit life at sea. To date, it has helped save more than 5,000 cetaceans!

Currently, only three countries are determined not to comply with the moratorium: Iceland, Norway and Japan. Japan was already condemned by the International Court of Justice in 2014 for its whaling activities, which were subsequently covered up by false claims of scientific research. The famous captain, who is the subject of an international arrest warrant issued by Tokyo for "conspiracy to commit a collision", was arrested on 21 July by the Danish authorities, while his boat was making a discreet stopover in Greenland. Since then, international public opinion has been mobilised to demand Paul Watson's release, notably through a petition launched by journalist Hugo Clément, which has more than 700,000 signatures. French President Emmanuel Macron has already intervened with the Danish authorities to try to prevent his extradition to Japan. Whaling, as well as the persecution of activists who protect it, is increasingly incomprehensible, since this is an activity that is not only illegal, but goes far beyond the protection of a species. Today we know that whales play a fundamental role in mitigating climate change. Scientists have recently discovered that whales can capture significant amounts of carbon from the atmosphere. Estimates indicate that a whale’s ability to capture carbon from the atmosphere is equal to that of thousands of trees. In 2019, the International Monetary Fund itself published a study in which the value of the services provided by a whale (which includes the capture of carbon dioxide) “is more than 2 million dollars and easily more than one trillion dollars for the current population of large whales.”

Whales are an essential part of a solution to the climate crisis. Carbon dioxide capture is around 30 to 40 times more efficient in the marine environment, in which whales play a fundamental role. Therefore, the undersigned urge the Portuguese Government to join the other governments that have already embraced this cause, by taking all necessary steps to ensure that the Danish Government does not extradite Captain Paul Watson and also calling on the Japanese authorities to comply with international law.
column4: ['Other']
column5: ['Other']

column3:
The Amazon will have a slow recovery due to climate phenomena

The general coordinator of Earth Sciences at the National Institute for Space Research (INPE), Gilvan Sampaio, says that the southwest of the Amazon will receive rain again from November, but the precipitation will be below average and the recovery will probably be slow.

“The rainfall deficit was very large, it will still have repercussions in November and will gradually recover”, he said.

Due to the influence of El Niño, according to him, rainfall will be above average in the South and, combined with the temperature anomaly in the North Atlantic, rainfall volumes will be below average in the North of Brazil in the coming months.

He says that, for Rondônia, the outlook is for below-average rainfall. “This is the area where the Madeira River basin is located, which makes an important contribution to the Amazon River”, he explained.

The Madeira is the main tributary of the Amazon. Natural flows in Porto Velho (RO) are 51% below average in October.

Researcher sees relationship between drought in Rio Negro and global warming

The data are included in maps from the joint bulletin of INPE, the National Institute of Meteorology (INMET) and Funceme.

Last Friday (27), INPE's director-general, Clézio De Nardin, explained the situation to senators in a session dedicated to discussing the effects of climate phenomena such as El Niño.

"There is a very serious drought in the western Amazon and it will spread to the east. Today in Manaus and on to Pará. It is serious", he warned.

He explained that the data indicate that the Northeast will suffer from drought starting in February, March and April.

"Get ready! The Northeast will suffer from rainfall well below average. This is already motivating the organizations to take appropriate preventive actions, mainly social", he warned.

INPE data indicate the largest increase in temperature ever recorded in the North Atlantic, which inhibits the growth of transpiration in the Amazon.

“The cycle of temperature increase in the North Atlantic carries the currents and when it reaches the Amazon, it forces the air current downwards, preventing the formation of clouds, preventing rain and this causes droughts”, he explained.

In addition to this, there are the El Niño currents. With part of the Pacific warming, the ocean winds that flow in an east-west direction over the Andes Mountains form a kind of barrier over Brazilian territory, causing cold fronts to circulate more slowly over the southern region.

“The cold currents enter the southern region very slowly, causing extreme rainfall and well below average in the rest of the country”, he said.

The director highlighted the investment of around 32.7 million euros by the Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation (MCTI) in the Renovation of INPE's Supercomputing Infrastructure.

The resources from the National Fund for Scientific and Technological Development (FNDCT) will be used to acquire the new supercomputer, install a photovoltaic plant to meet the machine's energy demand, and develop Monan – the Model for Forecasting Oceans, Continental Surfaces and Atmosphere.

The unique data modeling system that receives information from satellites, radar data and other measurement systems to forecast weather, ocean behavior, winds, among others.

column3:
Russia may deploy missiles if US deploys long-range missiles in Germany

"I do not exclude any option," said Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov when asked about the possibility of deploying nuclear missiles if the United States of America (USA) confirms its decision, adding that such actions imply "the definitive end of arms control agreements in that area."

"In this situation, taking into account the combined capabilities of NATO member countries, we must evaluate our responses, without any internal limitations in terms of what, where and when [missiles] should or should not be deployed. This means that the options should be as broad as possible," the official noted, quoted by the Russian news agency Interfax.

In this sense, the deputy minister said that Russia's position "does not pose a threat to anyone, it is simply seeking the most effective way, also in terms of costs, to respond to changing challenges."

Ryabkov also assured that the Russian authorities will guarantee the security of the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad (a Russian enclave in the Baltic bordering Lithuania and Poland, two countries in the European Union and NATO), which has "long attracted the attention of adversaries".

"Should the representatives of the German government consider it justified to initiate measures for an escalation under the pretext of the situation in the region, we will respond with compensatory measures in the manner we consider most acceptable", he stressed.

"Nothing will stop us from solving the problems for our security along the entire perimeter of the Russian borders", he stressed.

Last week, Ryabkov had considered that "the nature of Russia's reaction" - should the US decide on such a measure, which would involve the first American shipment of these weapons to Germany since the end of the Cold War - "will be decided calmly and professionally".

The announcement by the United States and Germany indicates, as recalled today by the Spanish agency Europa Press, that the installation of long-range missiles aims to demonstrate Washington's "commitment" to NATO and a contribution to "integrated European deterrence", specifying that "these conventional long-range units will include (missiles) SM-6, Tomahawk and latest-generation hypersonic weapons, with a significantly greater range than current ground-based materials in Europe".

In parallel, the United States and four European countries - the Netherlands, Germany, Italy and Romania - announced on Wednesday the sending of anti-aircraft defence systems to Ukraine following the latest wave of Russian attacks that left 40 dead and 170 injured, as part of the military invasion ordered in February 2022 by President Vladimir Putin.

column3:
“Zombie” viruses are waking up 50,000 years later thanks to thawing Siberian permafrost

The danger is “increasingly clear”: While we are keeping an eye on climate threats from the south, such as tropical diseases, threats from the thawing north may be emerging simultaneously.

Global health authorities, including the World Health Organization (WHO), are sounding the alarm about a potential new health crisis: the awakening of ancient “zombie viruses” originating from permafrost — the permanently frozen layer of the earth’s surface.

Some of these pathogens are up to 50,000 years old and were unearthed from layers of Siberian permafrost, according to research shared in a Bloomberg report on Monday. Concerns have intensified in the post-Covid-19 era, given the lack of immunity and treatments available for these viruses.

The main culprit for the awakening of these giant zombies is, once again, global warming, which is, as you read this article, thawing this permanent layer. With the Arctic set to be ice-free by the summers of the 2030s, the release of ancient pathogens presents a new frontier of risk. Alongside greenhouse gases such as methane, pathogens dormant in permafrost pose an underappreciated danger. Last year, according to the Financial Express, a team led by Aix-Marseille University professor Jean-Michel Claverie, who is studying these zombies, published research that found that multiple ancient viruses extracted from Siberian permafrost were still infectious. The danger is “increasingly clear” The revival of pathogens is not just theoretical. An anthrax outbreak in Siberia in 2016, triggered by a heatwave, resulted in numerous infections and led to the deaths of thousands of reindeer and a child. A separate study this year also managed to revive a 46,000-year-old roundworm, adding another layer of concern. According to Claverie, the danger is “increasingly clear”: while we typically think of climate threats emanating from the south, such as tropical diseases, threats could also be emerging from the melting north.

The WHO has been monitoring unknown infectious diseases for which humans have neither immunity nor medical therapies to treat them. The organization has included a generic “Disease X” on its list of priority pathogens requiring urgent investigation.

While research is becoming increasingly complicated by geopolitical tensions and fears of new pandemics, it remains essential.

column3:
André Ventura confirmed the presence of two “friends” of Putin who only visit Portugal after electoral defeats

André Ventura confirmed the presence of Jair Bolsonaro and Matteo Salvini, the two “friends” of Vladimir Putin who only visit Portugal after electoral defeats, at a far-right summit scheduled for May 13 and 14.

Bolsonaro, who has never visited Portugal as president of Brazil, has at least 8 legal proceedings pending against him.

In July 2022, 5 months after Russia invaded Ukraine, then-president Jair Bolsonaro reaffirmed that Brazil would not adhere to sanctions against Russia and that his relationship with the Russian leader was “exceptional… My relationship with the Russian government is not good, it is exceptional”.

Matteo Salvini, leader of the Northern League, a party that lost more than half of its voters in the last elections in September 2022, risks 15 years in prison where he is accused of “kidnapping” 147 migrants rescued on board a ship operated by the Spanish NGO Open Arms, to whom he denied disembarkation as part of his closed ports policy. The Deputy Prime Minister of Italy, who once again defended the end of sanctions on Russia in September 2022, has never hidden his admiration for Vladimir Putin, to the point of considering him in 2019 as the “best statesman currently on the planet” and having worn a T-shirt with the Russian President’s face printed on it.

Jair Bolsonaro, former President of Brazil, is facing several judicial investigations:

The case of the jewelry offered by Saudi Arabia. Bolsonaro is said to have brought two packages of jewelry that were not declared to the tax authorities.

Genocide crimes against the Yanomami indigenous community. Disobedience, breach of judicial secrecy, and environmental crimes related to the life, health and safety of several indigenous communities.

Incitement to violence in the attacks in Brasília. The Public Prosecutor's Office considers that Jair Bolsonaro shared videos on social media in which he questions the regularity of the Presidential elections, which constitutes public incitement to commit a crime.

Accusations of electoral fraud. Even before the elections, Bolsonaro was already the target of an investigation due to the successive attacks made on the Brazilian electoral system.

Fraud regarding the administration of the vaccine against Covid-19. Bolsonaro's medical records indicate that the former President had taken a dose of the Janssen vaccine on July 19, 2021.

Use of government agencies and resources to benefit his children, who are also the target of judicial investigations.

Spying on citizens through the Brazilian Intelligence Agency (Abin). Suspicions that FirstMile was used to monitor opponents of Bolsonaro's government.

Appropriation of weapons received on an official trip, accused of embezzlement.

column3:
Red alert due to intense heatwave in eastern and southern Europe

Like Romania, the whole of eastern Europe is in the grip of an intense heatwave, the third of the season.

"It's exactly what scientists predicted. This is part of human-induced climate change, and it will only get worse in the future if we don't act," Professor Ilan Kelman of University College London told AFP.

Hungary's Debrecen airport, the country's second largest, had to be temporarily closed because the heat damaged the runways.

In neighbouring Romania, power outages are multiplying in hospitals due to peaks in air conditioning consumption.

A 45-year-old man died due to the heat in the northern city of Botosani, and in several parts of the country, temperatures broke records overnight, with thermometers above 27ºC.

"It is very worrying that temperatures are not going to drop. If organisations do not have time to cool down overnight, the death toll could increase," Kelman warned.

The fires have devastated thousands of hectares in North Macedonia, Albania and Bulgaria.

According to Hannah Cloke, a climatologist at the University of Reading, "European city dwellers will have to adapt not only their infrastructure but also their habits to cope with more intense heatwaves in the future", adding that "it could be almost impossible to leave their homes on certain days".

Working outdoors banned in several places

Heatwaves are becoming more likely and more severe as a result of climate change, experts say.

In Europe, temperatures are rising at twice the rate of the global average.

Some regions of Greece have already recorded temperatures above 40ºC for more than 10 days.

The heat is so intense that the Acropolis of Athens, the country's most visited site, has had to close for several days during the hottest hours of the day.

The economy has also had to adapt to the high temperatures.

In Sicily, since Wednesday, work in agriculture and construction has been prohibited between 12:30 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. on days when the risk of working outdoors is "high." The measure remains in force until August 31.

A total of 14 Italian cities, including Rome and Florence, are on "red alert" due to the heat and humidity.

Due to the temperatures, several regions of Italy have suffered an invasion of locusts, according to the Coldiretti agricultural union.
