column3:
Ukrainian presidential election cancelled: what's next?

Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky's decision not to hold a presidential election in his country, despite his term ending in two months, is unlikely to have a significant impact on his relations with the West, political analyst Bogdan Bezpalko tells Sputnik.

The elections in Ukraine, originally scheduled to take place this Sunday (31), were cancelled under the pretext of martial law declared by President Zelensky. While the authorities in Kiev insisted that this decision was related to the Ukrainian conflict that began in February 2022, there are suspicions that the decision was motivated by Zelensky's ratings in opinion polls.

"He does not want to hold elections because he is afraid of losing them and someone else taking his place. Ukraine is not in a state of war, mobilization has not been officially declared, there are no other attributes associated with a country that is officially in a state of war. Martial law, of course, may allow him to extend his term, but not indefinitely," political analyst Bogdan Bezpalko told Sputnik.

Russia's Permanent Representative to the United Nations (UN), Vasily Nebenzya, has already suggested that Zelensky will technically cease to be a legitimate president once his term ends on May 21.

However, Bezpalko noted that Zelensky's presidential term may be extended until August, without mentioning that the regime in Kiev may try to stage some provocation to "change the judicial status of the conflict" and thus further escalate the situation.

The analyst added that Zelensky's decision is unlikely to have repercussions in the West, since the current regime in Kiev serves the interests of allied countries. However, if for some reason the West decides to remove Zelensky, it would immediately be declared that he does not legitimately hold office, Bezpalko suggested. While Western powers may make “some timid statements” about Zelensky’s decision not to hold elections, they are unlikely to be followed by any sanctions or a reduction in the flow of Western assistance to Kiev, he added. “He may end up facing some difficulties in his contacts with the West, but he will continue to receive assistance — limited, significantly reduced perhaps, but he will continue to receive assistance,” Bezpalko noted. According to the expert, the question of Zelensky’s legitimacy is a secondary concern, since a replacement would likely not change Ukraine’s position towards Russia or the conflict as a whole. The reason for this, he said, is that it is not just Ukraine or Zelensky himself that is involved in the conflict with Russia, but essentially the entire West. Bezpalko further noted that Zelensky has established an authoritarian regime in Ukraine by trying to deny his political opponents access to the mass media and any material resources.

Furthermore, the president is considered responsible for dragging Ukraine into a conflict that has become an unmitigated disaster in the country, and Zelensky would suffer a major defeat in a free and fair election, Bezpalko concluded.

column3:
Ukraine detains 30 officials suspected of allegedly embezzling nearly €3 million in military funds

The Prosecutor General's Office of Ukraine announced on Friday the detention of 30 people during a large-scale operation across the country on suspicion of a conspiracy to embezzle military equipment worth nearly €3 million.

The suspects were detained on suspicion of being “organizers and participants in criminal schemes involving the embezzlement of budget funds intended to meet the needs of the Armed Forces of Ukraine,” it said in a statement on the social network ‘Telegram’.

In a statement, the Prosecutor General's Office stressed that “a large-scale special operation was carried out to uncover the organizers and participants of criminal schemes involving the embezzlement of budget funds allocated to meet the needs of the Ukrainian Armed Forces,” it wrote, noting that “employees of housing maintenance units were found involved in embezzlement in almost all oblasts of Ukraine, in cooperation with representatives of commercial entities.”

The detainees are 15 alleged members of criminal organisations and 15 other local government officials, including, for example, three officials from the city of Kharkiv, or seven from the Lviv, Chernigov or Yitomir regions. Specifically, they are accused of “inflating the prices” of firewood, electricity or natural gas and infrastructure for military use, as well as “illegal acquisition of assets in the form of commercial properties and land”. This is the latest example of the anti-corruption drive promoted by the country’s President Volodymyr Zelensky, following calls from the international community to facilitate its accession process to the European Union and NATO. These issues are a source of concern for Ukraine’s allies, led by the United States, which has provided tens of billions of euros in financial and military assistance since Russia’s invasion in February 2022.

column3:
US taps Turkey for explosives to help Ukraine, US media say

The United States is in talks to increase purchases of explosives from Turkey to speed up production of artillery shells. According to media reports, Ankara is on track to become the largest seller of artillery munitions to Washington this year.

Turkish supplies of trinitrotoluene, known as TNT, and nitroguanidine, which is used as a propellant, would be crucial in the production of 155mm munitions, the NATO standard, according to officials familiar with the discussions who spoke to Bloomberg.

The surge in demand has delayed global orders and put pressure on defense supply chains, especially for components such as TNT, the officials said on condition of anonymity.

The Pentagon said in late February that it had contracted General Dynamics Ordnance and Tactical Systems to build three metal parts lines for 155mm projectiles in Texas, including Turkish subcontractors. The plant, in Mesquite, Texas, is expected to be operational in June, the company said.

Turkish defense contractor Repkon’s production lines are expected to produce about 30% of all 155mm artillery shells made in the United States by 2025, the people said.

In a statement about the investment in Texas and Turkish industry, the Pentagon said working with allies “is critical to building a global defense industrial base,” the media reported.

In addition, the Defense Department has purchased 116,000 rounds of combat-ready ammunition from Turkey’s Arca Defense for delivery this year, with more expected to be delivered as soon as 2025, the officials added.

The U.S. and European efforts are part of a race to catch up with Moscow, which has the upper hand on the battlefield and has forced Ukrainian troops to abandon strategic locations after assaults. Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan plans to visit the White House on May 9 for the first time since President Joe Biden took office, as the two men work to soften military ties. The deal with Ankara also highlights a delicate balance between the NATO allies, whose relations have been strained by Russia’s operation in Ukraine and Turkey’s months-long blockade of Sweden’s accession to the alliance.

column3:
Climate activists jailed for four to five years in England

Five protesters linked to the climate group Just Stop Oil have been found guilty of conspiracy to cause public disorder, The Guardian reported. The activists were given record sentences for non-violent protests for their role in the movement that blocked London's M25 motorway for four consecutive days in November 2022.

Roger Hallam, 58, and co-founder of the climate group, was sentenced to five years in prison. The other four defendants were sentenced to four years.

The five defendants are said to have met on Zoom on 2 November 2022 to discuss the planning of the protest. During the meeting, they are said to have tried to recruit people to block the motorway. A journalist from The Sun is said to have joined the call and sent the recordings to the police.

During the trial that led to the record sentences, 11 protesters were arrested for contempt outside the court. Christopher Hehir, the judge, said that “the disturbance was intricately planned” and that there was “irrefutable evidence” of a conspiracy, as reported by Sky News. Hehir added that the protesters “have appointed themselves as the sole judges of what should be done about climate change” and that they have gone “from concerned to fanatical” for some time now. Climáximo, a Portuguese climate activist group, has expressed its solidarity with Just Stop Oil. In a statement, the group said that the convicted protesters are “political prisoners of a war that fossil fuel companies have declared on society” and compared this situation to the one and a half year suspended sentence given to the eight protesters from the group, who were tried for blocking Avenida Duarte Pacheco in Lisbon on 14 December 2023. Amnesty International has also spoken out against the sentence. “These long sentences for people simply seeking climate justice should raise alarm bells about the ongoing crackdown on peaceful protest in this country. It violates all of our human rights,” said Tom Southerden, legal and human rights adviser at Amnesty UK, as quoted by The Independent.

Prosecutors alleged that the protests, during which 45 people climbed onto motorway gantry cranes, had cost the Metropolitan Police at least £765,000. In addition, the demonstration is said to have cost the Metropolitan Police the equivalent of €1.3 million.

The protests also caused around 50,000 hours of delays and affected 700,000 vehicles, leaving the M25 blocked for more than 120 hours.

A police officer was also left with bruises after being knocked down by a motorbike in traffic.

column3:
Lisbon Court Removes Coercive Measures for Historic Leader of Neo-Nazi Skinheads to Go Fight in Ukraine

It is true, when one thought that justice could not surprise, it does, and it is estimated that there are victims of racism and xenophobia who wish that Mário Machado, historic leader of neo-Nazi skinheads and supporter of André Ventura's Chega, would not stop at words and join the Ukrainian troops as soon as possible, preferably on the front line.

Mário Machado shared the request and the court's decision to remove the coercive measure of biweekly presentation for the crime of possession of a prohibited weapon and wrote:

Breaking news!!

Judge of the Criminal Investigation Court of Lisbon, defers request by Mário Machado, so that the coercive measures applied in the last political process of biweekly presentations, are changed.

Machado requested, through his distinguished lawyer, Dr. José M. Castro, the following: “The serious international crisis triggered by Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has mobilized the efforts of thousands of people, mainly in the humanitarian field.

The defendant is not indifferent to this movement.

Therefore, he mobilized a group of people of different nationalities who intend to go to Ukraine to provide humanitarian aid and, if necessary, fight alongside Ukrainian troops.”

The judge issued the ruling: “..considering the humanitarian situation in Ukraine and the purposes invoked by the defendant for his claim, the defendant may not comply with the aforementioned coercive measure while he is abroad.”

“We cannot be fair if we are not human.” Luc de Clapiers

column3:
Russia ready to negotiate with Zelensky but questions legitimacy

"This is a difficult issue. From a legal point of view, it is a problem, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. Therefore, several options are possible," the presidential spokesman said.

Zelensky's legitimacy as president of Ukraine has been a question raised by Russia, which argues that the Ukrainian leader's term ended on May 20.

The Russian spokesman said that in addition to "problems with Zelensky's legitimacy", there is also "the problem of the ban on establishing any contacts or negotiations with the Russian side, since this ban remains in force".

"Therefore, there is still a lot to clarify and we need to hear some explanations," Peskov said.

Following Zelensky’s recent statements about his readiness to negotiate a peaceful solution to the war in Ukraine, the Russian presidential spokesman stressed that “Russia is generally open to the negotiation process, but it is necessary to understand to what extent the Ukrainian side is prepared.”

“So far, as you can see, we have heard very different statements, so far things are not very clear,” he added.

On Wednesday, Peskov recalled that Russian President Vladimir Putin had stated that “Zelensky has lost legitimacy” after the end of his term, which “is a factor that can significantly hinder the peace process.”

The spokesman also stressed that Russia will ensure the defence of its interests and security in any case, whether through negotiations or weapons.

“The special military operation was launched as a last resort to achieve our goals,” Peskov said, stressing that “any war ends with peace negotiations.”

In recent days, Zelensky has stressed the need for negotiations to end the war as soon as possible.

The Ukrainian president has recently held talks with political representatives in favour of an immediate ceasefire, such as Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba travelled to China this week to discuss potential peace talks between Ukraine and Russia.

Ukraine has been relying on financial and arms aid from Western allies since Russia invaded the country on 24 February 2022.

Kiev's allies have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort in Ukraine.

column3:
Bonn Conference: two handfuls of nothing

Compared to COP28, the negotiations took place in a more structured manner, without the confusion of the Green Zone, the hundreds of pavilions and side events, and with much less civil society participation – which, a priori, could indicate a greater appetite for streamlining and rapid negotiations. But that was not what happened.

Around 6,000 participants from almost 200 countries gathered to address issues such as National Mitigation Plans (NDCs) and Adaptation Plans (NAPs), the Loss and Damage Fund, accelerating climate action through a just transition, Article 6 of the Paris Agreement (Carbon Markets) and the Transparency Framework. Climate finance, in particular the New Quantified Target for Climate Finance (NCQG), will be decided almost entirely at COP29 in Azerbaijan, becoming the “elephant in the room”. 

Despite expectations based on the outcome of the COP28 Global Stocktake on climate finance, SB60 represented a snail’s pace in climate negotiations and a serious omission in relation to the informal commitment to abandon fossil fuels. We returned home with two hands full of nothing and two hands full of everything for Azerbaijan. 

The major agreements of SB60 concerned the length of the texts presented for negotiation, and the structural division between the views of developed and developing countries. 

The current model of climate negotiations, known as the “Global Negotiating Process”, has proven to be ineffective, bureaucratic and dominated by the Global North. Every year, negotiators meet to discuss and make decisions on how best to combat climate change. The working instruments for the negotiations are the negotiating texts, based on written proposals submitted by governments. At the end of a negotiation, the President bangs the gavel to declare that a decision or new treaty has been adopted. The COP is the supreme decision-making body in the climate change process and we are heading towards the 29th.

This inefficiency becomes even more worrying given the consecutive increase, year after year, in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. It is urgent to rethink the traditional negotiation model and make it more efficient, accessible and transparent to civil society, ensuring a fair and equitable process that legally incorporates the needs of countries on the front line.

Ultimately: turn it into a true Climate Action Body, otherwise it will become the “dinosaur” in the room. Nothing less than this will be enough to limit the average temperature of the planet to 1.5 ºC.

column3:
Artists have given up on “saving” the Amazon

This week, the Amazon experienced its worst fire season in 17 years. The smoke corridor that spread has already affected 10 Brazilian states. Although news about the fires not only in the Amazon Rainforest but also in the Pantanal are highlighted in the media, the concern of those who claim to be defenders of the environment has not been nearly the same as that of the previous government.

In 2021, when everything was the acting president’s fault, Greenpeace Brazil brought together more than 30 artists to release the song “Song for the Amazon”, written by Carlos Rennó and Nando Reis. Several artists who participated in the action also campaigned for Lula in 2022, of course. However, they all remain silent about the increase in fires in Brazil.

Three years ago, Nando Reis himself, when commenting on the project, stated that “The situation in the Amazon is dramatic, serious and represents well the climate catastrophe we are experiencing. And, to make matters worse, we have a president who has no commitment to combating deforestation.” Will Nando’s concerns be the same in 2024, given that he is not making the same demands now?

Also worth mentioning is the speech by Greenpeace’s Amazon Campaign Spokesperson, Carolina Marçal, who stated in September 2021 that “Bolsonaro’s mismanagement is implementing a destructive anti-environmental agenda. We will continue to resist and fight for the Amazon. Art is a powerful form of activism, struggle and resistance, and it is an honour for us to participate in a project like this”, said the expert. Where has all this resistance gone now that Lula is president?

During the last election campaign, one of the main agendas raised by the left was environmental issues and the protection of indigenous peoples, but as with many other things, it was yet another failure.

The number of Yanomami deaths in 2023 was higher than in 2022. Earlier this month, the newspaper “Estadão” reported that Lula’s government would erase data on indigenous deaths. Nothing that seems to worry progressive singers either.

Minister Marina Silva, now forced to appear more often due to the fire crisis, has already blamed climate change, human actions, and El Niño. She even blamed the previous administration for the record deforestation under the PT government, but before supporting and joining the PT there were not so many culprits. The target was just one. As always, according to the left, nothing bad that happens when they are in power is their fault, always someone else’s.

In 2020, Lula questioned where the armed forces were to try to fight the fires in the Pantanal and the Amazon, and stated that the then Minister of the Environment was a citizen without character and without respect for nature. I am still waiting for the moment when you and your current minister will be criticized for what is happening.

With deforestation or fires, dead jaguars or charred alligators, indigenous people being killed or committing suicide, the artists, who so enjoyed appearing in previous years, did not have the courage to take a stand now, confirming that their concern was not with nature but with their pet politician. They quickly gave up on “saving” the Amazon.

column3:
Too much sunlight and heat reduce mental abilities: here are the results of a study

Science, in several studies published in the literature, has amply demonstrated how excessive heat can lead to heat exhaustion or heatstroke, as the body's core temperature rises dangerously.

A new study shows that the scorching sun can have an impact on the brain even when the body temperature remains normal, without excessive temperatures.

The research

Supported by the EU-funded HEAT-SHIELD project, the research team suggests that the real effect of prolonged exposure to sunlight on brain temperature and function has not been fully explored in previous research.

"Acute exposure did not affect performance parameters, while prolonged exposure of the head and neck resulted in a 1°C increase in core temperature and significant changes in controlled cognitive performance and motor activities," says the study published in the journal Scientific Reports.

"Importantly, impairments emerged at significantly lower levels of hyperthermia compared to previous experiments," it adds. Cognition refers to the mental abilities and processes involved in acquiring and processing information necessary for everyday life. It includes memory, cognition, attention, reasoning, problem-solving and comprehension.

The consequences of hyperthermia

Even short-term hyperthermia can lead to cognitive impairment, negatively affecting attention, memory and information processing.

These results highlight the importance of including the effect of radiative heat from sunlight on the head and neck in future scientific assessments of the impacts of heat stress and of specific head protection to minimise the harmful effects.

What is the impact of heat stress?

According to Professor Lars Nybo, co-author of the study, "the decrease in cognitive performance was observed at 38.5 degrees, i.e. at a body temperature one degree lower than that demonstrated in previous studies, which represents a substantial difference".

Co-author Andreas Flouris, associate professor at the University of Thessaly and project partner, stresses the need to mitigate the deterioration in health and performance induced by heat stress, which is intensified by global warming.

The expert stresses that people who work or perform daily activities outdoors should protect their heads from sunlight. "The ability to maintain concentration and avoid impairment of motor and cognitive performance is certainly important for safety at work and in traffic, as well as for minimizing the risk of error during other daily activities."

The impact of solar radiation on climate change

The researchers conclude that the harmful effects of solar radiation should be taken into account in future studies examining the current effects of atmospheric or climate change on occupational health.

For the purpose of the study, the researchers tested the mental abilities of eight men, aged between 27 and 41, while they worked at computers with direct exposure to the heat of lamps directed at their heads and backs.

column3:
Here is the news after the bomb cyclone Ciarán: Portugal has “physical conditions for storms to increase in frequency and amplitude”

“The warmer the ocean, the more energy is available for the atmosphere to develop these very deep depressions with significant impacts.” And since “the ocean is very slow,” the consequences last for a long time.

Portugal has “physical conditions for storms to increase in frequency and amplitude.” Storm Ciarán, which reached Europe as a bomb cyclone, is not the first of its kind to hit Portuguese soil, but it is likely that phenomena like this will become more frequent. In addition, the weekend should bring another storm, which already has a name - Domingos.

Geophysicist and former president of the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA) Miguel Miranda warns, in statements to CNN Portugal, about the size of the storms in question. “It is very interesting from a physical point of view but very alarming from a social point of view”, he stresses, noting that in the most affected countries, such as France, winds of 200 km/h were recorded, a highly significant value that is extremely rare on European soil.

Miguel Miranda explains that, mainly due to global warming - which will cause the oceans to warm - it is natural for phenomena like this to occur with greater frequency and intensity. “The warmer the ocean, the more energy is available for the atmosphere to develop these very deep depressions with significant impacts on buildings and people”, adds the geophysicist.

And, although the worst is over, it is expected that several effects will still be felt in the coming days, at least until the weekend. This is because “the ocean is very slow”, which means the consequences will continue over time, even after the system that caused the storm has passed.

“This leads to restrictions on the coast, especially because there is a second ocean storm this weekend that will make life more difficult in coastal communities,” stresses Miguel Miranda.

The expert therefore asks that people strictly follow the recommendations of the IPMA, which has issued a red warning for a large part of the coast, and also leaves an orange warning for at least the entire coast.

“It is important to understand that we are going to have a new high in sea agitation. When an eight-meter-high swell is indicated, this means that 10% of the waves may be over 16 meters. When there is a red warning issued by the IPMA, it must be strictly followed because the dangers that exist are many,” reiterates Miguel Miranda.

Regarding the effects that these bomb cyclones can cause, Miguel Miranda says that “the Portuguese have some experience of tornadoes, systems of another dimension,” but warns of the impacts that wind and rain can have, especially in areas closer to the coast. Just look at what happened in 1941, when IPMA records recorded the first bomb cyclone on national soil.

"When winds reach speeds of this magnitude, they lift objects and destroy trees. The combined action of wind and rain is very impactful - large trees that fall in urban areas are capable of destroying homes and vehicles", concludes the geophysicist.

column3:
Environmental surcharges on airline tickets will become the norm

When you buy a plane ticket, do you choose to pay extra to offset carbon emissions? If the answer is "no", you are not alone. Voluntary participation in offsetting schemes may be less than 3% of people.

Instead, Lufthansa will introduce a mandatory "environmental cost surcharge" on flights from the EU, the UK, Norway or Switzerland from the beginning of 2025.

This will add up to 72 euros to a long-haul first class ticket. On short- and medium-haul flights, it will be closer to 1 to 7 euros.

The German airline is unlikely to be alone. Mandatory green surcharges are expected to be adopted by traditional airlines in particular.

A number of environmental regulations are to blame, says Lufthansa. She cites EU requirements for jet fuel to include a blend of at least 2% sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from next year, as well as changes to emissions trading schemes (ETS) in Europe.

Air France-KLM laid the groundwork in 2022 by imposing a “SAF contribution rate”, charged at a lower level.

Each regulatory change alone is not exorbitant. Indeed, SAF, made from a variety of materials including recycled cooking oil, is expected to cost at least double the long-term historical price of kerosene by 2050, according to a recent report by LEK Consulting.

But assuming Lufthansa’s 2025 fuel bill remains close to the €8.3bn it expects in 2024, a quick calculation suggests that complying with the EU’s 2025 blending rules could cost an extra €17m. The required blending levels will increase again in 2030 and 2035.

Changes to the EU’s ETS scheme and similar programmes elsewhere will be more costly. Polluters currently receive some free allowances, but these are being reduced.

The impact on traditional airlines will be greater, argues Goodbody analyst Dudley Shanley, as they have historically been bigger emitters and tend to have less efficient fleets.

Lufthansa expects to receive free emissions certificates for about 2.8 million tonnes of CO₂ this year, compared with 3.8 million tonnes in 2023, according to its latest annual report.

The reduction could cost €65 million, based on BloombergNEF’s forecast of an average price of €65 per tonne of EU emissions allowance this year. This is expected to rise to €80/t by 2025.

In good times, these costs could be absorbed. Lufthansa is expected to post a net profit of almost €1.8 billion in 2025, according to figures from Visible Alpha. 

However, traditional airlines are fighting a perpetual war to close the huge cost gap with their low-cost competitors. 

Passengers may complain, but mandatory environmental fees for luggage — at least among major airlines — could become the norm.

column3:
This is not activism: it is radicalism and it is unworthy

In an evolved and democratized society, the ends do not justify the means. In order to defend an idea and fight for a cause, this ceases to be acceptable to society when dialogue is not used in a civilized manner. By resorting to aggression, whatever its modus operandi, one is clearly disrespecting the good practices that activism should implement, with the objective consequence that the struggle and the fight for the idea are not understood, and for that very reason do not have the necessary strength that they should.

In my opinion, the recent events that led to the throwing of green paint at Minister Duarte Cordeiro have a simple reason. Someone is gradually feeding a group, radicalizing the issue of climate change.

With dignity, Duarte Cordeiro continued his work, not dwelling on the controversy, stating that he understands the situation and others in the recent past.

Activism, as we have seen it, with ramifications for the most radical policies, is losing across the board. The debate has given way to the most original ways of showing oneself, but with the sad premise of harming others.

The trend of puncturing the tires of specific brands of cars just because is still very much present in everyone's minds, and in the wallets of some.

This is nothing. This is hitting rock bottom in everything that is civilization and a society that wants to be modern in the debate of ideas.

We will never become evolved if activism in Portugal continues to offer us these sad spectacles that only diminish the power of dialogue in the search for solutions and points of convergence.

The group “Student Climate Strike”, which committed a public crime with its act, which therefore does not require complaint, must realize that it is socially losing the fight, not because of the idea it defends, but because of the way it is defended, and we must all show our indignation towards this group and so many others. No matter how respectable their struggle and conviction are from an ideological point of view, everything starts to look different when they resort to aggression, because it is completely reprehensible.

It is urgent to change the paradigm of thought and action of activist groups. Their notorious “dangerousness” should not be the motto, but unfortunately this is how they show themselves. The right to expression is inalienable and intrinsic to human nature itself, but none of this can be confused with everything we are witnessing. With this episode, which affected Minister Duarte Cordeiro – who was fortunate enough to miss the ink in his eyes – the time has come to tell all activists to change. Be intelligent in the way you do it, be dignified in the fight for your causes and stop violence once and for all. Yes, because we are talking about violence and its practice is counterproductive in our democratic state of law.

This is not how we evolve, nor is this the way to act, but neither is it how Portuguese society will show you any respect. Quite the opposite.

column3:
Extreme heatwaves cause more than 175,000 deaths per year in Europe, says WHO

More than 175,000 people die every year in Europe due to the effects of extreme heatwaves, according to a statement published this Thursday (1) by the European division of the World Health Organization (WHO).

Of the almost 489,000 heat-related deaths recorded annually between 2000 and 2019 in the world, "the European region accounts for 36%, that is, an average of 176,040 deaths per year" in this period.

The WHO's European region, which extends to Central Asia, is the one warming the fastest, about twice the global average, says the organization.

In the last 20 years, heat-related mortality has increased by 30% in the region.

"Extreme temperatures aggravate chronic diseases, including cardiovascular, respiratory and cerebrovascular diseases, mental health and diabetes-related conditions," explains WHO Europe.

They are also responsible for "heat stress", when the human body cannot maintain a temperature between 36 and 37°C, the main cause of climate-related mortality in the region.

According to the WHO, the number of heat victims "will skyrocket" in the coming years due to climate change, which has been responsible for the increase in heat waves in recent decades.

"The three hottest years on record in the WHO European region have occurred since 2020, and the ten hottest years since 2007", explained Kluge.

According to the United Nations organization, it is possible to cope with the heat by adopting simple behaviors, such as keeping the house cool and hydrating regularly.

On July 25, the UN head, António Guterres, made an appeal in the face of the "epidemic" of extreme heat and advocated concrete measures to confront this "invisible killer".

For the Secretary-General of the United Nations, it is necessary to care for vulnerable people, protect exposed workers and limit the increase in global temperature to 1.5°C.

Chega's National Advisor No. 1 accuses the “President of Ukraine of prolonging the agony of his people”

João Tilly published a video on his YouTube channel about “The Rations and Reasons for Ending the War”, where he says that Ukraine has no chance of winning this war, and asks: “Why is Zelensky (President of Ukraine) prolonging the resistance?”

Russia will eventually achieve its goals, and the longer it continues to fight, the more people will die... Zelensky to spare his people, to avoid thousands and thousands of innocent deaths, and I'm not even talking about the military part, the people will be massacred anyway, when a political leader realizes that his people are in the biggest exodus in its history, 1 million or so per week, it will reach 10 million according to the UN, any leader realizes that his people are fleeing, that leader has a moral and historical obligation, towards his people, to stop fighting, to spare his people. Let's stop with Nationalisms. It is a war that cannot be won or drawn. What he is doing by resisting is prolonging the agony of his people, and that is very bad; he is subjecting them to a massacre… 

The National Advisor No. 1 of Chega says that democracy cannot do anything against dictatorship, and that if he could speak to the President of Ukraine he would ask him to end the war immediately…

The president of the district of the far-right party says that Putin is a communist, or a fascist, “or both, which is almost the same thing”.

column3:
Dugin: “Ukraine is the First Multipolar Conflict”

In an interview with the international television network RT, Alexander Dugin quickly explained the geopolitical dimension of the Ukrainian conflict and the foundations of the multipolar world that is rising against the imperialist universalism of the West.

The conflict in Ukraine is the world’s “first multipolar war,” in which Russia fights for the right of each civilization to choose its own path while the West wants to maintain its hegemonic totalitarian globalism, Aleksandr Dugin told RT in an exclusive interview on Friday.

Multipolarity is not “against the West as such,” Dugin said, but “against the West’s claim to be the model, to be the unique example” of history and human understanding. Today’s Russophobia and hatred of Russia, he argued, are a relic of Cold War thinking and the “bipolar understanding of the architecture of international relations.”

When the Soviet Union self-destructed in December 1991, it left the “Western global liberal civilization” in control of the world, Dugin noted. This hegemon now refuses to accept a future in which it would be “not one of two, but one of [a few] poles,” put in its rightful place as “just a part, not the whole, of humanity.” Dugin described the West as “pure totalitarian liberalism,” which pretends to have absolute truth and seeks to impose it on everyone. “There is racism inherent in Western liberalism,” the philosopher told RT’s Donald Courter, because it “identifies Western historical, political, cultural experience [as] universal.” “There is no universal in multipolarity,” Dugin insisted, explaining that each civilization can and should develop its own values. Russia specifically needs to overcome centuries of Western ideological dominance, he said, and create something “new, fresh, creative” that would nevertheless remain “in direct refutation of Western liberal hegemony, against the open society, against individualism, against liberal democracy.” He rejected the “dogmatic” attitudes of Marxism, fascism or liberalism toward politics and economics, saying Russia should strive for a “holistic” approach, in which the spiritual would be more important than the material. Obsession with material goods ends up enslaving people, Dugin told RT. Dugin lamented the collapse of the Soviet Union in December 1991 as a “suicide” perpetrated by power-hungry bureaucrats in Moscow. He echoed Russian President Vladimir Putin’s description of the event as a “geopolitical disaster” and described it as a great victory for “Sea Power.” While the USSR was the polar opposite of the Russian Empire in ideological terms, he explained, in geopolitical terms the two were one and the same, the strongest power in what the English geographer Harold Mackinder described as the global Heartland. 

While some Western observers have called Dugin “Putin’s brain,” the 60-year-old philosopher and author has no official ties to the Kremlin. He is an outspoken supporter of the current military operation in Ukraine — whose independence he sees as a Western imperial project against Russian sovereignty. 

Dugin’s daughter, Daria, just 29, was murdered in August by a car bomb set by Ukrainian agents. Although Kiev officially denied it, US intelligence officials later said they believed someone in the Ukrainian government was involved and responsible.

column3:
About Kiev's attacks on Russian missile attack warning radar stations (SPRN)

In recent days, information has appeared on the network about attacks by Ukrainian Armed Forces UAVs on:

▪️the Voronezh-DM long-range radar near Armavir.

▪️the Voronezh family long-range radar in the Orenburg region.

In addition, Portuguese-made Tekever AR3 UAVs were not spared for the attacks.

These stations are an element of Russia's nuclear security shield. We note that, in accordance with Russia's National Security Strategy, in achieving the country's defense goals, special attention is paid to solving tasks, among which "maintaining a sufficient level of nuclear deterrence potential" stands out.

The attacks on these radars are a serious decision. They solve several tasks:

▪️Weakening of Russia's nuclear security

▪️Repeated testing of Russia's patience

▪️Russia's provocation to use tactical nuclear weapons

▪️In the absence of a firm reaction from Russia, creating conditions for further weakening of our strategic defense in the event of a direct conflict with NATO.

After these attacks on our long-range radars, a surprised expression was made by The Washington Post: "The US is concerned about Ukrainian drone attacks on long-range radars in Russia. In the newspaper's opinion, this could disrupt 'strategic stability'."

This "concern" of the Americans is completely understandable. For, according to the open Supreme Decree “On the Fundamentals of the State Policy of the Russian Federation in the Field of Nuclear Deterrence”, the conditions that determine the possibility of using nuclear weapons by the Russian Federation include “the enemy’s influence on critical objects of state or military importance of the Russian Federation, the deactivation of which will lead to the failure of retaliatory actions by nuclear forces”.

Today, all the legal grounds for the use of nuclear weapons by Russia on the territory of Ukraine have been established. And nowhere does it say that these weapons should be designated as “tactical”.

However, given the eternal delay in implementing retaliatory measures or their media-driven nature, we are unlikely to see such actions in the near future.

And so far, the situation is still moving in such a way that no one thinks about the moral aspects of such actions or about opening the “Overton Window” or “Pandora’s Box” “when the very existence of the state is threatened”.

column3:
Russia says it wants to understand what kind of peace summit Zelensky wants

Russia is not outright rejecting participation in a future peace conference with Ukraine, but it wants to first understand the framework of the meeting suggested this week by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.

The Kremlin responded on Tuesday to the proposal put forward the day before by Zelensky that Russia should be present at a second peace summit that could probably be scheduled for November.

“The first peace summit was not a peace summit at all, so perhaps we need to first understand what he means,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on Tuesday in an interview with the military channel Zvezda, quoted by the Moscow Times.

Peskov was referring to the conference organized by Switzerland in June, in the Alps, to which no Russian leader was invited. At the time, this was a demand from Zelensky, who refused to sit at the table with representatives of the power that occupies part of Ukrainian territory.

Moscow criticised the lack of an invitation and several countries decided not to attend the conference, including China, Russia’s main diplomatic ally. Other nations from the Global South that were present ended up not signing the final communiqué, dealing a blow to the ambitions of Kiev and its Western partners to provide strong global support for Zelensky’s peace plan. 

Despite the lack of an invitation to Russia at the summit in Switzerland, the possibility of Russian representatives participating in future meetings was never ruled out. 

Still, it is difficult to see what could bring the two countries’ positions closer together in potential talks. Ukraine is demanding an immediate military withdrawal by Russia from the occupied territories, while Moscow wants recognition of the annexations of the four provinces it partially occupies. 

Zelensky’s statements this week come at a time when Russia is making some progress on the battlefield, especially in Donbass, which is the primary target of the invasion that began in February 2022.

column3:
Activists who blocked private jet in Cascais sentenced with suspended sentences

The six activists from the Climáximo movement, who blocked a private jet at Cascais airfield in 2023, were sentenced this Monday to a suspended sentence of 15 months in prison, 135 days of community service and to pay 5,300.59 euros.

The environmental group, in a note sent to newsrooms, indicated that the sentence was read this Monday morning, in “the same month in which the temperature broke the world record twice in a row”. seven months ago, while governments and fossil fuel companies were meeting at COP28, to which they flew en masse by private jet for yet another round of false promises, Climáximo supporters entered the Cascais airfield, painted a private jet with red paint and blocked it with their bodies”,

The six activists were tried for, in December 2023, blocking a private jet at the Cascais airfield, to denounce the “superfluous and luxury flights of the super-rich, and the use of these weapons of mass destruction, whose emissions are killing people all over the world”.

Climáximo recalls that, “seven months ago, while governments and fossil fuel companies were meeting at COP28, to which they flew en masse by private jet for yet another round of false promises, Climáximo supporters entered the Cascais airfield, painted a private jet with red paint and blocked it with their bodies”.

The group stresses that this sentence will not intimidate its supporters, “nor will it stop the fight”.

One of the convicted activists, quoted in the group’s statement, lamented that “today, despite the court’s admission of the gravity of the climate crisis and the impact of disruptive protests, the people who took action to stop the destruction have been convicted, while the real culprits remain unpunished”.

Last week, Climáximo supporters supported the actions at airports of the international uprising to end fossil fuels by 2030, as well as the fight in France against the privatization and theft of water by big industries.

column3:
Ukraine, strapped for support, heads to India, urges New Delhi to rethink 'Soviet legacy with Russia'

This week, Ukraine's foreign minister Dmitry Kuleba traveled to New Delhi to seek support from the world's most populous nation, seeking to deepen ties with countries in the Global South as Ukraine faces a critical moment on the battlefield.

In an interview with the Financial Times, the foreign minister urged the Indian government to support Kiev, saying that close ties between India and Russia are based on a "Soviet legacy".

The foreign minister's visit is the first by a senior Ukrainian official to India since the Russian operation in Ukraine began.

"Cooperation between India and Russia is largely based on the Soviet legacy. But this is not a legacy that will last for centuries; it is a legacy that is evaporating," he said.

Kuleba also made a provocative connection by linking the friendship between Moscow and Beijing with what China supposedly means to India today.

“The Sino-Russian relationship should be of special concern to India, in light of its national security prerogatives.”

Going further in his arguments to convince New Delhi, Kuleba cited that when the conflict ends, Ukraine “will probably become the largest construction site in the world and Indian companies are welcome to participate in the recovery.”

Kiev is now seeking to “restore trade” with India, the minister said, by resuming exports of agricultural products such as sunflower oil and buying more Indian products itself: “We are interested in importing some of the heavy machinery items that India produces,” he added.

Ukraine has struggled to win the favor of India and many other countries in the Global South. These states have mostly avoided taking sides in a conflict that they consider to be “the business of rich nations” and whose economic price they have paid in trade disruptions and higher costs, the media reports. Despite Kuleba’s statements that ties between Moscow and New Delhi are “evaporating”, Russia remains India’s largest arms supplier. The Indian state has also become one of the main buyers of Russian crude oil following the Russian operation in Ukraine, and India shares with Moscow (along with China and Brazil) the original founding of the BRICS. The media recall that Kuleba previously claimed that every barrel of Russian crude oil purchased by India contained “a good portion of Ukrainian blood”. However, Kiev has sought to soften relations with New Delhi as it tries to win over more countries to its cause, writes the Financial Times.

column3:
Lavrov calls on UN to eliminate causes of conflict in Ukraine

The end of the confrontation between Moscow and Kiev must be accompanied by the elimination of the threat posed by the West to Russia's security, the foreign minister said during an open debate of the Security Council convened by his delegation, which is chairing the body this month.

Lavrov insisted that both his country and the West need mutual guarantees and agreements, in a clear allusion to the need to reach an agreement for the security of both.

At the same time, he considered it necessary to take into account the new geostrategic realities on the Eurasian continent, where a new, truly equal and indivisible continental security architecture is being formed.

In this context, he added, Europe risks falling behind in this objectively historic process.

“We are ready to seek a balance of interests,” he added.

The global and regional balance of power must also be restored, along with the redress of injustices in the global economy, the senior diplomat added.

The Russian Foreign Minister rejected the use of these coercive measures in a multipolar world that, in his opinion, should not have any monopoly on financial or monetary regulation, trade or technology.

Regarding US policy, the head of Russian diplomacy warned that Washington is convinced that a new global war will not affect the United States, but rather its European allies.

“If this analysis forms the basis of the strategy of the (Joe) Biden administration, it is a very dangerous mistake, and the Europeans should understand that they have been assigned a suicidal role,” he added before members of the highest body for peace on the planet.

At the same time, he demanded that more attention be paid to national minorities in resolving the conflict on Ukrainian territory.

“We call on all those who show a sincere interest in overcoming the crisis in Ukraine to consider the fundamental issue of the rights of national minorities in any of their proposals. Everyone, without exception,” the high representative insisted.

Chega MP in Cascais does not spare the “self-confessed neo-Nazi with a long criminal record”

They are united in homophobia and xenophobia, but on completely opposite sides when it comes to the invasion of Ukraine, which is nothing new when it comes to Chega supporters, if it weren’t for André Ventura’s party, the party of contradictions. Maria Vieira, Chega’s municipal MP in Cascais, does not spare Chega supporter and “self-confessed neo-Nazi”, Mário Machado, “who has a long criminal record involving bodily harm, possession of illegal weapons, kidnapping and extortion, among other things”, because he decided to travel to Ukraine to join the neo-Nazi militias that are part of the Ukrainian National Guard.

Mário Machado, an avowed neo-Nazi with a long criminal record involving assault, possession of illegal weapons, kidnapping and extortion, among other less than desirable things, decided to travel to Ukraine to join the neo-Nazi militias that are part of the Ukrainian National Guard and that support and are in turn supported and sustained by President Zelensky in the armed conflict against Russia. And it is never too much to highlight everything that the lying and corrupt television channels refuse to report in relation to this neo-Nazi battalion that has been accused, since 2014, of war crimes against civilian populations in Eastern Ukraine, namely in cases of torture, rape, looting and all those “cute” things that the Nazis love to do! And so that the aforementioned Mário Machado can leave Portugal in the company of twenty other accomplices, a judge (it is true, a judge from the Central Criminal Investigation Court) exempted him from reporting fortnightly to the police station, following yet another case in which he is a defendant, so that he can travel freely to Ukraine, where he will allegedly go for “humanitarian reasons”!

I am a conservative and right-wing woman, I am (with great honour and great pride) a Municipal Deputy in the Municipality of Cascais for a well-known right-wing party, I am an avowed anti-socialist and anti-communist, I have the greatest contempt for left-wing progressivism, as well as for Cultural Marxism and Globalism and I am astonished when I see a Portuguese judge grant such a privilege to a known neo-Nazi who is going to travel to a foreign country in order to join a group of people who believe in and defend a hideous ideology, responsible for the death of so many millions of people and whose "art" of killing has only been surpassed by the damned communism! This determination imposed by NATO, the EU, the UN and the damned globalists to shape the world against Russia and its president (and I do not support either one, just as I do not support Ukraine or the Ukrainian president) is so biased and sickening that we witness this type of unspeakable thing without the majority of the population being outraged by such a procedure, because after all, Mário Machado, who is a neo-Nazi, is also very human and very sweet just because he is going to help his neo-Nazi cronies in Ukraine!

For God's sake! What else are we going to witness, Lord?

column3:
Underground water reserves at risk due to climate change

The study, published on Saturday in the scientific journal Scientific Reports, from the Nature group, analyzed “an unprecedented set of data” collected over the course of a year in caves in various parts of the world, from subarctic to tropical regions, including, in Portugal, caves in the center of the country, in the Algarve and in the Azores.

Over the course of a year, the temperature in caves and on the surface was measured every two hours, totaling more than 100,000 measurements, which “show that the temperature in the caves corresponds to the average annual surface temperature for each location,” said Ana Sofia Reboleira, Professor at the Faculty of Sciences of the University of Lisbon and researcher at the Center for Ecology, Evolution and Environmental Changes, to the Lusa news agency.

According to the biologist, “the caves responded with three different patterns”: one in which the variation in the outside temperature is reflected in the cave with a small delay, another in which the surface temperatures are quickly reflected inside, and a third in which they work as a mirror image, the lower the surface temperature, the higher the temperature inside the cave and vice versa.

More surprising was the discovery of the “existence of daily thermal cycles in some caves”, considered by the researcher “particularly interesting because in ecosystems with a total absence of light, organisms lack circadian rhythms, that is, biological rhythms marked by the natural cadence of day and night controlled by sunlight on the surface”.

This discovery “shows that these daily thermal cycles can potentially control the biological rhythms of subterranean organisms”, a hypothesis that is being put forward for the first time in the history of Biology.

“These ecosystems are inhabited by unique species that play a very important role in what scientists call ecosystem services” since, she explained, “these animals ensure the recycling of nutrients at depth, of some contaminants that reach them, that control bacterial growth and other types of problems that can affect us”.

Since these are organisms adapted to low amplitudes and reduced thermal variability, the increase in temperatures of several degrees, due to climate change, “will certainly affect these organisms responsible for ensuring the good ecological state of these underground bodies of water”, which represent 97% of the total freshwater resources available for immediate human consumption.

Among the caves studied in the study, the scientist highlights the case of one in Loulé that recorded the highest surface temperature, with more than 39 degrees, and another in the Azores, with the largest thermal amplitude, with a variation of 8.8, explained by the fact that it is a volcanic cave.

The impact of climate change, combined with the fact that underground ecosystems “are constantly neglected in political and public agendas”, have led researchers to now move forward with laboratory studies “on the effects of rising temperatures on these organisms” with the aim of estimating the maximum temperatures that they can withstand.

In addition to the coordinator, the study now published also included the participation of Maria João Medina, a master’s student whose dissertation includes the study, and Paulo Borges from the University of the Azores. At an international level, the work involved researchers from the United States, Serbia, Slovenia, Norway, Spain (including the Canary Islands), Croatia and the island of Guam in the Pacific.

column3:
Extreme heat wave: what to do to avoid risks to the body

A family doctor points out measures that can be taken to minimize the effects of extreme temperatures, but draws attention to the lack of public policies for adapting to climate change.

Brazil began the last week of winter facing an extreme heat wave. An atmospheric blockage has prevented the arrival of the cold fronts that are common for the season and has promised temperatures above 40ºC in several regions, especially in the Center-West and Southeast.

The effects of this temperature spike can go beyond mere discomfort. It is possible to develop hyperthermia and heatstroke, which can even cause death – especially among more vulnerable populations, such as children and the elderly.

Is it possible to die from heat? Doctor explains

In an interview with Natuza Nery, family and community doctor Mayara Floss explains what measures can be taken to minimize the effects of extreme temperatures, and also draws attention to the lack of public policies for adapting to climate change.

"For example, shanty towns, regions with few trees – where there are vast monocultures... These demographic factors put these populations at risk", she says.

To mitigate the effects of heat on a daily basis, Mayara mentions measures such as: carrying a lighter change of clothes to use on public transport during rush hour; placing a bottle of ice-cold water to cool areas of the body, such as the armpits; if possible, prioritise working hours early in the morning, avoiding times of greatest temperature rises; keeping the house more ventilated at night and more closed during the day.

column3:
Environmental Crisis in the Pantanal: Drought and deforestation devastate the Biome

The Pantanal, one of the largest wetlands on the planet, is facing an unprecedented environmental crisis.

The combination of deforestation and prolonged droughts has led to an alarming reduction in the water surface, affecting not only local biodiversity, but also the communities that depend on these natural resources.

A recent study by the MapBiomas platform highlights that, in the current century, almost every year there has been a decrease in the water surface in Brazil, with the Pantanal and Cerrado being the most affected biomes.

Experts warn of the risk of a severe drought and a possible water collapse, a direct consequence of the neglect of springs and riverside forests, essential for the percolation of rain into the earth and for maintaining the flow of rivers.

Deforestation in the Amazon, which affects rainfall through evapotranspiration, also contributes significantly to drought in the Pantanal, creating ideal conditions for the spread of devastating fires. These fires, in turn, further compromise soil structure and reduce the amount of water available in the water table. The situation is aggravated by the fact that the Pantanal has lost 29% of its surface water, with 57% of its territory having been burned at least once in the last 36 years. This loss not only signals a decline in the health of the biome, but also reflects the profound climate changes that are occurring at a global level. The receding water level of the Paraguay River, which is registering levels close to historical lows, is another indicator of the severity of the situation. The impact of these changes goes beyond environmental degradation, also affecting the economy and society, with damage that overlaps and amplifies the challenges faced by the region. It is imperative that measures are taken to mitigate these effects and protect the Pantanal for future generations. Raising awareness of the importance of ecosystem services provided by biomes such as the Pantanal and the Amazon is a crucial step in this process.

The preservation of these ecosystems is not just a matter of nature conservation, but a necessity for the sustainability of our own way of life.

Henrique Cortez, environmental journalist, editor of the EcoDebate Portal

column3:
‘The emergency in the Amazon is everyone’s problem’, says Chief Raoni

His home is in a village in Mato Grosso, in the heart of the Brazilian Amazon. But for some time now, his stage has been the whole world. Wherever he is invited, he goes, because indigenous leader Raoni Metuktire, now 93 years old, has dedicated his life not only to defending the Amazon rainforest, but also to warning that, in the face of the climate disasters of our time, “nothing can be saved alone”.

This led him to walk the red carpet at the Cannes Film Festival a year ago, and to go to Belém last March, where French President Emmanuel Macron, accompanied by his Brazilian counterpart, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, presented him with the Legion of Honour insignia.

And now he has been given a new opportunity by Pope Francis, who wanted him to be among the protagonists of the international summit “From climate crisis to climate resistance”, which took place in the Casina Pio VI, in Vatican City.

Recalling the meeting he had with the Pontiff, Raoni told ANSA: “I asked him to make clear to the Catholics who follow him in Brazil what the Church’s orientation is on environmental issues, because sometimes they seem not to have understood the message”.

Speaking in the language of the Mebengokre indigenous people, Raoni stressed that “a void is gradually being created around our lands in the Amazon and there is no longer anything truly protected”.

“We live almost on islands and, as if that were not enough, there are people who are not satisfied, who want to attack even the reserves where we live, putting our survival at risk”.

“What is happening?” he asked, adding that he is “worried because people living in the developed world do not understand that this is a problem for us, but also for them”.

According to the chief, now in Brazil, “we are facing a ‘monster’ with two heads: on the one hand, the serious drought phenomena in the north of the country, where fires are multiplying, and, on the other, the tragedy of floods, such as the one that recently occurred in the south of Brazil”.

Focusing on indigenous lands, Raoni recalled that, “when Lula became president, he promised me that he would clearly demarcate them”.

“I am still waiting for that to happen. Of course, we have better relations with his government than when Jair Bolsonaro was in power. But right now for us there are many words, but few actions”.

Addressing the large group of experts who listened to him and who at the end of the presentation gave him a standing ovation at the summit, Raoni argued that “the developed world seems convinced of the urgency of the fight against climate change”.

“But now we need to decide to immediately finance the tools to start the necessary projects, before it is too late. It is useless to remember that, normally, we do not use money in our reserves. Money, in large quantities, is used in the developed world”, he said, guaranteeing that “the time has come to use [the money] to save life on the planet”.

column3:
Nostradamus’ Prophecies for 2024: King Charles’s Drama, War and Tsunami

Renowned French philosopher Nostradamus’s prophecies for 2024 have been revealed, bringing with them worrying news about what the coming year could hold for the world. Nostradamus, whose accurate predictions have included historical events such as the rise of Adolf Hitler and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, released his visions of the future in the book Les Prophéties more than 450 years ago. His words have been considered a ‘warning’ of what is to come.

One of the most alarming predictions suggests that King Charles could face difficult times in 2024. Although the text does not mention a specific king, it is speculated that it refers to the current leader of the British monarchy. Analysts have interpreted Nostradamus’ words as a possible abdication scenario due to persistent attacks on the king and his second wife, Queen Camilla.

In another intriguing prediction, Nostradamus foresees an imminent naval conflict, indicating that a “red enemy” will turn pale with fear, putting the ocean in a state of apprehension. Many believe that this red enemy is communist China, suggesting a possible confrontation in the Indian Ocean.

In addition, Nostradamus warns of disasters related to climate change. He predicts that the Earth will become increasingly arid, resulting in floods and rising sea levels as ice caps melt. The mystic warns of a possible great famine due to pestilential waves, indicating the possibility of a tsunami that would threaten crops.

The Future of the Catholic Church: Election of a New Pope

Nostradamus also makes a prediction related to the Catholic Church, suggesting that Pope Francis could die in 2024. Turning 88 in December, the Pope could be replaced by an “elderly Roman” upon his death. Although there are several potential candidates, the choice will be made between cardinals under the age of 80.

Nostradamus’s dire predictions for 2024 have the world on alert, prompting reflections on the uncertain future that awaits us. While some remain skeptical, the accuracy of the philosopher’s previous predictions is raising global apprehension about what’s to come.

column3:
Plankton observation: why is it so important to predict the next mass extinction?

What if we carefully observed the movements of plankton in the oceans? No, this is not a far-fetched suggestion to occupy your afternoons, but rather a very serious study with surprising results carried out by a team of researchers from the Universities of Bristol (United Kingdom), Harvard, Texas (USA) and Victoria (Australia), published in the journal Nature.

What happened 53 million years ago?

These scientists discovered that, around 50 million years ago (more precisely between 53 and 49 million years ago), almost all marine plankton, that is, all aquatic plants and animals that drift with the currents, moved to the higher latitudes, between the Antarctic Circle and the South Pole.

This surprising change preceded by several million years a mass extinction of marine species in the ocean. What is even more worrying is that during this Eocene period, between 53 and 49 million years ago, there was a “climatic optimum”, that is, a period of “persistently high” global temperatures that is curiously reminiscent of today.

Climatologists are inevitably very concerned, since this “Eocene climatic optimum” is close to the most pessimistic scenarios of global warming currently being studied. It is clear that plankton must be subject to close scrutiny at this time, because the slightest change could mean the same disastrous scenario of the Eocene, with a mass extinction of species.

An “early warning system”

Of course, the authors of the study explain that the past is never a reflection of the future and that this is only a correlation between the movement of plankton and the disappearance of species, and is in no way a causal relationship. However, they believe that plankton could act as a warning before a supposed wave of extinction of larger marine species.

Study co-author Dr Adam Woodhouse (Bristol) described the results as “exciting”, however, adding that observing plankton could provide an “early warning system” for predicting the extinction of life in the oceans. Indeed, by applying their computer model to the archives, his team revealed that, since the disappearance of the dinosaurs, changes in plankton have often preceded the extinction of certain organisms.

column3:
Perito Moreno Glacier calls for help

The majestic Perito Moreno Glacier, one of the icons of the Argentine Patagonia landscape, is sending a warning signal to the world. Located in Los Glaciares National Park, this ice giant, with its impressive area of ​​250 square kilometres and an average height of 60 metres, is more than a natural wonder. It is a testament to the power of nature and, more recently, to the urgent need for collective action in favour of the environment.

Declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1981, the glacier is part of the third largest body of continental ice on the planet, behind only Antarctica and Greenland. In other words, its grandeur and beauty serve as an unmistakable reminder of the indomitable nature. However, researchers at the Argentine Institute of Nivology and Glaciology have observed with growing concern the signs of imminent change.

A group of experts has been studying the effects of climate change on the Perito Moreno Glacier. According to the results, since 2021, the glacier has retreated by around 700 meters on the northern shore of the Los Témpanos Channel. This retreat surprised the scientific community, since until then, the glacier had gone against regional trends by showing stability, with little evidence of melting or significant retreat.

Influence of climate change

The explanation for this retreat lies in the climate changes that have been occurring on the planet. The increase in temperatures has resulted in accelerated melting of the glacier and the detachment of blocks of ice. In addition, the lack of precipitation that results in the accumulation of snow also plays a crucial role in this scenario, among other issues.

This scenario not only affects the delicate balance of the region's ecosystem, but also directly impacts tourism in the area. The hiking experience to the Perito Moreno Glacier has already been affected, with the trekking route having to be readjusted due to changes in the glacier's geography.

It is in this context that Patagonia Experience Travel, an agency specializing in trips to the Patagonian region, highlights the importance of embracing sustainable tourism as a way of uniting human beings in favor of mitigating the effects of climate change.

The agency's CEO, Jefferson Gonzalez, who has served as an ambassador for the Patagonian region in Brazil for 13 years, stresses that it is essential to raise awareness of the consequences of climate change so that this natural wonder can be preserved for future generations.

"We need to join forces to combat climate change, ensuring that, in a few decades, we will still have the privilege of contemplating these glacial formations," says Gonzalez.

column3:
Former leader of neo-Nazi skinheads says that Portuguese communists become “legitimate targets” if his sons are called up for war

Mário Machado, a well-known former leader of neo-Nazi skinheads in Portugal, sentenced to prison terms for several crimes, said on social media that if Poland invokes NATO article 5 and his three sons of military age are called up for “war”, all communists in Portugal will become legitimate targets. This is quite a contradiction, since the Portuguese communist party, unlike the parliamentary majority, is against Portugal’s integration into NATO, and United Russia, Vladimir Putin’s party, has an absolute majority in the Federal Duma (325 seats). It is a nationalist, conservative, populist party, and is affiliated with the Centrist Democratic International, an adversary of the Russian communist party, which has only 57 seats.

André Ventura's supporter based his argument on the news that Russia had hit Poland with 2 missiles, a news that has since been denied by Poland, which ultimately attributes the “unfortunate accident” to Ukraine.

Although Russia has not been communist for many years, and despite the fact that there are several Chega members who are also on Putin's side, as the Chega municipal deputy in Cascais, Maria Vieira, can attest, Mário Machado turns the targets onto the Portuguese communists:

Russia hit Poland with 2 missiles, killing 2 people. If Poland invokes NATO's Article 5, and 3 of my military-age sons are called up, all communists in Portugal will become legitimate targets.

Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty:

The Parties agree that an armed attack against one or more of them in Europe or North America shall be considered an attack against them all, and consequently agree that, should such an armed attack occur, each Party, in exercise of the right of individual or collective self-defence, as recognised by Article 51 of the Charter of the United Nations, shall render assistance to the Party or Parties thus attacked by taking without delay, individually and in agreement with the other Parties, such action as it deems necessary, including the use of armed force, to restore and ensure security in the North Atlantic area.

Any such armed attack and all measures taken as a result of such attack shall be immediately reported to the Security Council. Such measures shall cease as soon as the Security Council has taken the measures necessary to restore and maintain international peace and security.

column3:
More than 200 civilians killed in Russia's Belgorod region since invasion

"More than 1,100 civilians were injured and more than 200 people were killed," Viacheslav Gladkov told the Russian news agency TASS about the casualties caused by Ukrainian drone and artillery strikes on the region.

The Belgorod region shares a 540-kilometer border with Ukraine and is the Russian Federation entity most affected by Ukrainian military actions.

According to data from local authorities provided last April, more than 120 civilians had been killed in the region as a result of Ukrainian attacks since the beginning of the war.

In recent weeks, attacks have intensified against this Russian region, which borders the Ukrainian provinces of Sumy, Kharkiv and Lugansk from west to south, the latter of which was annexed by Russia in September 2022.

The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on 24 February 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from its Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort.

The past few months have been marked by large-scale Russian airstrikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kiev's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory close to the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014.

Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian Armed Forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of help from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
Moscow responds to Zelensky's statements on negotiations with Russia

For the Russian president's spokesman Dmitry Peskov, Ukraine must take into account the drastic changes in the country's borders since the start of the special military operation in the peace negotiations. Increasingly abandoned by the West, the country has accumulated significant losses in recent months.

Earlier this week, Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky said in an interview with CBS News that returning to the 1991 borders was no longer a prerequisite for negotiations with Russia. However, the Ukrainian still insisted that Kiev must regain the territory lost to Moscow by 2022.

That year, four former Ukrainian regions — Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporozhye — voted overwhelmingly to join Russia in a public referendum. The population followed suit in the Crimean peninsula, which did the same in 2014.

After the 2022 referendums, Zelensky banned all talks with the current Russian leadership, focusing on a formula for ending the conflict that requires a complete withdrawal of Moscow's forces from all previously mentioned territories.

Although Russia claims to be open to talks with Kiev, the country has rejected Zelensky's idea as "detached from reality".

Regarding Zelensky's statements, Peskov told Sputnik on Saturday (30) that "the geopolitical reality has changed dramatically since the beginning of the special military operation. The borders of both Ukraine and the Russian Federation have changed."

The spokesman also commented that Russia has already incorporated the four former Ukrainian regions, stressing that this reality "cannot be ignored".

Meanwhile, Russian Foreign Ministry official Maria Zakharova said Zelensky’s change of position was due to “nervousness.” “He has an election coming up. Or is there no election?” she asked. The Ukrainian president has previously indicated he has no plans to authorise a vote, citing martial law, which has drawn criticism both at home and abroad. Zelensky’s remarks followed a statement by Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmitry Kuleba, who said Kiev could engage with Moscow at some point after a summit in Switzerland later this year that is widely expected to revolve around Zelensky’s peace formula. Russia has said it does not plan to attend the event, even if it is officially invited.

column3:
Airbus says global fleet could reach 48,230 planes in next 20 years

Company says demand will be driven by wide-body aircraft

Airbus on Monday revised upwards its forecast for demand for aircraft over the next 20 years, Reuters reported. According to the agency, which cites an annual report on industry trends, the global fleet could reach 48,230 planes in the next 20 years, or more than double.

According to the document, the world's largest planemaker forecast the delivery of 42,430 new planes over the next 20 years, including 41,490 passenger planes, an increase of 4% in both figures since the previous study.

The report comes as the planemaker's long-range, single-aisle A321XLR is expected to gain certification in the coming days.

Boeing, which has been embroiled in controversy in recent times, is developing a long-range version of its 737 MAX. 

Airbus’s forecasts are based on economic forecasts suggesting that 1.7 billion people will join the middle class, with some disposable income to travel by air, over the next 20 years, according to Reuters. 

“We expect particularly strong growth in Asia and the Middle East, led mainly by India and China. China’s domestic traffic will surpass that of the United States,” said Bob Lange, head of market analysis and forecasting at Airbus. 

Airbus’s data highlighted the shift in focus to India, with three of the fastest-growing traffic flows serving the Indian subcontinent. 

However, aviation’s post-pandemic growth forecasts have put the industry at odds with environmental groups who question its record on tackling climate change. Airbus argues that delivering new planes would help reduce emissions as greener fuels are being developed.
