column3:
Analyst: Western elite used Ukraine as 'guinea pig for human trials' after 2014 coup

When conducting human trials, Big Pharma did not think twice about using hospitals in certain developing countries without "strict controls" for such actions, William Jones, a former White House correspondent and non-resident fellow at the Chongyang Institute for Financial Studies, told Sputnik.

Sputnik recently obtained a series of documents indicating that rheumatology drugs were allegedly tested for several years on psychiatric patients at a hospital in the city of Mariupol at the request of major Western pharmaceutical companies and with the assistance of Ukrainian authorities.

The documents contain information belonging to companies such as Pfizer, AstraZeneca, Celltrion, Novatris International AG, Merck KGaA and a Samsung subsidiary that produces medical equipment. The tests were carried out while the Kiev government held Mariupol, until May 2022, when Russia took control of the city.

Patients in the psychiatric ward of Mariupol Hospital No. 7 were likely used as vulnerable “guinea pigs” in experiments that would not have been permitted in the countries where these pharmaceutical companies are located, William Jones, a former White House correspondent for Executive Intelligence Review and a nonresident fellow at the Chongyang Institute for Financial Studies, Renmin University of China, told Sputnik.

“In general, it has been the practice to use some of the developing countries that do not have such strict controls for these types of experiments,” Jones noted, alluding to Ukraine.

After the 2014 Maidan coup in Kiev, the country “effectively became a ‘guinea pig’ for whatever experiments the Western elite forces had in store for them, as we see most dramatically in the way the ‘nation’ of Ukraine is being reduced to nothing by NATO’s proxy war against Russia,” the expert said.

He also addressed the issue of “the extensive network of biological laboratories that have been established in Ukraine over the past 20 years, largely with the help, and no doubt at the request, of the United States,” something Jones recalled having been repeatedly pointed out by Lt. Gen. Igor Kirillov, head of the Russian Defense Ministry’s Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defense Forces. 

“Given the current situation in Ukraine, with the growing understanding that Ukraine — or NATO — cannot ‘win’ this conflict using conventional weapons, as well as NATO’s determination not to accept a peaceful resolution unless Russia is defeated, this could very well lead to NATO using some form of biological warfare to ‘level the playing field,’” Jones warned. 

In the spring of 2022, Russia’s Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defense Forces brought to light the alarming extent of U.S. biomilitary activities taking place in several locations in Ukraine. These investigations revealed collaboration between Washington and Kiev in the research and treatment of several highly dangerous pathogens. Several of these findings were subsequently independently corroborated.

column3:
Russia 'has been successful' in combating US hegemony in Latin America, analyst says

Russia's soft power in combating US hegemony in Latin America "is successful," historian and international analyst Daniel Trujillo Sanz told Sputnik when commenting on Russian President Vladimir Putin's annual message.

In his annual message to the Federal Assembly on Thursday (29), Putin advocated strengthening relations with Latin American countries. He added that it is important for Russia to seek new points of convergence and deepen the full range of partnerships, especially with its Arab and South American counterparts.

Regarding the president's speech, Sanz said that "we saw a sober, concise and direct speech from President Putin, as always, clearly structured." The analyst drew a parallel between the words of the Russian head of state and those of Western leaders, "whose criteria seem to change every day."

"We can refer to [French President Emmanuel] Macron as an example. One day he leads a rebellion against NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization], the next day he proposes sending French forces to Ukraine and practically triggering a war," he emphasized. 

The analyst also gave other examples of Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, with the entry of Finland and Sweden into NATO. In addition, he drew attention to Germany's attitude "towards the terrible and very serious sabotage it suffered in its national interest with the explosion of Nord Stream". 

Still on Latin America, Sanz added that it is necessary to admit that the United States "continues to have hegemony or at least primacy in this regard". 

"Culture, music, lifestyle and clothing have clearly established themselves during the era of globalisation, and in this respect Russia must overcome decades of influence, especially in Latin America and other parts of the world. I consider it absolutely necessary for Russia to start taking part in this fight, despite the difficulties it will face."

On 29 February, Vladimir Putin delivered his annual message to the Federal Assembly. The president took stock of the country's situation and outlined the main lines of action in domestic and foreign policy for the next six years.

column3:
US and NATO have no interest in a fair resolution to the crisis in Ukraine, says Moscow

According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the United States are focused on an escalation of the crisis in Ukraine, which creates strategic risks and could even lead to a confrontation between nuclear powers.

"The United States and NATO do not show the slightest interest in a fair resolution of the current conflict. They are clearly not willing to consider Russian concerns and to work seriously on eliminating fundamental contradictions," said a statement from the ministry.

The special military operation will complete two years in February, amid constant Ukrainian defeats and the insistence of Vladimir Zelensky's regime on continuing the fighting at any cost to the country.

"The West is focused on the escalation of the Ukrainian crisis, which now represents the main strategic risks, as such a course could lead to a direct confrontation between nuclear powers with catastrophic consequences," the ministry added.

Moscow added that "the destructive policy of the United States has led to a deep deterioration of Russian-American relations and a radical change in the security situation." In addition, Russia has repeatedly indicated its readiness to negotiate, while Kiev refuses to engage in dialogue. Earlier, Moscow stated that there were no preconditions for the situation in Ukraine to move towards a peaceful solution, and that the priority goal was to achieve the goals of the special operation, which are currently only possible militarily. More than 600,000 people are in the combat zone More than 600,000 Russian servicemen are in the combat zone, Russian President Vladimir Putin said on Friday. "As for the decision to launch the special military operation, […] there were no other considerations other than one — defending Russia's interests. None at all. And there can be and have been no other motives when addressing issues of this kind," Putin said. He noted that Russia had previously tried in every possible way to build relations with Ukraine.

column3:
EU transfers part of profits on frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine

The European Union transferred, this Friday (26), around 1.5 billion euros in support of Ukraine, from the profits generated by Russian assets frozen in the bloc.

EU countries reached an agreement in May to use billions of euros generated by these assets to arm Ukraine and finance its post-war reconstruction.

The EU froze around 200 billion euros in Russian Central Bank assets held in the bloc as part of sanctions imposed on Russia due to its invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

About 90% of these funds are under the control of the Belgium-based financial services company Euroclear.

"The EU stands by Ukraine. Today we transfer 1.5 billion euros from Russian assets mobilized for the defense and reconstruction of Ukraine," said the President of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, in a statement.

The bloc announced that 90% of the proceeds would go to a fund used to buy weapons for Kiev, known as the European Peace Facility. The remaining 10% would go to the EU fund to support Ukraine's reconstruction. Russia called the move "illegal." "This is a reason to take action in response to illegal decisions like this one, which are implemented by the European Union," Dmitry Peskov, spokesman for Russian President Vladimir Putin, told reporters. Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shymgal thanked the support. "Thank you, von der Leyen and the EU, for your strong support and this important contribution to the defence and reconstruction of Ukraine," he posted on social media.

column3:
Little hope for justice on 10th anniversary of MH17 crash in Ukraine

Ten years after the downing of MH17, which was flying over Ukraine, the families of the victims have little hope of seeing those responsible arrested.

Hundreds of relatives of the 298 victims attended a tribute on Wednesday (17) near Amsterdam-Schiphol airport, from where the plane took off on 17 July 2014 bound for Kuala Lumpur.

Hours later, the Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 was hit by a Russian-made missile in an area of ​​Ukraine controlled by pro-Russian separatists. All people on board died.

During the ceremony, the names of all the victims were read out loud, most from the Netherlands (196), but also many from Malaysia (43) and Australia (38).

Dutch courts sentenced three men to life in prison in 2022 for their role in the disaster, including two Russians, but Moscow has refused to extradite any suspects. International investigators suspended their work last year after concluding there was insufficient evidence to pursue the suspects involved. "I don't think those responsible will serve their sentences," Evert van Zijtveld, who lost his 19-year-old daughter Frédérique, 18-year-old son Robert-Jan and his in-laws, told AFP. Dutch television broadcast the ceremony live and the national flag was flown at half-mast in many towns across the country. The Australian government, in a ceremony in parliament with relatives of the victims, said it would not back down "from its commitment to holding Russia accountable". "I recommit myself to our collective pursuit of truth, justice and accountability for the atrocities committed on 17 July 2014," said Australian Foreign Minister Penny Wong.

- "Hard to believe" -

The plane crashed in the early stages of the conflict between the Ukrainian government and pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country, during which Moscow took control of the Crimean peninsula.

In November 2022, a Dutch court found Russians Igor Guirkin and Sergei Dubinski and Ukrainian Leonid Kharchenko "guilty" of intentional homicide and sentenced them to life in prison.

The magistrates found that they were responsible for transporting the missile that brought down the plane from a base in Russia to the launch site, although they were not charged with firing it.

The three men refused to take part in the Dutch trial, which convicted them in absentia, and denied any responsibility. A fourth suspect, Russian Oleg Pulatov, was acquitted.

International investigators concluded that there was "strong evidence" that Russian President Vladimir Putin approved the supply of the missile that brought down the plane.

Moscow denies any involvement and has strongly rejected the court's 2022 verdict as "political" and "scandalous".

The European Union urged Moscow on Tuesday to "accept its responsibility for this tragedy and to cooperate fully in the service of justice".

The evidence presented during the trial "clearly shows that the BUK surface-to-air missile system used to shoot down Flight MH17 belonged without a doubt to the armed forces of the Russian Federation", EU foreign minister Josep Borrell said.

Moscow has refused to extradite the suspects, saying it would be against its laws.

"The invasion of Ukraine and the escalation of the war make it really hard to believe that one of them will be arrested soon," Evert van Zijtveld said.

column3:
Woman dies from ‘paralytic virus’ after being bitten by a mosquito in Spain

Granada Romero Ruiz, 86, died after being hospitalized for 9 days in a hospital in Seville, Spain, after being bitten by a mosquito and contracting the “paralytic” West Nile virus. The elderly woman’s son, Antonio Pineda, said she was in perfect health before being bitten.

“She had no underlying health problems, she was healthy, active and leading a normal life,” he told local media. Tragically, this is not the first time the virus has affected the lives of the Granada family. The woman’s husband contracted the virus in 2016.

In a statement on X published alongside a photo of Granada holding a beer, the city council of La Puebla del Rio, a municipality in Seville, said it regretted the incident and was working “tirelessly to ensure that all administrations do everything possible, without holding back, against the virus and that there is a permanent service against mosquitoes”.

New outbreaks of the “paralysing” West Nile virus

The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) says there have been new outbreaks in parts of Greece and Italy and is warning against the deadly virus.

“Europe is already seeing how climate change is creating more favourable conditions for invasive mosquitoes to spread to previously unaffected areas and infect more people,” said ECDC director Andrea Ammon.

Who is at risk?

According to health professionals, people over 50 and those with conditions such as diabetes, high blood pressure or cancer are at greater risk of contracting the disease.

What mosquito transmits the “paralysing” West Nile virus?

The Asian tiger mosquito — known to transmit several diseases, including West Nile — has been detected in the UK on several occasions since 2016.

The mosquito, known for the black and white stripes along its body and legs, can transmit several tropical diseases, including dengue, Zika and chikungunya.

What are the symptoms of West Nile disease?

The symptoms of the disease are similar to those of the flu (such as fever, body aches and headache), rash and feeling unwell.

Others may experience muscle weakness, confusion, loss of vision, numbness, stiff neck, diarrhoea and seizures.

What is the treatment for West Nile disease?

Treatment usually involves rest, hydration and over-the-counter painkillers.

Severe cases need to be treated in hospitals, as they can cause meningitis (inflammation of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord) and encephalitis (inflammation of the brain), warn the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

column3:
NASA says Brazil could become uninhabitable in 50 years; find out

Heat is expected to make human life impossible in at least five regions of the Earth in the next 50 years, including Brazil, according to a study by the US Space Agency (NASA).

The research found that rising temperatures combined with high levels of air humidity can cause thermal effects to which the human body would not be able to adapt.

The emission of greenhouse gases directly impacts nature, with increasingly accelerated and severe climate change across the planet. Rising temperatures make unseasonal heat waves more frequent and winters less intense or shorter than usual.

According to NASA, the body's cooling process occurs through perspiration, that is, sweat. Rising temperatures combined with humidity increase the sensation of heat and prevent sweat from evaporating, which keeps the body hot – and can be fatal.

The study indicates that temperatures above 37ºC – a mark exceeded in many regions of Brazil during the summer – with humidity levels equal to or greater than 70% can cause premature death after up to six hours of exposure.

The body can still sweat at temperatures of 45ºC and humidity levels of up to 20%. However, the research projects that with the thermometer at the same level and a humidity level above 40%, the thermal sensation can exceed 71ºC and be lethal.

Although the combination of these factors is considered rare, since hot days are characterized by drier air, the study found that the phenomenon has been observed in regions of the Persian Gulf and Pakistan since 2005.

In this scenario, NASA considered the trend of increasing temperatures in the coming decades, with climate change driven by the emission of greenhouse gases, and concluded that human life may be threatened in areas of the center-west, north, northeast and southeast of Brazil.

column3:
Impunity marks 10 years since the downing of a Boeing in Ukraine

One of the most important events of the long period of civil war in Ukraine that preceded the Russian invasion of 2022, the downing of a Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777 in the east of the country, completes ten years marked by impunity this Wednesday (17).

"Who fired the missile? Who gave the order?", asked in a video message the president of the foundation for the families of the 298 victims of the incident, the Dutchman Piet Ploeg. He lost his brother, sister-in-law and nephew on the flight.

An international investigation, which was able to collect the wreckage of the plane, reached several consensuses. First, that the anti-aircraft missile had been fired from a Soviet-made Buk system. Second, more controversial, that the weapon had been launched from territory controlled by pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine.

In 2022, a Dutch court, the country of birth of 193 of those killed while flying from Amsterdam to Kuala Lumpur (capital of Malaysia), sentenced three people to life imprisonment "in absentia" for more general involvement in the downing: Russians Igor Girkin and Serguei Dubinski, as well as Ukrainian Leonid Khartchenko. All of them operated with separatist forces in the region and, according to the European country's justice system, had worked to bring, deploy and then return the Buk to a Russian base in the region across the border. The case was closed in 2023, but the Netherlands filed a complaint against Russia at the European Court of Human Rights, directly accusing President Vladimir Putin of having authorized the operation. Separately, the International Civil Aviation Agency is still investigating responsibility, with a view to a possible civil lawsuit. The Kremlin denies all accusations, saying the trial was a Russophobic farce typical of the turbulent times that Europe is experiencing. From the beginning of the investigation, the Russians have tried to shift the blame to Ukraine. First, they suggested that the missile that shot down the Boeing had been launched by a Kiev fighter jet. Then, they suggested that a Ukrainian anti-aircraft system had been responsible for the tragedy. With ties with the European Union cut over the 2022 invasion, the chances of an agreed solution are slim. The then Dutch Prime Minister, Mark Rutte, a harsh critic of Putin, will now be the Secretary General of NATO (the Western military alliance). The three convicted men live in Russia and will not be extradited — the most notorious of them, Girkin, ended up falling out of favor for criticizing Putin's conduct of the war and was sentenced to four years in prison this year for "inciting extremism." For the victims' families, all that remains are doubts. "We will not rest until we reveal the truth," Ploeg said in the video. Over the years, the report has heard versions of what might have happened from people with access to security information in Moscow. The most likely scenario, they say, was an operational error on the part of the separatists, who mistook the Boeing on the Buk's radar for a Ukrainian plane.

When news of the plane's downing arrived, the initial reaction was one of shock and particular disbelief, given that Malaysia had lost an identical plane in the mysterious case of flight MH370, which had disappeared four months earlier after taking off from Kuala Lumpur bound for Beijing with 239 people on board — a case that remains unsolved to this day.

But the reality on the ground would soon give rise to outrage over what had happened. Between late 2013 and early 2014, the pro-Russian government in Kiev faced protests and was overthrown. Putin responded by annexing Crimea and inciting a civil war in the Donbass, a region that includes the Donetsk and Lugansk areas.

For Ukrainian filmmaker Marina Er Gorbach, who used the downing of the plane as a backdrop for her award-winning "Klondike" (2023), the episode was the first warning shot about the gravity of the crisis and yet it ended up being ignored in the West.

In an interview with Folha last year, she stated that the sanctions applied to Moscow in 2014 were too lax, leading to the escalation of the civil war, which killed around 14,000 people, and the full invasion eight years later.

The trauma of the unfinished episode spread throughout the commercial aviation industry. Just access any website that monitors aircraft traffic to see the black hole formed in the region, now widened by the war between neighbors.

column3:
Russia and Hungary criticize Paris Olympics opening ceremony

Russia, excluded from the 2024 Paris Olympics due to its offensive against Ukraine, said this Saturday (27) that the opening ceremony of the sporting event was a "huge failure", while Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban declared that the party reflected the "fragility and disintegration of the West".

Russian diplomatic spokeswoman Maria Zakharova highlighted on Telegram what she considered to be flaws in the show, which took place on Friday (26) on the Seine River.

"I had not planned to watch the opening. But after seeing the photos, I could not believe that it was not a 'deep fake' or photoshop", she wrote on Telegram. The ceremony was not broadcast live on Russian television.

Zakharova cited, among other things, the “collapse of transport” after the French rail network was sabotaged, and “spectators sitting for hours in the pouring rain”. “The organisers did not think about cloud dispersion or awnings,” she added, referring to the Russian practice of sending planes before large outdoor events to try to break through the clouds. Zakharova also said that the centre of Paris had been “turned into a ghetto for the homeless” and that “rats had flooded the streets” of the capital. The spokeswoman was particularly critical of the presence of drag queens at one point during the ceremony, whose performance was reminiscent of Jesus Christ’s Last Supper with his apostles. “In Paris, they decided that if the Olympic rings are multicoloured, you can turn the whole thing into a giant gay march,” she added. Only 16 Russian athletes accepted the invitation from the International Olympic Committee (IOC) to participate in the event under a neutral flag. In Hungary, Orban said the show had shown the West's "emptiness." "They have gradually eliminated metaphysical ties, with God, homeland and family," the Hungarian prime minister said, adding that this has led to "the absence of public morality." According to Orban, who defends an "illiberal" doctrine, "Western values, long considered universal, are increasingly considered unacceptable and rejected by many countries in the world," such as China, India, Turkey and the Arab countries.

column3:
Russian Senator: International Court's Verdict Is First Step Towards Truth About Situation in Ukraine

The lawsuit filed by Ukraine in January 2017 made several accusations against Russia, holding it responsible for the attacks in Donetsk and the downing of Boeing MH17. This Wednesday (31), the International Court of Justice (ICJ) found the country not guilty.

Following the verdict of the international court linked to the United Nations (UN), Russian Senator from Sevastopol Ekaterina Altabayeva told Sputnik that the decision is only the first step towards the truth about the situation in Ukraine.

In a historic decision, the court did not give in to Kiev's demands, which essentially asked for Russia to be recognized as an "aggressor state" and the Donetsk and Lugansk People's Republics (DPR and LPR) as "terrorist organizations".

Most of Ukraine’s claims against Russia in Crimea under the International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination were also rejected, ICJ President Joan Donoghue announced.

“In particular, this signals that the time will come when the Ukrainian government will be assessed. This is the first step, and the assessment of the Ukrainian regime and the investigation of the crimes of certain politicians, members of terrorist organizations such as ‘Azov’ in Ukraine will take place; I am sure that this will happen in the foreseeable future.”

The senator also stressed that the court’s decisions “put Ukraine in its place.”

“I believe this is an important signal to the international community; He says that it is necessary to objectively assess what is happening in Ukraine," he added. 

Kyiv's accusations

The proceedings, initiated by Kyiv in January 2017, addressed several issues, one of which was Russia's responsibility for the downing of a Boeing MH17 plane. However, the court rejected this demand, finding Russia not guilty of the incident. 

Furthermore, the court did not support Ukraine's arguments about Russia's alleged involvement and the responsibility of Donetsk militias in several attacks, including the shelling of the Bugas military checkpoint near Volnovakha; the military airfield in Kramatorsk; and the positions of the Ukrainian Armed Forces in Mariupol and Avdeevka, which occurred between 2014 and 2017. 

With regard to the accusations of financing terrorism, the court indicated that Russia had fulfilled its obligations to cooperate, including identifying and blocking funds used to finance terrorism.

column3:
Pentagon claims Ukraine's economic boom: 'A boon to our economy'

Workers from Texas to Ohio are benefiting from Washington's push to supply arms to Kiev, Lloyd Austin said.

The conflict in Ukraine is "a boon to the US economy" as it has created more jobs in the US military-industrial sector, Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin said. Speaking at a White House Competition Council meeting on Tuesday (5), the Pentagon chief promised that Washington would continue to push for a stronger defense industry, especially in light of the Ukraine-Russia conflict.

Austin said that US military assistance to Kiev has not only "saved lives" and kept Ukraine in the fight, but has also strengthened the US economy.

"These investments have expanded facilities and created jobs for American workers. And the weapons we send to Ukraine to help defend itself are made in the United States by American workers all across the country — from Texas to Ohio to Arizona," the official added. The conflict in Ukraine has also highlighted the need to improve military production, according to Austin, who stressed coordination with Washington's allies. He also urged U.S. lawmakers to adopt a national security package that would provide $60 billion to Kiev. The bill remains stalled in Congress amid opposition from Republicans, who have demanded that the White House address the security crisis on the border with Mexico. The United States has been Ukraine’s main military backer, providing Kyiv with about $45 billion in weapons between January 2022 and January 2024, while total commitments have reached more than $70 billion, according to the Kiel Institute for the World Economy. Reports suggest that the U.S. push to arm Ukraine has put significant strain on the country’s own arsenals. 

While officials in President Joe Biden’s administration have maintained that most funding for Ukraine is being spent domestically, some Republicans have criticized the White House for allocating taxpayer dollars to foreign countries rather than directly addressing domestic problems. 

According to a December poll by the Pew Research Center, 31% of Americans believe the U.S. is providing too much support to Ukraine, while 29% say the current level of assistance is about right. 

Russia has repeatedly denounced Western arms shipments to Ukraine, warning that they will only prolong the conflict. Russian Foreign Ministry official Maria Zakharova said in December that the US would likely continue to fuel the conflict in Ukraine into 2024 as long as it could withdraw funds from American taxpayers.

column3:
What were the consequences of Russia's Iskander strike on Patriots in Ukraine?

The attack on a Ukrainian military convoy in the Donetsk People's Republic was carried out using short-range ballistic missiles.

The crews of Patriot air defense systems supplied to Ukraine by the US, previously destroyed by Russian forces, were "almost certainly" eliminated, Forbes magazine reported.

The media outlet reported that the "persistence and good fortune" of a Russian drone operator "paid off on Saturday (9) when he located a Ukrainian convoy including at least two truck-mounted quadruple launchers for a Patriot surface-to-air missile battery" in the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR).

"The Ukrainians lost up to 13 percent of their Patriot launchers that day," so "the air over eastern Ukraine may have become much safer for the Russians," according to Forbes.

The report comes after a security source told Sputnik that two Patriot systems were among the military equipment of Ukrainian troops destroyed by a strike by the Russian Iskander surface-to-surface ballistic missile in the DPR. 

Data from the Russian Defense Ministry showed that the strike also destroyed an S-300 missile system of Ukrainian troops near the town of Pokrovsky in the DPR. 

The last time the Russian military hit a Patriot was in late February, when the launcher, tractor, ammunition and transport vehicle of the system were destroyed by high-precision weapons. 

In May 2023, the Russian Defense Ministry reported that its forces had destroyed a Patriot stationed in Kiev with a Kinzhal hypersonic missile. Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu announced a successful strike on another Patriot two weeks later. 

Western countries have increased their military supplies to Kiev shortly after the start of Russia's special military operation in 2022. Moscow has repeatedly warned against continuing arms deliveries to Kiev, saying it would lead to a new escalation of the conflict.

column3:
Lavrov: EU recommends Ukraine to invest in long-range weapons to hit 'heart of Russia'

According to Russian data, the European Union (EU) has made recommendations to Ukraine that it is necessary to invest in the supply of long-range weapons to "hit the heart of Russia", said Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov on Friday (16).

During his speech at the Euromaidan: Ukraine's Lost Decade conference, Lavrov also said that Western instructors directly help direct Ukrainian troops' strikes at Russian targets, and the West is participating in the war against Russia.

"There is no doubt that the West has declared war on us, they do not even hide it. And although they say in every possible way that 'they are just arming Ukraine, and it is fighting for itself', everyone understands that this is a lie.

He stressed that "the most important thing in a war is strategies, and strategies are not in Kiev, but far away".

"According to our data, the European External Action Service has made recommendations for Ukraine, which assume that the methods by which Ukraine is currently fighting will not be successful and Ukraine will lose. Therefore, it is necessary to focus on transferring weapons of even greater range to Ukraine, so that, as the European Union describes it, they will 'hit the heart of Russia', and thus once again sow confusion and panic and undermine the people's confidence," Lavrov said during his speech. 

The Russian Foreign Minister noted that the limit of Moscow's "gestures of goodwill" in the context of restoring relations between Russia and the West has been exhausted, Western countries have not reciprocated Russia's "good deeds." 

After Russian President Vladimir Putin's interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson, it became clear that until now the US society has been living in a complete information blockade, Lavrov noted. 

Finally, the Russian Foreign Minister said that on the issue of dialogue with Ukraine, the ball is not in Russia's court, first of all, Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky must revoke the decree prohibiting negotiations with Moscow. 

"I repeat once again about the existence of Zelensky's decree, which prohibits negotiations with the government of [Russian President Vladimir] Putin. Our president has repeatedly said when the West asked such questions: 'Make him rescind this decree and say so publicly.' The ball is not in our court, everyone understands that," Lavrov said.

column3:
Russia: Ukrainian forces used US chemical weapons during Russian military operation

Cases of the use of US chemical weapons were recorded during the special military operation, the head of the Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defence Forces of the Russian Armed Forces, Igor Kirillov, said on Monday (19).

According to him, two facilities in the US still store highly toxic reactive compounds that remained after the destruction of declared stockpiles of American chemical weapons.

The US was supposed to complete the destruction of declared stockpiles of chemical weapons in 2007, but did so only in 2023, Kirillov noted in a statement.

"The United States still retains highly toxic compounds after the destruction of chemical agents at the facilities in Blue Grass (Kentucky) and Pueblo (Colorado)," the Russian lieutenant general said.

According to him, the Armed Forces of Ukraine have repeatedly used toxic substances against Russian soldiers.

As an example, Kirillov cited the use on August 19, 2022, of a toxic chemical that is an analogue of the chemical warfare agent B-Zet included in Annex 2 of the Biological and Chemical Weapons Convention (BWC).

All documents at the disposal of the Russian Defense Ministry confirming the facts of violations by the United States and Ukraine of the provisions of the Chemical Weapons Convention have been handed over to the Investigative Committee of Russia for making a procedural decision, he said.

A similar substance, according to Kirillov, was discovered on January 28, 2024 during an operational search in a cache on the territory of Melitopol. "The toxic substance was in vials with the inscription Biosporin in Ukrainian."

Kirillov noted that Kiev is developing a “special chemical belt” tactic, which involves detonating containers with hydrocyanic acid and ammonia during the advance of the Russian Armed Forces.

The Ukrainian Armed Forces use toxic compounds not only in the course of hostilities, but also for carrying out terrorist acts. Thus, in August 2022, the head of the Kherson region, Vladimir Saldo, was poisoned with ricin. On December 5, 2023, Leonid Pasechnik, the head of the administration of the Lugansk People’s Republic (LPR), was seriously poisoned with phenolic compounds.

From September to October 2023, the chemicals were delivered to Kramatorsk and Kupyansk to be placed along the roads, said the head of the Radiological, Chemical and Biological Defense Troops of the Russian Armed Forces, Igor Kirillov.

column3:
Russian warships make routine visit to Cuba

Havana residents watched as Russian warships arrived for the second time in as many months, in what the Cuban Revolutionary Armed Forces called a routine visit.

Cuban officials fired shots in the air in a welcome as curious fishermen watched from Havana’s promenade as the ships sailed into the bay. Russian residents were among the few who woke up early to watch the fleet arrive.

The patrol vessel Neustrahimiy, the training vessel Smolniy, and support vessels — all from the Baltic Fleet — are scheduled to depart on Tuesday.

In June, a Russian nuclear submarine, frigate and support vessels flexed Moscow’s muscles in Havana harbor, less than 100 miles from Florida.

“Russia’s movements in the Atlantic do not pose any direct threat or concern to the United States,” a spokesman for U.S. Northern Command said, adding that the command monitored all approaches to North America. Tensions between the United States and Russia have risen since Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine, and Russian naval activity — while routine in the Atlantic — has increased because of U.S. support for Ukraine, U.S. officials say. At the same time, relations between Russia and Cuba, Cold War allies, have improved significantly as the communist-ruled country struggles with an economic crisis that it blames largely on U.S. sanctions.

column3:
Arrest of Russian 'chef' raises fears of Russian interference in Paris 2024

The recent arrest of a Russian man for alleged "destabilizing" activities against the Paris Games highlights the last-minute concerns of organizers that Moscow may try to disrupt the event, which begins next Friday (26).

The man, born in 1984, was arrested at his home in Paris this week and is suspected of "espionage with a foreign power to provoke hostilities in France", the prosecutor's office said last Tuesday (23).

The newspaper Le Monde reported that the police found documents "of diplomatic interest" in his apartment, and that he is suspected of working for the Russian security service, the FSB, after appearing on reality TV shows and having worked for a time as a chef in a French ski resort.

“We strongly believed that he would organize destabilization, interference and espionage operations,” French Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin told BFMTV on Wednesday (24), pointing to a variety of clues: “It could be cyber attacks that require complicity, it could be information manipulation...”.

The individual “is in the hands of the justice system, which could clarify the police’s suspicions,” explained the minister, commenting that the suspect’s presence on French soil is recent.

- Campaign to discredit the Games -

Darmanin recalled that “other Russian individuals” were recently arrested in the capital, and that French authorities have been observing a disinformation campaign aimed at discrediting the Paris Olympic Games.

The minister recalled a very recent video on social media by an alleged representative of the Palestinian Islamist movement Hamas, who threatened France with attacks for hosting Israeli athletes, but which turned out to be false content.

“We believe that this is a fake video spread by accounts that, from what we can see, are pro-Kremlin, pro-Russia,” the minister said, denouncing a “multiplicity” of maneuvers that could “cause damage to our country and raise concerns.”

Almost all Russian athletes have been banned from competing in the Paris Games as a diplomatic retaliation for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and only fifteen will participate under a neutral flag.

Over the weekend, Darmanin revealed that French authorities have rejected a “large number” of requests from Russian citizens to be accredited as journalists and cover the Games, due to suspicions that they may in fact be spies. Requests from Russian citizens to volunteer have also been denied.

Russia has denied its involvement in any destabilization operation against the Paris Games and said that refusing accreditation to Russian reporters “violates press freedom.”

In April, French President Emmanuel Macron assured that he had “no doubt” that Russia was targeting the organization of the Olympic Games, “including the information sphere”.

column3:
Putin warns US of Cold War-style missile crisis

MOSCOW (Reuters) - Russian President Vladimir Putin warned the United States on Sunday that if Washington deploys long-range missiles in Germany, Russia would position similar missiles within striking distance of the West.

The United States said on July 10 it would begin deploying long-range missiles in Germany from 2026, in preparation for a long-term deployment that will include SM-6s, Tomahawk cruise missiles and hypersonic weapons under development.

In a speech to sailors from Russia, China, Algeria and India to mark Russian Navy Day in the former imperial capital of St. Petersburg, Putin warned the United States that it risked triggering a Cold War-style missile crisis with the announcement.

"The flight time to targets of such missiles on our territory, which in the future could be equipped with nuclear warheads, will be about 10 minutes," Putin said.

“We will take mirrored measures, taking into account the actions of the United States, its satellites in Europe and other regions of the world.”

Putin, who sent his army into Ukraine in 2022, sees the war as part of a historic struggle with the West, which he says humiliated Russia after the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991 by invading what it sees as Moscow’s sphere of influence.

Ukraine and the West say Putin is engaged in an imperial-style land grab. They have vowed to defeat Russia, which currently controls about 18 percent of Ukraine, including Crimea, and parts of four regions in eastern Ukraine.

Russia says the lands, once part of the Russian empire, are now back in Russia and will never be returned.

column3:
Media: France tries to convince Baltic countries to send troops to Ukraine

The French government intends to build an alliance with the Baltic nations (Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia) that agree to the proposal to send troops to fight Russia, according to an article published by the US edition of Politico.

According to the article published this Saturday (9), the proposal was made by the French Minister of Foreign Affairs, Stéphane Séjourné, during his meeting in Lithuania last Friday (8), with Baltic counterparts and the Ukrainian Minister of Foreign Affairs, Dmitry Kuleba.

"It is not up to Russia to organize how we should implement our actions or establish red lines. So we decide that between us", declared the French minister, as reported by Politico.

Last week, French President Emmanuel Macron surprised many in Europe by saying that he does not rule out sending ground troops to Ukraine.

Despite opposition to Macron's statement from most EU countries, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are much more open to the idea, the article says.

On February 27, Macron reported that Western leaders discussed the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine during a conference held in Paris, but did not reach a consensus.

On February 29, Russian President Vladimir Putin warned in his annual address to the Federal Assembly, the country's parliament, of the tragic consequences if this decision were to be implemented.

Since February 24, 2022, Russia has continued the special military operation aimed at defending the Donetsk People's Republics (DPR) and Lugansk People's Republics (LPR), previously recognized by Moscow as sovereign states, against the genocide committed by Kiev, facing the risks to its national security posed by the advance of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) in Eastern Europe.

Moscow has repeatedly warned that NATO is “playing with fire” by supplying arms to Ukraine and that foreign arms shipments would be a “legitimate target” for Russia once they crossed the border.

In the words of Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, Russia sees direct confrontations between Russia and NATO as inevitable if the West sends its troops to Ukraine.

column3:
Senator on Sweden in NATO: Russia will respond by increasing its military presence in the West

After the protocol of Sweden's accession to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) came into force this Thursday (7), with the inclusion of the European country, the military alliance led by the United States now has 32 members. The group's advance was one of the reasons that led to the special military operation in Ukraine.

The measure has already provoked reactions from Russia, such as that of the senator from Kaliningrad, Aleksandr Shenderyuk-Zhidkov. In an interview with Sputnik, the parliamentarian stressed that the country will be forced to respond to the advance of the Western alliance, which has increasingly threatened international stability.

"Sweden's entry into NATO, of course, cannot but cause concern. Sweden has a very significant military force on the continent, and its neutrality for many years has ensured a balance of power both in the Baltic Sea and in Europe as a whole," said the politician.

With this, the senator points out, Russia will not remain inactive and "will be forced to respond to NATO's aggressive advance by strengthening its Western military presence".

"Our country has been ensuring the safety of navigation in the Baltic Sea for many centuries and will not allow its unilateral militarization", the senator noted.

Conflict between Russia and NATO

In recent weeks, statements have been made about a possible direct armed conflict between NATO and Russia, with the alliance's involvement in the fighting in Ukraine. In addition, Moscow has been warning for years about the organization's unprecedented increase in activity on its Western borders and that this will not be ignored.

Under the justification of "containing Russian aggression", the country has repeatedly expressed its concern about the alliance's increase in forces in Europe.

The Russian Foreign Ministry has stated that Moscow remains open to dialogue with NATO, but on equal terms, while the West must abandon the militarization of the continent.

President Vladimir Putin, in an interview with American journalist Tucker Carlson, explained in detail that Moscow has no intention of attacking NATO countries. Putin added that Western countries have begun to realize that Russia's strategic defeat in the conflict with Ukraine is impossible, so they should think about their next steps, and Russia is ready for dialogue.

column3:
US sabotage of Nord Stream could completely destroy NATO, expert says

An investigative journalist has assessed the situation surrounding the Russian gas pipelines, the investigation into which has already been abandoned by Sweden and Denmark, a move he sees as an attempt to hide the truth.

On Monday (26), Denmark became the second European country to officially close its investigation into the explosion in the Nord Stream 1 and Nord Stream 2 gas pipelines.

Nord Stream has played a crucial role in supplying German industry and providing low-cost energy across Europe.

Observers immediately blamed the United States for the event, which took place in September 2022, highlighting US President Joe Biden's enigmatic promise to "put an end" to the project if Russia deployed its troops in Ukraine in response to the oppression of the Russian-speaking population of Donbass. Denmark’s inquiry found that the explosions were an act of “deliberate sabotage,” but authorities have refused to investigate who was responsible.

Earlier this month, Sweden closed its own investigation.

“It’s an absolute farce,” investigative journalist Dan Lazare said on Wednesday (28).

“I don’t know how much longer this can go on. I mean, Denmark investigated, they came to a conclusion, and everyone knows that it was obviously sabotage — that was obvious from the beginning. And [Denmark] is refraining from pointing the finger at a likely culprit.”

He said he was 100 percent convinced that “the United States” was to blame and that “Denmark, Sweden, everyone is afraid to say this.” It's extraordinary." Lazare sees the situation benefiting far-right parties across the continent, such as the Alternative for Germany (AfD), which are the only ones willing to openly acknowledge the US's role in the act. "So if the AfD is rising in the polls, they have Joe Biden to thank, because Joe Biden blew up the pipeline, and everyone is afraid to admit it," Lazare concluded, also mentioning Donald Trump in the US, Marine Le Pen in France, Geert Wilders in the Netherlands and Giorgia Meloni in Italy. "The centre is self-destructing and is now practically introducing the far right to take its place," he said, predicting that establishment lawmakers "will pay a terrible, terrible price for covering this up [the Nord Stream sabotage]." At the same time, he said, "the political consequences would have been terrible" if the leaders had publicly acknowledged US responsibility for the Nord Stream sabotage. "When People admit what happened, NATO [the North Atlantic Treaty Organization] will basically go up in smoke, because an alliance is not a scheme for one member to attack another," he said.

"It is a mutual defense pact, and the US has violated it on a massive scale. This [sabotage] of Nord Stream is an event that will have repercussions for decades. It is an explosion at the heart of the Western alliance — it will completely destroy the Western alliance. There is no way NATO can survive this blow when it becomes too big to ignore," Dan Lazare made clear.

column3:
Beijing blames NATO escalation for Ukraine conflict, Chinese defense chief pledges support to Russia

China's defense minister says cooperation between Moscow and Beijing is a cornerstone for maintaining world peace and praised Russia's stance on Taiwan.

In his first public appearance since being appointed defense minister late last year, Dong Jun told his Russian counterpart Sergei Shoigu that strategic cooperation between China and Russia is a cornerstone for maintaining world peace.

During a video call meeting, the officials agreed that China and Russia should deepen their cooperation and respond decisively to global challenges.

"We have supported them on the Ukraine issue, despite the US and the European Union continuing to pressure the Chinese side," Dong said, promising that Beijing "will not change or abandon our established political course on this issue" even under the threat of more sanctions.

At the same time, according to the Chinese minister, China sees the "strong support of the Russian side on the Taiwan issue, as well as on other issues of our core interests," he added. "As two of the most important and fundamental forces in the world, we must respond decisively to global challenges," he reiterated. Dong also criticized the United States' attempt to maintain its hegemony by targeting Russia and China. "History and reality prove that hegemony is doomed to failure." The Russian minister said that, unlike Western states, Russia and China are not "creating military blocs" and military cooperation between the two is not "directed against third countries." Shoigu noted that "Russian-Chinese relations in the military sphere are developing steadily in all areas" and said he was looking forward to "close and productive cooperation" with his Chinese counterpart. China's stance on the conflict between Russia and Ukraine has created tensions between the Asian country and the United States. US officials accuse Beijing of supporting Moscow rather than demonstrating neutrality. China, for its part, blames the extension of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) in Europe for the crisis in Ukraine and has denounced the use of unilateral sanctions by the US and its allies as a tool of geopolitical pressure.

column3:
UN launches new guidelines to deal with extreme wildfires

The document "Voluntary guidance for integrated fire management: principles and strategic actions" updates two-decade-old guidelines from this UN (United Nations) agency and includes new recommendations "to address the challenges arising from the current climate crisis", the organization said in a statement.

By the end of the century, extreme wildfires are expected to become around 50% more frequent and environmental changes linked to climate change, such as more frequent droughts, high temperatures and strong winds, "will likely result in hotter, drier and longer fire seasons".

According to the FAO, around 340 million to 370 million hectares of the Earth's surface are burned annually by wildfires, with losses to sustainable development and the livelihoods of communities and generating large volumes of greenhouse gas emissions.

"How we respond to the challenge of wildfires is critical (...). We must shift our focus from reactive responses to proactive strategies and prioritize prevention and preparedness," said Zhimin Wu, Director of FAO's Forestry Division, who launched the new edition of the guide during the 9th World Forest Week, taking place in Rome.

The launch of the updated guidelines is "the debut activity" of the Global Fire Management Centre, established in 2023 by FAO and the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), with the support of the United States, Canada, France, Germany and Portugal, as well as the Republic of Korea.

The centre announced that it has already received funding worth almost five million dollars (4.6 million euros), "essential support for its mission to reduce the adverse impacts of wildfires on society, landscapes and the climate".

column3:
Foreign Ministers of China and Russia Meet on the Sidelines of Ministerial Meeting in Laos

The Foreign Ministers of Russia and China met on Thursday (25) and discussed the construction of "a new security architecture", Moscow reported, after the meeting that took place on the sidelines of the meeting of ministers of the National Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), in Laos.

At the meeting, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, discussed in "detail" issues of cooperation within the framework of ASEAN, the Russian minister said in a statement published after the meeting in Vientiane, the capital of Laos.

Lavrov said that, at a time when "some countries" are creating "a close alliance" with political-military mechanisms aimed at undermining security and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, the two Foreign Ministers discussed the construction of "a new security architecture".

Wang said China was “ready to work with Russia to maintain the ASEAN-centered, open and inclusive regional cooperation architecture” in the face of “external disruptions and obstacles,” China’s state-run Xinhua news agency reported. Lavrov and Wang spoke on the sidelines of the annual ministerial meeting of the 10 ASEAN members, which began on Thursday and will last three days and will also be attended by foreign ministers from outside the regional bloc. US Secretary of State Anthony Blinken is scheduled to attend the ministerial meeting next Saturday. The meeting comes a day after Wang met with his Ukrainian counterpart, Dmytro Kuleba, in China. China is an ally of Russia and NATO members consider Beijing to have played a “decisive” role for Moscow since its invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Ahead of the meeting, Lavrov said ASEAN was “one of the essential elements for a new multipolar and fairer order.”

column3:
Ukrainian court orders detention of suspect in murder of former nationalist MP

A Ukrainian court on Friday (26) ordered the pre-trial detention of the suspect in last week's murder of former ultra-nationalist MP Irina Farion, local media reported.

Farion was a member of parliament from 2012 to 2014 for the ultra-nationalist Svoboda party and was known for her passionate campaign against the use of the Russian language in Ukraine.

Ukrainian state-run media outlet Suspilne reported that a court in Lviv, in western Ukraine, ordered the suspect to be held in pre-trial detention for 60 days pending trial.

The defendant identified himself as Vyacheslav Zinchenko and was arrested this week in Dnipro, 800 kilometers east of Lviv.

The 18-year-old - who did not plead guilty - is charged with premeditated murder and could face a 15-year prison sentence.

Authorities announced Thursday the arrest of a suspect in the murder of Farion, a 60-year-old linguist who caused controversy for her staunch defense of the Ukrainian language after the Russian invasion that began in February 2022.

In 2023, Farion caused controversy by criticizing Ukrainian soldiers who continued to speak Russian while facing Moscow's troops.

Before the invasion, the use of Russian was widespread in Ukraine, especially in the eastern regions. Since then, many people have decided to stop speaking Russian, and the authorities have promoted Ukrainian.

Investigators believe that the perpetrator of the shooting that occurred on July 19 may have acted under orders.

Farion's funeral brought thousands of people to the streets of central Lviv, one of the historic strongholds of the Ukrainian nationalist movement.

column3:
Amorim: Assassination of Hamas leader was 'excessive and could be costly'

Haniyeh was a leader who talked, said Amorim. "Hamas carried out a terrorist action [against Israel, in October 2023] that we condemn, without any doubt. But it is not treated in most of the region as a terrorist group. It is treated as a political party, perhaps more radical, that frequents Turkey, a NATO member, and Iran."

"Our problem is with Netanyahu's government." The presidential advisor also criticized Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. "We cannot confuse the Jewish people, Netanyahu's government and the State of Israel. If he [Netanyahu] leaves power, he may be arrested, there are several accusations against him... War is a way for him to stay in power."

Haniyeh was wanted by the International Criminal Court. On May 20, arrest warrants were issued against the political leader and main interlocutor of Hamas for crimes against humanity committed since October 7. The same Court decision also issued a warrant against Netanyahu.

Russia x Ukraine

Amorim stated that "adopting Ukraine's principled and radical position" will not resolve the country's conflict with Russia. The diplomat defended the negotiation proposal signed by Brazil and China at the end of May. According to him, with the impasse in the attempt to find a resolution based on what Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky proposes, the plan drawn up by Brasília and Beijing is beginning to be noticed by other countries.

There is a positive harmony between Brazil and China, which are large countries, defend the UN Charter, defend non-intervention, and defend territorial integrity. Implicitly, there is a lot of criticism of Russia, but there is also no point in adopting Ukraine's principled and radical position, which will not work.

Celso Amorim, Lula's advisor on international affairs

At the end of May, Amorim traveled to China and signed with the Chinese Minister of Foreign Affairs, Wang Yi, the document called "Common Understandings between Brazil and China on a Political Resolution to the Crisis in Ukraine". The text contains six points that should be considered for the resolution of the war and the support of both countries for holding an international peace conference "at an appropriate time".

Venezuela

In the interview, Amorim also said that the delay of the National Electoral Committee disappointed the Brazilian authorities. The Minister of Foreign Affairs also stated that he believes that the non-profit organization that monitors elections around the world, the Carter Center, "is not rigged".

The presidential advisor also said that the Venezuelan context aggravates the situation. "In any country, the burden of proof lies with the one who accuses. But in the case of Venezuela, the burden of proof lies with the one who is accused, with the one who is the object of suspicion. Given everything that has happened, the entire political scenario, there is an expectation that Venezuela and the Venezuelan government will be able to prove the vote that he claims to have had." He stated that the records could clear up doubts regarding the electoral count. "I asked President Maduro about this [about the records], and he said it would be a matter of two or three days," Amorim told the presenter.

column3:
Ukraine cannot be discussed 'without addressing NATO's eastward expansion', says US observer

Russia has repeatedly warned NATO against expanding into Eastern Europe, which the Kremlin says could further fuel tensions in Europe.

American political commentator and podcaster Candace Owens stressed the importance of linking the conflict in Ukraine to NATO's continued expansion towards Russia's borders.

"No serious person can discuss what happened in that region without addressing the expansion of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to the east, despite the promises made by our government officials that we would not do so after German reunification," the observer wrote on her X account (formerly Twitter).

Owens noted that Russian President Vladimir Putin "stated this reason in virtually every speech he made before and after" the start of Moscow's special military operation.

The remarks came after the Russian head of state last year rebuked the US-led military bloc for repeatedly making “empty promises” not to expand eastward. In an interview with Chinese television, Putin noted that there have been “five waves” of expansion since the US administration assured Russia in 1991 that NATO would not expand eastward.

“And every time we expressed our concerns, they said to us: well, yes, we promised that NATO would not expand eastward, but these were verbal promises, specifically, where is the piece of paper with our signature? There is no such paper, so goodbye. You see, it is very difficult to have a dialogue with these people,” the Russian president noted.

Earlier, Putin made it unequivocally clear that if Ukraine were to potentially join NATO, it would pose a threat to Russia’s security and would in no way enhance Ukraine’s own security.

He also stressed that one of the reasons for the Russian special military operation is “the threat of Ukraine joining NATO.”

In recent years, the Atlantic Alliance has particularly ignored Moscow’s offers to NATO and the United States that sought to provide security guarantees. These proposals included an agreement that would impose a mutual commitment by Russia and NATO to refrain from deploying troops, ships or aircraft near each other.

In addition, Moscow has called for an immediate halt to NATO’s expansion towards Russia’s borders, stressing the importance of refraining from inviting post-Soviet countries into the bloc or deploying military infrastructure on their territories.

column3:
Syrsky blames mistakes by Ukrainian commanders on the front for jeopardizing the "sustainability of the defense"

The top commander of the Ukrainian military acknowledged difficulties in the Avdeevka and Zaporozhye directions in his statement.

The commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine accused on Thursday (29) certain commanders of the front ... Speaking at the Munich Security Conference, Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky blamed the withdrawal of Ukrainian forces on a lack of sufficient Western assistance and an “artificial shortage” of ammunition. The Pentagon has previously said that the Ukrainian military, without renewed US aid, would have to decide which cities it would be able to hold. The bill, which would provide, among other things, more than $60 billion (R$298.96 billion) for Kiev, has been approved by the US Senate but is stalled in the House of Representatives, the country’s lower house of Congress. Russia believes that arms deliveries to Ukraine and the training of its military are preventing a settlement and directly involving NATO countries in the conflict, which is “playing with fire”. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said that any arms deliveries to Ukraine would be a legitimate target for Russia.

column3:
Russia’s precision-guided glide munition to cause ‘tremendous headache’ in Ukraine, media say

The West’s proxy war against Russia in Ukraine is seen as on a downward trajectory to decimate the previously fearsome reputation of NATO’s expensive, high-tech weaponry. At the same time, Russian forces have unleashed a series of surprises in the conflict zone with updated, cutting-edge military technology.

However, another Russian weapon has reportedly piqued the interest of Western media outlets, amid concerns that it could add to Kiev’s headaches.

The new UMPB D-30SN interspecific glide munition appears to be generating a lot of interest because this precision-guided winged bomb is an over-the-range weapon that is rumoured to be suitable for launch from aircraft and ground-based multiple launch rocket systems (MLRS) such as Russia’s Tornado-S.

An over-the-range weapon can be launched from a great distance, allowing its user to avoid defensive fire from the target.

“If it can also be launched from the ground, it would provide extended and accurate range for Russian rocket artillery systems without the need to risk tactical aircraft. This could be especially useful for hitting time-sensitive targets at long ranges, such as artillery positions and air defense systems,” wrote the US-based news portal The War Zone (TWZ).

According to the publication, while details about the munition were still limited, the glide weapon, which resembles a small-diameter bomb, drew parallels with the US GBU-39 small-diameter bomb, which can also be launched from both air and ground. Ukraine, the outlet added, received the GLSDB ground-launched version as part of Western military aid packages received by Kiev.

column3:
Canada plans to transfer CRV7 air-to-air missiles to Kiev, but lacks warheads, media reports

Canada is considering transferring CRV7 unguided air-to-air missiles to Ukraine, but lacks warheads, CBC TV reported Friday (2).

According to reports, the Canadian Armed Forces have more than 83,000 of the missiles, which were retired from service in the early 2000s and would be dismantled.

A spokesman for Canadian Defence Minister Daniel Minden confirmed that the government is considering transferring the missiles.

"Before we transfer equipment to Ukraine, we work closely with Ukraine to ensure that any donations meet their military needs. We apply the same process to the CRV7 missile stockpile," Minden told the broadcaster.

However, a defence source said that not all of these missiles have warheads. According to the TV station, only about 8,000 missiles still have warheads in good condition.

Earlier, the United Kingdom proposed to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) to discuss sending an expeditionary force to Ukraine, as well as establishing a no-fly zone over the territory controlled by the Kiev authorities.

The offers come amid a series of problems between President Vladimir Zelensky's regime and the Ukrainian Armed Forces, which even this week saw rumors of an alleged dismissal of commander Valery Zaluzhny, which was subsequently denied by Kiev.

Russia previously sent a note to NATO countries on arms supplies to Ukraine, in which Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov noted that any cargo containing weapons for Ukraine would become a legitimate target for Russia.

Russia has been conducting a special military operation in Ukraine since February 24, 2022. President Vladimir Putin said that the operation aims to "protect people who have been subjected to genocide by the Kiev regime for eight years."

According to the president, the ultimate goal of the operation is to liberate Donbass and create conditions that ensure Russia's security.

column3:
We don't want the conflict in Ukraine to turn into a war between Russia and NATO, says Germany

The insinuation made on Monday (26) by French President Emmanuel Macron that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) allies could send troops to Ukraine is still having repercussions among European and North American leaders.

This Wednesday (28), Berlin made a point of making it clear once again that it will not send troops to Ukrainian territory and that it does not intend to expand the conflict.

"NATO is not and will not become a party to the conflict. This will continue to be the case. We do not want Russia's war with Ukraine to turn into a war between Russia and NATO. We stand united with all our allies. This also means: no German involvement in the war! And I can say bluntly, as Federal Chancellor, that I will not send soldiers from the German Armed Forces to Ukraine!", said Chancellor Olaf Scholz in a video published on the subject on his X account (formerly Twitter).

Washington also spoke out again today about sending troops through State Department spokesman Matthew Miller. When asked by a Sputnik correspondent about the matter, Miller said that "other nations will decide what they want to do. But on behalf of the United States, the president [Joe Biden] made it clear that there will be no American military presence on the ground," he said. According to the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, Maria Zakharova, France's allies did not understand or support the French president's idea. "This very statement shocked its NATO allies. Then, a few hours later, a series of statements were made by the leaders of NATO countries, [...] dissociating themselves from this statement by Macron. That they themselves do not plan anything like this, do not plan to send anyone and understand that this will be a different story," she said. Yesterday (27) Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that if troops are sent, "we will have to talk not about the probability, but about the inevitability of a direct confrontation between Russia and NATO."

column3:
"We see no action. Zelensky continues to massacre Ukrainian citizens"

Russian Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said on Wednesday that Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky cannot be trusted when he talks about possible negotiations with Russia.

"Nobody has any trust in him. Everyone understands perfectly well that this is a man who can distort everything, who can lie, who can abandon everything, as he abandoned even his own people, literally throwing the people of Ukraine onto a sacrificial altar," she said at a press conference, quoted by Tass.

In Zakharova's view, "nothing has been done by anyone" in relation to Ukraine, "neither by Zelensky, nor by his administration or other branches of government, nor by Western manipulators to repeal the law prohibiting Ukraine from negotiating with Russia."

"We hear a lot of words, but basically we don't see any actions. Well, except for the fact that Zelensky continues to massacre Ukrainian citizens," she added. Zakharova also suggested that Zelensky and his supporters "want to make another attempt to promote the so-called peace formula, which they are trying unsuccessfully." "They want to force literally everyone, to involve as many countries as possible in their discussion under false pretenses," she stressed. She continued: "There is nothing new in the intention of the Kyiv regime and its Western manipulators to redeem themselves through the failed so-called peace summit. We understand that these attempts will continue. Behind this is the desire to impose the 'Zelensky formula', which is a dead end, on a wide range of countries." It is worth recalling that in an interview with the BBC, Zelensky stated that talks with the Russian side were possible, despite the decree in force in Ukraine prohibiting such talks. "By putting pressure on Russia, I believe that it is possible to reach a diplomatic agreement. I think the power of diplomacy can help," the Ukrainian president said.

On July 15, Zelensky also said that Russian representatives should participate in an upcoming peace conference in Ukraine.

column3:
NASA study indicates that the Northeast and a large part of Brazil could become uninhabitable within 50 years

A study developed by NASA researchers revealed that a large part of Brazil could become uninhabitable within 50 years, due to the increase in temperatures on the planet. In addition to Brazilian lands, territories in Asia and the Middle East are also at risk of becoming inhospitable.

Published in the journal Science Advances, the analysis was developed by the team of researcher Colin Raymond, from NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. To reach the results, the scientists observed extremes of heat and humidity across the globe, using satellite images and wet bulb temperature projections, a method that allows the measurement of humidity in the air.

It is important to analyze humidity because, when it manifests itself in excess, it hinders the evaporation of sweat, which impairs the body's ability to dissipate heat and, consequently, overheats the body. Thus, the combination of high levels of humidity and extreme temperatures can be lethal.

AFFECTED REGIONS

According to research by the US space agency, the Central-West, Northeast, North and Southeast regions of Brazil will be the most affected in the country.

There is no exact date to determine when conditions in these places will become hostile, but scientists believe that the process should happen in the coming decades, driven by deforestation and the reckless consumption of natural resources.

In addition to Brazil, parts of Southeast Asia will also suffer the consequences of global warming, and may record worrying combinations of temperature and humidity by 2070.

In the Middle East, the regions near the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea are the most threatened. Known for their already high temperatures, these locations will see the thermometers rise even further in the coming decades, and may become uninhabitable within the next 46 years.
column4: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears', 'CC: Amplifying Climate Fears']
column5: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Earth will be uninhabitable soon', 'CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Amplifying existing fears of global warming']

column3:
Study shows that it is possible to recover 500 thousand hectares of Caatinga

An area equivalent to three cities in São Paulo can have its native caatinga vegetation recovered from deforestation and desertification. The information is contained in a survey released this week by the Dutch foundation IDH and the research institute WRI Brasil, both linked to sustainable initiatives. According to the study, the areas are located in Cariri Ocidental, in Paraíba; in Sertão do Pajeú, in Pernambuco; and in Sertão do Apodi, in Rio Grande do Norte.

The research highlights that native vegetation, if restored in these 500 thousand hectares, can offer sustainable income and jobs for local populations. This, in addition to providing water regulation, soil stabilization and erosion control. As explained by WRI Brasil's Projects and Research Coordinator, Luciana Alves:

"In the Caatinga, investments directed at productive restoration and also ecological restoration are an opportunity to establish processes for conservation and restoration, but which will also bring social results, economic results and maintenance for the people who already live in this territory, in addition to providing ecological benefits that are fundamental for the processes of adaptation and mitigation of climate change".

The survey also points out the best ways to recover these areas. Among them, honey production, planting forage palm - to feed livestock -, fruit crops, raising goats and goats, all within the Agroforestry System. This agricultural practice combines trees and shrubs with agricultural crops and raising animals in the same area.

According to Mapbiomas' Annual Deforestation Report, deforestation in the Caatinga has advanced in recent years. In 2023, for example, 201,687 hectares of Caatinga were destroyed; an increase of 43.3% compared to 2022.

In June of this year, the Ministry of Environment and Climate Change selected 12 priority projects for the creation of federal conservation units in the caatinga. These units should be implemented by 2026 and will increase the protected areas by more than one million hectares.

column3:
EU transfers over $9 billion in frozen Russian assets to Ukraine

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said the European Union will transfer €1.5 billion in frozen Russian assets to Ukraine on Friday, 26.

The decision comes after G7 and EU leaders agreed last month to use $50 billion of the profits from Russian assets frozen in European banks to finance arms purchases and reconstruction of the war-torn country.

“Today we are transferring €1.5 billion in revenue from frozen Russian assets to the defence and reconstruction of Ukraine. There is no better symbol or use for Kremlin money than making Ukraine and all of Europe a safer place to live,” von der Leyen wrote on her social media.

Western governments have frozen $300 billion in Russia’s central bank in response to the 2022 invasion of Ukraine. Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal thanked the EU for “its firm support and this significant contribution to the defence and reconstruction of Ukraine”. “Together, we are turning adversity into strength and building a more secure and resilient Europe,” he said. What Russia says Following the EU’s announcement, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov called the transfer of frozen Russian assets to Ukraine “illegal” and said Russia would take “thoughtful action” in response. “Such measures by the European Commission will not go unanswered,” he said. This is not the first time Russia has threatened retaliation against the use of its frozen assets to finance Ukraine. Last month, Russian President Vladimir Putin said the use of such assets was “a robbery that will not go unpunished.”
