column3:
Humanity is suffering from an 'epidemic of extreme heat', warns UN official

Guterres repeated his call for humanity to fight its "dependence" on fossil fuels.

"Today, our focus is on the impact of extreme heat. But let's not forget that there are many other devastating symptoms of the climate crisis: hurricanes of unprecedented violence, floods, droughts, forest fires, rising sea levels. The list goes on," he said.

"To address all these symptoms, we need to address the disease. And the disease is the madness of burning down our only home. The disease is dependence on fossil fuels. The disease is climate inaction," he stressed, calling in particular for G20 countries to take action.

While 2023 was the hottest year on record, 2024 could break a new record, with temperatures well above 40ºC becoming increasingly common.

In the space of a year, the 50°C limit has been exceeded in at least ten places, from Death Valley in the United States (53.9°C on 7 July) to Agadir in Morocco, but also in China, India and Brazil.

However, intense heat, often less visible than other devastating impacts of climate change, such as storms and floods, is more deadly.

This "silent killer" was responsible for around 489,000 deaths per year between 2000 and 2019, compared with 16,000 deaths per year caused by cyclones, according to the document "Call to Action", published this Thursday by the United Nations.

Exposed workers

Extremely high temperatures also have an economic impact. The UN estimates that losses caused by heat stress at work will reach US$2.4 trillion (R$13.5 trillion) by 2030.

According to a report by the International Labour Organization published this Thursday, more than 70% of workers were exposed to extreme heat in 2020, 8.8% more than in 2000.

"The good news is that we can save lives and limit this impact," Guterres said this Thursday.

The UN called on the global community to act first to protect "the most vulnerable", including young children, the elderly and the poorest.

In this context, early warning systems should include extreme heat, alerting populations about the arrival of heat waves and informing them about precautions to take, the document added.

The call to action also recommends "increasing equitable access and scaling up low-carbon cooling".

This would include investments in passive cooling systems – which include climate-sensitive urban measurements, reflective surfaces and natural cooling systems – as well as the elimination of greenhouse gases, which are used in many cooling systems.

column3:
Russia reaffirms intention to negotiate peace with Ukraine

Russia has never renounced dialogue, it has always been open to the negotiation process, the spokesman told reporters, commenting on Kuleba's remarks at a meeting in the city of Guangzhou with his Chinese counterpart Wang Yi.

According to Peskov, the statement by the Ukrainian Foreign Minister that his country was ready to start negotiations is in line with Moscow's position. We know from reports that this statement was made at the meeting with Mr. Wang Yi, he stressed.

The spokesman said that the details are not known at the moment, but they are important for moving forward in this direction.

The last round of negotiations between Russia and Ukraine on the cessation of hostilities took place on March 29, 2022 in the Turkish city of Istanbul, and since then the countries have not resumed negotiations.

Moscow has repeatedly stated its willingness to resume dialogue, but has made it conditional on Ukraine revoking its decree prohibiting the resumption of peace talks.

President Vladimir Putin has already set several conditions for opening peace talks, including that Ukraine withdraw its troops from the four new Russian territories (Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporozhye) and that it give up its plans to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).

He also demands that Ukraine maintain its neutral, non-aligned and non-nuclear status and that all sanctions against Russia be lifted. Ukraine has rejected the Russian proposal as an ultimatum.

Russian forces have been conducting a special military operation since February 2022 to prevent Ukrainian shelling of civilians in Donetsk and Luhansk, two territories that gained independence from Ukraine in 2014 and joined Russia in September 2022. According to the Russian leadership, the objectives of the military campaign are to stop “the genocide of the peoples of Donetsk and Luhansk by the Ukrainian regime” and to deal with the national security risks posed by NATO’s eastward advance.

column3:
Spain is the latest country to refuse to send European troops to Ukraine

Spain does not agree with the French proposal to send European ground troops to Ukraine, the spokesperson for the Spanish government, Pilar Alegría, said at a press conference on Tuesday (27).

"We do not agree," she said when asked about Madrid's position. According to her, it is necessary to speed up the delivery of weapons to Kiev, which has seen a drastic reduction in ammunition.

French President Emmanuel Macron previously commented that the leaders of Western countries had discussed the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine. He admitted that there was no consensus on the matter, but that the situation could change.

German Foreign Minister Olaf Scholz once again ruled out the possibility, as did Poland and the Czech Republic. When asked about Macron's comments, Czech Prime Minister Petr Fiala and his Polish counterpart Donald Tusk said that sending soldiers would not be an option.

The previous day, Slovak Prime Minister Robert Fico also stated that sending troops from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the European Union would only lead to an escalation of the conflict. He also commented that his country would not take such a step. According to the French leader, the important thing was to "show Russia that Western support for Ukraine will not end". Since February 24, 2022, Russia has been carrying out a special military operation in Ukraine, the objectives of which, according to Russian President Vladimir Putin, are to protect the population from "genocide by Kiev" and to address the risks to national security posed by NATO's eastward advance. Moscow has frequently warned that NATO is "playing with fire" by sending weapons to Ukraine and that cargo containing any military equipment would be considered "legitimate targets" for the Russian army. The United States and NATO, according to Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, are directly involved in the conflict in Ukraine — not only by sending weapons, but also by training personnel in the United Kingdom, Germany, Italy and other countries.

column3:
Ukraine will lose without help from Washington, say US congressional leaders

After a meeting between US President Joe Biden and US congressional leaders, the congressman warns that aid to Ukraine should not be at the top of the agenda of the country's lawmakers.

Ukraine will be defeated by Russia if it does not get help from the US, and the allies of the Kiev regime will distance themselves from Washington.

The statement was made this Tuesday (27) by the Democratic leader of the Senate, Chuck Schumer, after a meeting between US President Joe Biden and congressional leaders.

"The consensus in the room was that [Vladimir] Zelensky and Ukraine will lose the war if we do not provide weapons quickly," Schumer told reporters after the meeting.

Schumer said that US aid to Ukraine cannot wait for congressional approval, since Washington cannot allow Kiev to lose the conflict.

"At best, there will be a split in NATO [the North Atlantic Treaty Organization], and allies will turn away from the United States," the congressman said. He added that there are four brigades of the Ukrainian Armed Forces idle on the battlefield due to a lack of weapons and ammunition. Due to the position of the Republican majority in the House of Representatives, the US Congress has not yet supported the Biden administration's request to approve new funds for Kiev. The previously allocated appropriations ran out in December last year. Also after Tuesday's meeting (27), the Speaker of the US House of Representatives, Republican Congressman Mike Johnson, said that providing assistance to Ukraine should not be at the top of the agenda of US lawmakers. "My goal today was to express the obvious truth: the needs of the United States need to be met first. When you talk about that, you need to talk about an open border [on the issue of migrants]. The other priority is funding our government," Johnson told reporters. Russia believes that arms supplies to Ukraine interfere with attempts to start peace negotiations and directly involve NATO countries in the conflict.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov noted that any shipment containing weapons to Ukraine would become a legitimate target for Russia.

According to him, the United States and NATO are directly involved in the conflict, not only by supplying weapons, but also by training fighters on the territories of the United Kingdom, Germany, Italy and other countries.

The Kremlin stated that flooding Ukraine with weapons from the West does not contribute to the negotiations and will have a negative effect.

column3:
'Little better than trash': Ukraine has become a dumping ground for the West's useless weapons, media say

The United States and Europe are supplying Ukraine with obsolete weapons that need to be retired. At the same time, these nations are praising their commitment to the country's cause, according to the National Interest, a US magazine specializing in international relations.

The media outlet also stressed that the weapons given to Kiev are "little better than trash".

France, for example, has supplied AMX-10RC armoured vehicles, also known as light armoured tanks. However, the origins of this tank date back to the early 1980s and its last upgrade was in 2000.

The French army began dismantling these tanks in 2021, after they were deemed unsustainable for modern warfare. When these tanks were deployed for the special military operation, the Russian Armed Forces were happy to help France finish the dismantling process.

The Challenger-2 main battle tanks supplied to Ukraine were also at the end of their service life and had zero effect on the battlefield, according to the report.

The National Interest added that the US promise to supply more than 30 M1 Abrams main battle tanks caused euphoria in Kiev, but no one noticed the observation that the modern and updated version of the Abrams main battle tanks was not available.

Similarly, the overpriced F-16 fighters promised to Kiev will also not make any changes on the battlefield, as they are at the end of their service life, while Russia has fifth-generation jets that can destroy US warplanes with little effort.

The situation makes columnists wonder whether the conflict in Ukraine is not just a mere business for Western governments, while the lives of the Ukrainian people are used as symbolic money.

“A cynical person might conclude that this was deliberate, part of a larger plan to drain Western arsenals of weapons platforms deemed obsolete, in order to force these governments to buy more expensive and modern systems from Western defense contractors,” the magazine wrote. 

However, even top-quality Western weaponry is unlikely to change the tide of the conflict, since the Ukrainian military is not trained to use it properly. 

Since the beginning of hostilities, Russian authorities have warned the West against sending military supplies to Ukraine, stressing that they only fuel and prolong the conflict and are incapable of affecting the course of the special military operation.

column3:
Ukraine: US Congress-linked agency calls for better tracking of weapons shipments

Recommendations have been sent to the US Department of Defense regarding the need to ensure proper tracking of the path and use of US weapons in Ukraine. In January, Russia reported that illegal shipments had been detected as far as the Gaza Strip.

The US Government Accountability Office (GAO) has presented a series of recommendations to the Department of Defense to ensure proper tracking of the path and use of weapons delivered by the country to the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Reuters reports.

The audit and oversight body is linked to the US Congress, which, according to the report, weapons supplied by Washington take weeks to reach the country. In addition, the Pentagon does not provide clear guidance on tracking these deliveries, and the data from this military body is not necessarily accurate in this regard.

To ensure traceability, the GAO made eight recommendations, including improving the accuracy of supply data and evaluating Ukraine’s approach to controlling the end-use of weapons. It also calls on the Defense Department to develop a procedure to help regularly assess and improve the accuracy of delivery data and to develop written guidance to document roles and responsibilities. The Pentagon rejected the recommendation to clarify guidance for documenting alleged violations of the end-use of weapons, although it did accept five of the suggested measures and partially two others. Last month, it was reported that Pentagon investigators had opened more than 50 criminal investigations into “procurement fraud, product substitution, theft, fraud or corruption, and diversion” of U.S. aid to Ukraine. Western weapons in Gaza Ukrainian weapons supplied by the West can be found not only in the Gaza Strip, but also in Finland, Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov said in January. "The weapons that the West supplies to the Ukrainian regime have been found not only in conflict zones in the Middle East, but illegal shipments have also been detected in Finland, Sweden, Denmark, the Netherlands and the Gaza Strip," the minister said during his speech at an event on the situation around Ukraine.

column3:
Bundestag votes in favour of draft resolution on supply of long-range missiles to Kiev

The German parliament (Bundestag) voted on Thursday (22) in favour of a draft resolution presented by groups of the ruling coalition on the supply of long-range weapons systems to Ukraine to destroy strategic targets in Russia's rear.

"382 voted in favour, 284 against, 2 abstained," said the parliamentary speaker.

Earlier in the day, the Bundestag voted against the opposition Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and Alternative for Germany (AfD), which directly calls on the German government to start supplying Ukraine with Taurus cruise missiles.

"182 voted in favour, 480 against, 5 abstained," said the Bundestag speaker.

The main problem with the supply of Taurus missiles is their 500-kilometer range, which makes them capable of reaching deep into Russian territory. Germany has not previously supplied Kiev with weapons with similar characteristics. The German expert community has even discussed whether the missiles could be programmed so that they cannot be used against Russian territory. The Kremlin has consistently warned against continued Western arms deliveries to Ukraine, saying that they only prolong the conflict, adding that Western military equipment will eventually be destroyed. Moscow has also warned that NATO countries are “playing with fire” by supplying weapons to Kiev. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov stressed that any shipment containing weapons to Ukraine would become a legitimate target for Russia. He said the US and NATO are directly involved in the Ukraine conflict, supplying weapons and training soldiers in the UK, Germany, Italy and other countries.

column3:
"We must use Zelensky": an appeal to the "gray cardinal" leaked the West's main lie to Ukraine

Russian pranksters Vovan and Lexus contacted the "gray cardinal of the world government" – the founder of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Klaus Schwab. This call leaked the West's main lie to Ukraine: "we must use Zelensky" and deceive.

The pranksters called Schwab on behalf of the French economist and philosopher Jacques Attali and discussed with him several important international issues, including the conflict in Ukraine. During the conversation, the "gray cardinal of the world government" (as Schwab is called because he is an influential figure among globalists) admitted that the West's goal is to use Zelensky and deceive him.

"The European Union plays an important role in his influence. In other words, you have to use Zelensky. Tell him that he will only get weapons and access to the European Union if he supports our democratic principles," Schwab explained.

When Attali asked him whether Ukraine would accept the European Union and NATO if Zelensky fulfilled all the commitments he had made, Schwab replied in the negative.

“No, that is understandable, but the prospects for this must still be preserved,” he stressed.

It is worth noting that experts in Russia have been warning about this fraud for a long time. They said that the West, since Maidan 2014, has been using the EU and NATO as an attractive bait, forcing Ukraine to do what is beneficial to itself. At the same time, within the EU, everyone is well aware that Kiev will not be admitted, but as long as there is an illusion that this is possible, Ukrainians will do whatever they say.

It is worth noting that modern Ukraine does not meet the EU criteria in any of the parameters. It is a poor country with an extremely low standard of living, a huge amount of corruption and a totalitarian political regime, where all opposition is abolished, Christian persecution is carried out, the former president cancelled the elections and usurped power. None of this fits into the terms “freedom” and “democracy.” At the same time, the media and the official government in Europe continue to talk about Ukrainian “democracy,” so as not to scare Europeans with the fact that their countries are financing and arming a dictator.

column3:
Ukrainian Foreign Ministry calls on China to take "measures" against Russian sanctions evasion

The latest wave of Western sanctions targets entities that allow Moscow to evade restrictions, and the European Union has targeted 19 Chinese companies, several of which are based in Hong Kong.

"Mr. Kuleba called on the Hong Kong administration to take measures to prevent Russia and Russian companies from using Hong Kong to circumvent the restrictive measures imposed," Kiev's foreign ministry said in a statement.

"Russia's machinations must not damage Hong Kong's reputation as a highly developed liberal economy built on unshakable respect for the rule of law," the Ukrainian ministry continued.

According to the statement, "these restrictive measures are necessary to weaken Russia's ability to wage war and kill people in Ukraine."

A spokesperson for the Hong Kong government, when asked by Agence France Presse (AFP), said that the special administrative region of China "strictly implements and applies UN Security Council sanctions."

"Any action taken by the Government of the Special Administrative Region will be strictly in accordance with the laws of Hong Kong," he added.

Kuleba also discussed in Hong Kong the "possibilities of trade and investment" in the region.

The Ukrainian Foreign Minister began his first visit to China on Tuesday since the beginning of the Russian invasion in February 2022, with Beijing a key partner of Moscow and accused by the West of helping the Kremlin in its war effort.

During his talks with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, Kuleba indicated that Ukraine was ready to negotiate peace with Russia when the latter was ready to do so in "good faith".

At the meeting, the head of Kiev's diplomacy asked Beijing for support for a "direct dialogue" to end the conflict.

"In-depth, detailed and substantive discussions are planned with my Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, on ways to achieve a just peace," the head of Kiev's diplomacy wrote on the social network Instagram.

Russia said today that it is ready to negotiate with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, despite questioning his legitimacy, and does not rule out "various variants" of negotiations, according to Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov.

column3:
Hungary maintains veto on EU funds to Kyiv (if blockade continues)

The decision was announced by Hungarian Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó in an interview with private television channel ATV, referring to the European fund that Budapest has been blocking since May.

"Until Ukraine resolves this issue, everyone should forget about paying the 6.6 billion euros," he said.

On Monday, Hungary and Slovakia asked the European Commission to mediate with Ukraine, after Kiev included the oil company Lukoil on its sanctions list, implying the end of oil transit to the two countries via the Druzhba (Friendship) pipeline.

The minister stressed that Hungary will not support European Union (EU) financing for arms shipments to Ukraine while the energy security of the Central European country, which currently holds the six-month rotating presidency of the Council of the EU, remains at risk.

"Ukraine's decision not to allow Lukoil to transit oil through Ukraine poses a fundamental threat to the security of energy supplies to Hungary and Slovakia," Hungarian government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs said on Monday on the X social network.

Hungary and Slovakia depend primarily on Russian oil imports, and although sanctions on Lukoil have affected trade, the two countries continue to receive supplies from other Russian companies.

Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and his Slovak counterpart Robert Fico, both described as "pro-Russian", have opposed military support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion and advocate a negotiated solution to end the conflict.

The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from its Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow’s ability to finance the war effort.

The past few months have been marked by large-scale Russian air strikes on Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kiev’s forces have targeted targets in Russian territory close to the border and on the Crimean peninsula, which it illegally annexed in 2014.

Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian armed forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of aid from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
July saw the hottest day on record on a global average; here's why

The Earth recorded its hottest day in its entire historical series of temperature measurements this Sunday, July 21. And in the middle of summer in the northern hemisphere, many parts of the Mediterranean face extreme risks of forest fires.

The global value recorded broke the previous record, set a year ago, according to provisional data from the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service.

Global average temperatures have now reached or exceeded a key climate threshold for 12 months, highlighting the challenge of limiting global warming to less than 1.5ºC above the pre-industrial era, as established by the Paris Agreement.

– The Paris Agreement, signed in 2015, seeks to limit global warming to less than 2ºC above the pre-industrial average and, ideally, to 1.5ºC.

Climate change is increasing the frequency and intensity of heatwaves, causing extreme weather events, from floods to forest fires – in Brazil, the floods in Rio Grande do Sul and the fires in the Pantanal and Amazon are examples. 

In southern Europe, global warming is causing temperatures to exceed 40ºC, as has been the case in Greece over the past two weeks. As a result, the threat of forest fires is increasing. 

In Greece, at least 33 forest fires broke out between Sunday and Monday 22. Athens and parts of the south of the country remain on high alert. 

Cooler weather will bring some relief this week to the Mediterranean nation, although temperatures are still expected to exceed 39ºC in parts of the European continent on Tuesday 23. 

Spain is also at extreme risk of fires this week, as temperatures rise in the south of the country. Seville and Cordoba will reach 43C on Wednesday 24th, according to the Spanish meteorological agency AEMET. 

Parts of southern France and Italy are also at risk of wildfires. Further north, Berlin and Paris – which will host the Olympic Games from this week – are expected to face heatwaves in early August. The average temperature in the German capital is expected to rise to 28C on 6th August, eight degrees above the 30-year normal. 

Extreme heat has already wreaked havoc on many parts of the global economy this year, affecting everything from air travel to power grids. 

The average temperature for the year to June was 1.64C higher than in the 1850-1900 era, according to Copernicus. Last month was the hottest on record, a record that has been broken for the 13th consecutive month.
column4: ['Other']
column5: ['Other']

column3:
Russia may deploy missiles if US deploys long-range missiles in Germany

"I do not exclude any option," said Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov when asked about the possibility of deploying nuclear missiles if the United States of America (USA) confirms its decision, adding that such actions imply "the definitive end of arms control agreements in that area."

"In this situation, taking into account the combined capabilities of NATO member countries, we must evaluate our responses, without any internal limitations in terms of what, where and when [missiles] should or should not be deployed. This means that the options should be as broad as possible," the official noted, quoted by the Russian news agency Interfax.

In this sense, the deputy minister said that Russia's position "does not pose a threat to anyone, it is simply seeking the most effective way, also in terms of costs, to respond to changing challenges."

Ryabkov also assured that the Russian authorities will guarantee the security of the Russian enclave of Kaliningrad (a Russian enclave in the Baltic bordering Lithuania and Poland, two countries in the European Union and NATO), which has "long attracted the attention of adversaries".

"Should the representatives of the German government consider it justified to initiate measures for an escalation under the pretext of the situation in the region, we will respond with compensatory measures in the manner we consider most acceptable", he stressed.

"Nothing will stop us from solving the problems for our security along the entire perimeter of the Russian borders", he stressed.

Last week, Ryabkov had considered that "the nature of Russia's reaction" - should the US decide on such a measure, which would involve the first American shipment of these weapons to Germany since the end of the Cold War - "will be decided calmly and professionally".

The announcement by the United States and Germany indicates, as recalled today by the Spanish agency Europa Press, that the installation of long-range missiles aims to demonstrate Washington's "commitment" to NATO and a contribution to "integrated European deterrence", specifying that "these conventional long-range units will include (missiles) SM-6, Tomahawk and latest-generation hypersonic weapons, with a significantly greater range than current ground-based materials in Europe".

In parallel, the United States and four European countries - the Netherlands, Germany, Italy and Romania - announced on Wednesday the sending of anti-aircraft defence systems to Ukraine following the latest wave of Russian attacks that left 40 dead and 170 injured, as part of the military invasion ordered in February 2022 by President Vladimir Putin.

column3:
Zelensky? "Speaking in one tone about dialogue is better than the intention to fight"

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's statements about the possibility of talks with Moscow are better than his refusal, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters.

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on Monday that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's statements about the possibility of talks with Moscow are better than his refusal.

"In general, it is certainly better than the statements that any contacts with the Russian side and the Russian head of state are excluded. It is clear that speaking in one tone or another about dialogue is much better than talking about the intention to fight to the last Ukrainian," he stressed, as quoted by Tass.

However, according to Peskov, Russia cannot yet "assess what exactly is behind these words [Zelensky's words about the possibility of negotiations]." "What concrete plans are being discussed and what actions are being taken in this direction, if the talks are serious," he added. The Kremlin spokesman also suggested that Russia would "wait for some concrete actions, if any." In an interview with the BBC, Zelensky stated that talks with the Russian side were possible, despite the decree in force in Ukraine prohibiting such talks. "By putting pressure on Russia, I believe that it is possible to reach a diplomatic agreement. I think the power of diplomacy can help," the Ukrainian president said. On July 15, Zelensky also stated that Russian representatives should participate in an upcoming peace conference in Ukraine.

column3:
Poland comments on opposition to use of frozen Russian assets

Poland today commented on opposition within the European Union (EU) to the use of dividends from frozen assets of the Central Bank of Russia (BCR) in Western financial institutions for the purchase of weapons for Ukraine, the capital's press reported.

Two EU countries are yet to reach a consensus on the use of profits from the retention of about $300 billion of the BCR in banks, said the head of Polish diplomacy, Rodoslav Sikorsky, quoted by radio station RMF24.

The country's Foreign Minister revealed that he raised the issue of frozen funds with his French counterpart, Stéphane Séjourné, during a recent meeting of EU foreign ministers.

Canada, the United States, Japan and the EU retain BCR assets, including almost $6 billion on US soil, while $210 billion is deposited in the Euroclear bank in Belgium.

Several European nations proposed at the time that dividends from frozen Russian money be used to finance Ukraine's rearmament, something that Moscow rejected, and which threatened to implement painful countermeasures. Russia also warned that such action would create a disastrous precedent for the international financial system, since many countries, especially developing ones, keep their assets in Western banks, given their high reliability, which would now be called into question. Despite this, the main leaders of the group of seven most industrialized countries (France, the United States, Japan, Canada, Italy, the United Kingdom and Germany) agreed to allocate $50 billion to the purchase of weapons from Ukraine, using the funds withheld.

column3:
What did the meeting between Vucic and Macron reveal? Serbian diplomat points to disagreement over Kosovo

The magnificent reception given to Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic in Paris by French President Emmanuel Macron during the Serbian's official visit to France was overshadowed by the disagreement between the two leaders over the Kosovo issue, expressed at their joint press conference.

While both agreed that the European Union (EU) is an area of ​​common interest, the Serbian president did not like the way Macron spoke about Kosovo and Metohija, that is, that both sides, Belgrade and Pristina, are making equal efforts.

The Serbian president disagreed, stressing that Kosovo had failed to comply with everything, from the Brussels and Ohrid agreements, to the elections in the north, the expropriation of Serbian lands, the presence of Kosovo police, and even the shooting of Serbian children.

Serbia's position clearly stated

Diplomat and former ambassador Branko Brankovic told Sputnik that the Serbian president acted correctly and moderately, but with a clear attitude that he did not agree with Macron on Kosovo and Metohija.

"Vucic was certainly very detailed in his private conversation with Macron, but it is important that he made it clear at the press conference that Serbia maintains the position that Kosovo is not a state and that what EU states do is the utmost hypocrisy," the diplomat stressed.

According to the former ambassador, by placing Serbia as a sovereign state and Kosovo as a protectorate on the same level, Macron has shown that his views on the matter will not change.

On the other hand, Brankovic notes, they are aware that the EU cannot be complete without Serbia, but only Serbia on its own terms. That is why there is a lot of talk about this, because they would have a lot of problems if Serbia turned its back on the EU.

"It turns out that France does not deviate from the positions of Europe and, above all, from the positions of the West, that is, the famous trio of the US, the UK and Germany, regarding Serbia's position at the moment. Therefore, for Serbia's international position and for everything else related to future cooperation related to Serbia's accession to the EU," Brankovic added.

In other words, for the diplomat, the situation showed that Macron has stuck to a well-known position: independent Kosovo, and let's forget about cooperation with Russia.

Western desperation

"In this whole issue, I see desperation on the part of the West, because they have to put pressure on us, since they have squandered all the trump cards they had in relation to Ukraine, and the very existence of the NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization] pact has been seriously shaken," the diplomat said.

According to Brankovic, "this means that the European Union must seriously think about what to do, because what they invested in Ukraine was in vain because Russia is winning there, regardless of Macron's words that Russia should not win."

In the meantime, as he continued, "not knowing how to get out of Ukraine and save face, Macron and the others are trying to use the Kosovo issue to force us to take some action, which would give them justification for NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia and now Ukraine," the diplomat concluded.

column3:
How did a notorious Daesh terrorist manage to live quietly in Ukraine for months?

While Kiev publicly rejects accusations of being “hospitable” to international terrorism, even Ukrainian journalists admit that the country’s authorities are “strangely” turning a blind eye to the issue.

A high-ranking member of Daesh (a terrorist organisation banned in Russia and several other countries), Caesar Tokhosashvili, also known as al-Bara al-Shishani, lived “quietly” with his wife and three children in the Ukrainian town of Belaya Tserkov for more than a year before being tracked down and detained by the Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) in 2019, reports have revealed.

The news undermines Ukraine’s official stance against terrorism and indicates that the country continues to be a safe haven for such operatives.

The CIA operation to capture Tokhosashvili – who is of Georgian origin – was conducted in collaboration with the Georgian Interior Ministry and the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU). Even Western media at the time were left wondering: “Why did they choose not to arrest him earlier?”

What do we know about the notorious Daesh terrorist?

His arrest five years ago made global headlines, with The Independent quoting Philip Ingram, a former British intelligence officer, as admitting that Kiev’s “lax” government had created “an obvious vulnerability to international terrorism”, something he said “Kiev does not seem entirely interested in addressing”.

The former officer was echoed by Vera Mironova, a jihad expert and visiting fellow at Harvard University, who told The Independent that “hundreds” of former Daesh militants had “fled to Ukraine”.

“When these terrorists arrive in Ukraine, they rarely encounter any problems with the authorities,” Mironova said.

A similar tone was struck by Kyiv-based journalist Katerina Sergatskova, who noted that Ukrainian authorities remain “strangely relaxed about the issue.”

“Whenever I have written about the issue, government officials have accused me of making it up. But the arrest of a top Daesh commander here in Kyiv, right under our noses, would certainly suggest that many of the world’s most dangerous men think of Ukraine as a safe house.”

The SBU has repeatedly dismissed claims that Kyiv “was somehow hospitable to international terrorism.” Mironova warned that Ukrainian authorities would have “a big problem on their hands” if more Daesh members based in Ukraine “became terrified of being arrested.”

column3:
Supporting NATO troop deployment, alliance member calls for end to 'red lines' in Ukraine

Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda on Wednesday (13) called on Ukraine's allies to stop "drawing red lines" in terms of what they are willing to do to support Kiev.

Speaking at the Paris Defence and Strategy Forum, Nauseda made his comments based on statements by French President Emmanuel Macron when he suggested sending NATO troops to Ukraine.

Macron backtracked a few days later after backlash from his allies, but then said now was not the time "to be cowardly in Europe".

The Lithuanian leader said he welcomed the debate opened by the French leader on the troop deployment.

"I welcomed the idea of ​​sending missions to Ukrainian territory and I think we should discuss it. Of course, it would be better if we all unanimously agreed on the need for this and carefully assessed the intelligence and other information that we have obtained," Nauseda said, according to Newsweek. The Lithuanian president also stressed that fear of a possible reaction from the Kremlin should not be a determining factor in making a common European decision. "If we start saying 'no, [Russian President] Vladimir Putin will not like this or that [...]' we will never make a decision. And that is why yesterday [12] I told the president [Emmanuel Macron] and the media that we have to stop drawing red lines for ourselves," he added. He stressed that by drawing red lines, the West is only helping Putin "who is beginning to think that we are predictable and manipulable," he added. This is not the first time Nauseda has made such comments. In January last year, he said that "red lines must be crossed when supplying fighter jets and missiles to Ukraine", according to state broadcaster LRT. Moscow has made it clear that any shipments of weapons destined for Kiev will become a legitimate target for the Russian military on the battlefield. At the same time, President Vladimir Putin has warned the West about the consequences of sending troops into Ukraine.

column3:
Russia denounces that the US is covering up those responsible for the attack on the Crocus City Hall

The United States is covering up those responsible for the terrorist attack on the Russian concert hall Crocus City Hall, the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service has denounced.

"The Americans are protecting those responsible for the terrorist attack on Crocus City Hall," the organization said, quoted by its press office.

According to the note, "the Foreign Intelligence Service of the Russian Federation reports that the administration [of US President Joe Biden] is intensifying its efforts to create a distorted image of the major terrorist attack that occurred in Russia on March 22."

Washington also began covering up Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky shortly after the attack, the text adds.

The US State Department, its special services and affiliated organizations have been tasked with "eliminating any suspicion that the international community has about the involvement of Zelensky and his closest circle in the crime."

US agencies are trying to convince their allies that Daesh (a terrorist organization banned in Russia and other countries) is behind the attack on the outskirts of Moscow, Russian intelligence said.

'A terrorist war against Russia'

According to the statement, the current government in Kiev is waging an all-out terrorist war against Russia.

"The Kiev regime has been waging a full-fledged terrorist war against Russia for some time now, as its representatives, such as Kirill Budanov [head of Ukrainian Military Intelligence] and Vasily Malyuk [head of the Ukrainian Security Service] openly claim," the statement said.

On Sunday (31), the Russian Foreign Ministry said it had sent Ukrainian authorities demands for the arrest and extradition of all those involved in the attack on the Crocus City Hall and other attacks in recent years.

The ministry mentioned the murders of journalists Daria Dugina and Vladlen Tatarsky, stressing that investigations "indicate that traces of all these crimes lead to Ukraine."

column3:
Scenario of Military Takeover of Ukrainian Parliament Was Drafted by US, Expert Says

The takeover of the Ukrainian parliament by the country's military would not be a popular move, expert Aleksandr Dudchak told Sputnik, suggesting that a potential rebellion was orchestrated from the West.

The disillusioned Ukrainian military is planning to take control of the Supreme Rada (Ukrainian parliament), an exchange of messages from a private Telegram channel called ParaBelum obtained by Sputnik reveals.

"This could be a scenario of replacing Ukrainian President Vladimir Zelensky without holding elections," Aleksandr Dudchak, a researcher at the Institute of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) and an expert on the "Other Ukraine" movement, told Sputnik.

Members of the confidential channel, consisting of commanders and soldiers of elite units of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, were discussing options for overthrowing the current government and its military command following the resignation of then-commander-in-chief General Valery Zaluzhny.

“The most important action that we will need to take quickly is the capture of the Supreme Rada at a certain point,” one of the chat participants wrote. 

The members also expressed dissatisfaction with the decisions of Zelensky and the new commander-in-chief of the Ukrainian Armed Forces, Aleksandr Syrsky, who was appointed a month ago to replace Zaluzhny. The alleged coup plotters have made particular emphasis on the involvement of Ukrainian troops fighting on the front lines in the anti-Zelensky movement. 

According to researcher Dudchak, the involvement of Ukrainian personnel on active duty is fraught with risks, since those in the trenches are closely monitored by foreign mercenaries from “containment detachments” with orders to shoot anyone who abandons their positions. 

If Ukrainian troops are allowed to march toward Kiev, it would mean that the regime change scenario was written in Washington in response to Zelensky’s refusal to hold elections this year, Dudchak argued. 

The leaders of Ukraine’s elite units, the Security Service of Ukraine (SBU) and the nationalist Azov and Aidar battalions (Nazi terrorist organizations banned in Russia) are also reportedly planning to create a radical party with a military wing. 

The expert insists that none of Ukraine’s military and intelligence structures are independent, arguing that each has British or American “overseers.” 

“The confrontation between the military and the Kiev regime is, by and large, a manifestation of the confrontation between London and Washington,” Dudchak said. "The president's office is under British control, while the military, which is supposed to meet on Zaluzhny's behalf, is under American control, and the SBU is also a US-backed structure."

The consequences for Kiev would be dramatic and could seriously complicate the positions of the Ukrainian military on the front line, the researcher concluded.

column3:
Russia accuses Ukraine of blackmailing Hungary and Slovakia

"The decision of [Ukrainian President Volodymyr] Zelensky's regime to stop transporting oil to Hungary and Slovakia once again demonstrates Kyiv's inability to negotiate and its penchant for petty blackmail," Andrei Nastasin, a spokesman for the Russian Foreign Ministry (FM), said at a press conference.

He added that the transit of energy resources through Ukraine "has become a lever of manipulation for the Kiev regime, whose actions in this direction are encouraged by the West."

According to Nastasin, "Zelensky's bosses have set themselves the goal of definitively ending Russia's energy cooperation with those European countries, which are nevertheless guided by their own national interests and rational economic considerations."

The diplomat noted that "the new escalation of legal pressure against Lukoil" coincided with a series of diplomatic initiatives by Budapest to quickly resolve the conflict in Ukraine, and with the refusal of Hungary and Slovakia to support new European Union (EU) sanctions against Russia.

The Russian Foreign Ministry spokesman recalled that Ukraine is a candidate country to join the European Union (EU) and stressed that Kiev, "with its insane actions, threatens the energy security of two EU member states and, certainly, other member and candidate countries".

Hungary's Foreign Minister Péter Szijjártó accused the European Commission on Tuesday of orchestrating the interruption of Russian oil supplies to the bloc via Ukraine, and warned that the dispute could lead to an energy crisis.

In a message on Facebook, Szijjártó harshly criticized the European Union (EU) executive body, saying it had "done nothing" since Budapest and Bratislava asked it to intervene in the dispute over the delivery of crude oil.

"Despite the threats to the energy security of two EU member states... Brussels remains silent," Szijjártó wrote, adding that the European Commission is either showing too much "weakness" in protecting the interests of Slovakia and Hungary, or "it was Brussels, not Kiev, that invented all this."

Budapest and Bratislava continue to demand that the Brussels leadership take immediate measures to allow the transit of Lukoil oil to the two countries.

column3:
Ukraine responds to Hungary: Russian oil blockade "is not blackmail"

Ukrainian presidential adviser Mykhailo Podolyak assured this Friday that the decision to stop the transit of Russian oil from the Lukoil company through its territory "has nothing to do with blackmail", but rather with sanctions from Kyiv.

The statement by Volodymyr Zelensky's adviser, sent to the Reuters news agency, comes after Hungary and Slovakia asked the European Commission to mediate with Ukraine, which included the oil company Lukoil on its sanctions list, causing the end of oil transit to the two countries via the Druzhba pipeline.

On Monday, Hungarian government spokesman Zoltan Kovacs warned that "Ukraine's decision not to allow Lukoil to transit oil through Ukraine poses a fundamental threat to the security of energy supplies to Hungary and Slovakia".

Earlier this Friday, at a press conference, Gergely Gulyas, the head of the Hungarian Prime Minister's office, said that Ukraine was blackmailing Hungary and Slovakia, which "defend peace and a ceasefire." However, Podolyak has now assured that "the situation with the suspension of Russian oil transit through the Druzhba pipeline to Hungary and Slovakia has nothing to do with blackmail in the Ukrainian version," Podolyak said in a written comment. "Hungary and Slovakia do not present themselves as true guardians of peace and do not insist on peace and justice, but only on concessions to Russia," he said. It should be noted that Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán and his Slovak counterpart Robert Fico, both described as "pro-Russian", have opposed military support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion and advocate a negotiated solution to end the conflict.

Both countries depend essentially on Russian oil imports, and although sanctions on Lukoil have affected trade, both countries continue to receive supplies from other Russian companies.

column3:
Suspect in recent Moscow attack collaborated with Ukraine

According to the FSB note accompanied by a video and published this Friday on its Telegram channel, the individual confessed to having had links with Ukrainian security since February 2023.

Earlier, the FSB reported that Evgeny Serebriakov, involved in the explosion of a car in the north of Moscow on July 24, was deported this Friday to Turkey, where he fled after committing the crime.

Born in 1995, Serebriakov was captured on Thursday in the Turkish city of Bodrum thanks to the interaction of Turkish security forces and Russia, which issued an international search and arrest warrant against him.

During his initial interrogation, the individual said that, on his own initiative, he contacted the administrator of a social media channel “to collaborate with the Ukrainian special services” and that he subsequently established communication with a certain Ilya, an alleged agent of that country’s security service. The two communicated via the instant messaging application Wire, which allows the sending of encrypted messages, and on one occasion met in Istanbul. In the video released by the FSB, Serebriakov revealed that his alleged Ukrainian contact “proposed to eliminate an officer”, for whom he collected components of an explosive device west of Moscow. “On the instructions and under the control of Ilya, I made an explosive device and planted it under a car,” he confessed. On Wednesday, at around 6:00 am (Moscow time), the explosion of a bomb attached to a car injured two people, a man and a woman, in a residential area north of Moscow. Serebriakov managed to escape to Turkey on a commercial flight and arrived in that country as a tourist. On the same day, Russian authorities issued an international search and arrest warrant for the suspect.

One of the lines of investigation, according to the FSB, is that the attack was related to the professional activity of one of the victims.

column3:
Kyiv claims drone attack on Russian refinery

A Ukrainian defense source said that several drones attacked the Tuapse refinery, a city on the Black Sea coast in Russia's Krasnodar region (southwest), causing a fire.

"The extent of the damage is being clarified," the Ukrainian source said, specifying that it is a refinery owned by Russian giant Rosneft, equipped with a port terminal and that almost 90% of its production is destined for export.

On the social network Telegram, Russian regional authorities said, in turn, that the fire at the refinery was caused by "drone debris falling."

"The Kyiv regime has once again attempted to attack civilian infrastructure in Tuapse with drones," the Russian sources said.

About a hundred rescue teams were mobilized to the scene and brought the flames under control early this morning, and according to preliminary information, there were no casualties.

In addition, a tractor driver was killed today by a drone and his wife was injured while they were working in an agricultural field near the village of Ustinka in the western Russian region of Belgorod, according to the local governor, Vyacheslav Gladkov, who identified the unmanned aircraft as Ukrainian.

The Russian army announced today that it had shot down 80 Ukrainian drones since Sunday night, including 47 in the southern region of Rostov alone, on the border with Ukraine.

According to the source, one drone was destroyed in Belgorod, another in Voronezh, another in Smolensk, eight in Krasnodar and 17 in the Black and Azov Seas.

In a separate statement, the Russian military added that it had destroyed five drones at around 7:00 a.m. (05:00 GMT) over the Astrakan region.

Russia has announced on an almost daily basis that it has destroyed Ukrainian drones launched against its territory.

Kyiv argues that it is carrying out the strikes in response to Russian bombings that have plagued Ukraine since Russia invaded the country in February 2022.

column3:
Russia eliminates up to 245 servicemen, several artillery pieces and hits US Patriot system

In the direction of Donetsk, Russian troops have taken more advantageous positions, Ukraine's losses over the past 24 hours amounted to up to 245 servicemen, one tank and one British-made AS-90 Braveheart self-propelled artillery piece, according to a statement from the Russian Defense Ministry.

In turn, according to the Defense Ministry, in the Kharkov region, Russian troops hit a US-made Patriot anti-aircraft missile system, and in the same region, a weapons and military equipment repair facility was also eliminated. In the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR), Russian military personnel destroyed two Ukrainian Air Force Mi-8 helicopters on the ground.

In the Kupyansk direction, Ukrainian troops lost about 250 soldiers, seven tanks, seven Bradley infantry fighting vehicles, two armored personnel carriers, four cars, one M777 howitzer, two D-20 cannons and a number of other military equipment.

Over the past day, the Russian army repelled 12 counterattacks by Ukrainian troops and improved its position in the front zone in the Avdeevka direction. Enemy losses amounted to 460 servicemen, one British AS-90 Braveheart self-propelled artillery piece, one American-made M777 artillery system, one Msta-B howitzer and one American M119 cannon.

Russian units defeated two Ukrainian brigades and repelled a counterattack in the southern direction of Donetsk, Kiev lost up to 150 fighters and two armored personnel carriers.

Russian air defense systems shot down ten Himars and Grad multiple launch rockets, three Hammer guided bombs and 136 Ukrainian drones on Tuesday, the Defense Ministry reported.

In total, since the beginning of the special military operation, 577 enemy aircraft, 269 helicopters, 15,362 unmanned aerial vehicles, 485 air defense systems, 15,464 tanks and other armored combat vehicles, 1,238 multiple rocket launchers, 8,397 field artillery pieces and mortars and 19,709 units of Ukrainian special military vehicles have been destroyed, the Russian Defense Ministry summarized.

column3:
Russia denounces NATO for expanding its military potential to Russian borders

The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) is systematically strengthening its military potential along Russia's borders, from the Barents Sea to the Black Sea, Russian Security Council Secretary Nikolai Patrushev said in an interview with the Russian newspaper Argumenty i Fakty.

"Even the term 'eastern side of NATO' has appeared in speeches by the bloc's leaders and documents, including for all Eastern European countries bordering Russia and its allies. Belarus, as well as Romania and, more recently, Sweden and Finland," Patrushev said during the conversation on the occasion of the 75th anniversary of the creation of the war bloc.

"The alliance's leaders do not hide the fact that the largest military maneuvers near Russia's borders since the collapse of the Soviet Union, 'Steadfast Defender 2024', which are being held in Europe, are aimed precisely at 'containing Russia'. Last year alone, NATO and its member states conducted 130 coalition and more than a thousand national military exercises.

In addition, the secretary added that the plans of the United States and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) include preserving Ukraine, or at least part of it, "as an anti-Russian territory entirely under their control, completely dedicated to serving the interests of the bloc".

Patrushev also said that there is irrefutable evidence that Kiev, at the instigation of the US and NATO, after the February 2014 coup in Ukraine, intended to resolve the problem with the "stubborn" regions with extreme harshness and force.

'NATO trains mercenaries in several countries'

"NATO instructors are training mercenaries and saboteurs in various countries to participate in anti-Russian operations," Patrushev said.

According to the secretary, the war bloc actively participates in organizing shelling of Russian territories and makes decisions on further deliveries of weapons with increased long-range capabilities to Kiev.

"In fact, the Atlantic Alliance is a party to the Ukrainian conflict," he said. According to Patrushev, the recent statement by the head of the NATO Military Committee, Rob Bauer, about the bloc's preparation for an open conflict with Moscow is in line with all of its policies.

"In March, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg presented an annual report on the organization's activities over the past year. The entire document focuses on the main task of 'containing' Russia, and in particular China, which means that the Atlantic Alliance did not hesitate to go beyond its geographical mandate and openly declare its global ambitions," the head of the Russian Security Council said.

The long-term strategic goals of the United States, the United Kingdom and the "collective Western countries under their control," as Patrushev insisted, are to "weaken our country as an economic and political competitor and subsequently eliminate it from the political map."

"For this reason, officials in Brussels have identified our country as the main source of threats to European security and have explicitly enshrined it in NATO's strategic concept," the Security Council official concluded.

column3:
At least 20 Polish mercenaries killed by Russian forces on the front lines, fighter says

In an interview with Polish radio, a Polish mercenary fighting for Kiev gives a grim account of the situation on the battlefield. Moscow estimates that at least 13,387 foreign mercenaries have enlisted with the Kiev regime, of whom 5,962 have been killed.

At least 20 Polish citizens have been killed while fighting as mercenaries paid by the Kiev regime in the Ukrainian conflict.

The information was given by Piotr Mitkiewicz, a Pole who works as a mercenary for the Ukrainian forces, in an interview with the Morning Talk program on Polish radio station RMF, when asked about the number of Polish mercenaries on the front lines.

"There are not many. I have been there longer and I know most of those who are there. But I will say this: up to 20 of us have died," Mitkiewicz replied.

Mitkiewicz’s estimate is lower than that of the Russian Defense Ministry, which estimates that some 1,497 Polish mercenaries were killed in combat with Russian forces, out of a total of 2,960 who signed up to fight for the Kiev regime. In the interview, Mitkiewicz gave a grim account of the situation on the battlefield, saying that “all they want to do is kill.” “There are mines under your feet. A man can come within 30 meters of you and throw a grenade. Within 100 meters, there is a man with an [AK-47 Kalashnikov]. There is a guy standing 400 meters away with a heavy machine gun, he wants to kill you too. There is a sniper 800 meters away. A tank is firing two kilometers away and there is artillery 10 kilometers away, also firing at you.” Moscow estimates that at least 13,387 foreign fighters have taken up arms in support of the Kiev regime, of whom 5,962 have been killed. Although Poland has been responsible for the largest number of mercenaries, the United States came in second on the list, with 1,113 fighters, of whom at least 491 have been killed, according to Russian military estimates.

column3:
World has moved from post-war to pre-war, says UK Defence Secretary

UK Defence Secretary Grant Shapps has said the world has moved from a post-war era to a pre-war era, urging NATO allies to think about the future of the alliance.

“Today we need to think urgently once again about the future of the alliance. We have moved from a post-war world to a pre-war world,” he said in a column published in The Telegraph newspaper.

Shapps listed measures to protect democracy and the alliance, including redoubling efforts to support Ukraine, increasing defence spending by NATO members and strengthening the Euro-Atlantic defence sector. The situation where some allies are unable to spend 2% of gross domestic product (GDP) on defence cannot continue because NATO “cannot afford to play Russian roulette with our future”.

Among other things, the Defense Secretary said that the plot of George Orwell's famous dystopian novel "1984" was set in a world without NATO, but today is an even more dangerous time. Shapps also said that the UK "has always been a key driver of NATO" and is proud of it. London has been no less than a force to be reckoned with fanning the flames of the Ukrainian conflict, and these hypocritical "warnings" are no surprise. These efforts range from the failure of former Prime Minister Boris Johnson's attempts to reach a peace agreement between Russia and Ukraine in the spring of 2022 to the British government sending billions of dollars worth of lethal and non-lethal weapons there. Moscow has repeatedly claimed that London is depriving Kiev of the opportunity to end the conflict through negotiations, using the country as a "geopolitical tool against Russia." The bloc's siege of Russia has been in full swing for decades. After a massive post-Cold War expansion in violation of the West's pledge not to approach Russia's borders, the alliance recently absorbed Finland and Sweden in 2023 and 2024, respectively. In March, the Russian Foreign Ministry told Sputnik that the bloc's activities in Eastern Europe and the Black Sea region were part of preparations for a possible conflict with Moscow.

column3:
Last Sunday was the hottest day on record globally, says European observatory

Last Sunday, July 21, was the hottest day on record globally, according to preliminary data from the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service.

The average air temperature at the planet's surface on Sunday reached 17.09°C — slightly above the previous record, set on July 6 last year, of 17.08°C.

Heatwaves have hit large parts of the United States, Europe and Russia over the past week.

The Copernicus observatory confirmed to Reuters that the record for average daily temperature set last year appears to have been broken on Sunday, according to its records, which date back to 1940.

According to Copernicus, the new daily record could be broken in the coming days. Temperatures are expected to drop after that, but fluctuations are expected in the coming weeks.

"What is really surprising is the magnitude of the difference between the temperatures of the last 13 months and previous records. We are in uncharted territory and, as the climate warms, we will certainly break new records in the coming months and years," predicts Carlo Buontempo, head of the climate change department at Copernicus (known by the acronym C3S).

Every month since June 2023 — that is, 13 consecutive months — has been ranked as the hottest on the planet since records began, compared with the corresponding month in previous years, Copernicus said.

Last year, four consecutive days broke the record, from 3 to 6 July, as a result of climate change caused by human activities, mainly the burning of fossil fuels. In 2023, this pattern led to days of extreme heat across the northern hemisphere.

Before July 2023, the record for the average daily global temperature was 16.8°C, on 13 August 2016, according to the European observatory. Since 3 July 2023, 57 days have exceeded this figure. 

Some scientists suggest that 2024 could surpass 2023 as the hottest year on record, as climate change and the natural El Niño weather phenomenon — which ended in April — have pushed temperatures even higher this year. 

The Copernicus observatory, however, is cautious about commenting on this possibility. "For now, 2024 is warm enough for the whole year" to break the record, the European service said, "but the exceptional heat recorded in the last four months of 2023 makes it too early [to predict]."

column3:
Kremlin welcomes Trump's comments that Russia is a 'war machine' but keeps an eye on Republican

The Kremlin said on Friday it welcomed comments by Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump that Russia is a "war machine" that defeated Napoleon Bonaparte and Adolf Hitler, but said he was not wearing rose-tinted glasses when it came to the Republican candidate.

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov was responding to a question about comments Trump said he made to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy in a July 19 phone call.

Trump later told Fox News that he had told Zelenskiy the war had to end.

"This is a war machine that you're up against. That's what they (the Russians) do, they fight wars. They beat Hitler. They beat Napoleon. We have to end this war," Trump said.

Commenting on Trump’s remarks, Peskov said: “It will probably be useful for most of the American public to know that there are many glorious pages in Russian history, and in fact, probably few people in the US, that is, ordinary Americans and perhaps representatives of the so-called political establishment, know history so deeply.” But Peskov, when asked later about a Wall Street Journal commentary co-authored by Mike Pompeo, Trump’s former secretary of state, said the Kremlin had its eyes wide open when it came to assessing what a Trump presidency could mean for Russia. Pompeo’s comment suggested that Trump would impose tough new sanctions on Moscow if elected and increase aid to Ukraine. “We have never and do not wear rose-colored glasses. (Trump) is a representative of the US political elite, which is now absolutely suffering from the all-out anti-Russian sentiment,” Peskov said. "When he was president, under Trump, the Americans started this race for sanctions, under Trump a huge number of sanctions were imposed against our country and in that respect he is not very different to us from everyone else."

column3:
Russia ready to negotiate with Zelensky but questions legitimacy

"This is a difficult issue. From a legal point of view, it is a problem, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. Therefore, several options are possible," the presidential spokesman said.

Zelensky's legitimacy as president of Ukraine has been a question raised by Russia, which argues that the Ukrainian leader's term ended on May 20.

The Russian spokesman said that in addition to "problems with Zelensky's legitimacy", there is also "the problem of the ban on establishing any contacts or negotiations with the Russian side, since this ban remains in force".

"Therefore, there is still a lot to clarify and we need to hear some explanations," Peskov said.

Following Zelensky’s recent statements about his readiness to negotiate a peaceful solution to the war in Ukraine, the Russian presidential spokesman stressed that “Russia is generally open to the negotiation process, but it is necessary to understand to what extent the Ukrainian side is prepared.”

“So far, as you can see, we have heard very different statements, so far things are not very clear,” he added.

On Wednesday, Peskov recalled that Russian President Vladimir Putin had stated that “Zelensky has lost legitimacy” after the end of his term, which “is a factor that can significantly hinder the peace process.”

The spokesman also stressed that Russia will ensure the defence of its interests and security in any case, whether through negotiations or weapons.

“The special military operation was launched as a last resort to achieve our goals,” Peskov said, stressing that “any war ends with peace negotiations.”

In recent days, Zelensky has stressed the need for negotiations to end the war as soon as possible.

The Ukrainian president has recently held talks with political representatives in favour of an immediate ceasefire, such as Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba travelled to China this week to discuss potential peace talks between Ukraine and Russia.

Ukraine has been relying on financial and arms aid from Western allies since Russia invaded the country on 24 February 2022.

Kiev's allies have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort in Ukraine.

column3:
Trumpism's 'Nice to meet you' radicalism

The Republican convention here in Milwaukee brings together party officials and delegates from all US states and territories. Few of them are from the poorest sectors of the population. They are mostly white men in suits and Trumpist caps. There was little diversity in the audience. The atmosphere was festive. I did not witness any hostility. Many of the issues raised are legitimate. But the radicalism at other times of people with that friendly smile of "Nice to meet you" is frightening.

In his speech, Donald Trump once again used a slogan that has become famous in the current campaign. "Drill baby, drill!" they shouted. This phrase in English indicates that oil prospecting should be one of the Republican's priorities if he wins the election, ignoring warnings about the risks of using this polluting energy at a time of worsening climate change.

Immigration is another point that draws attention when Trump uses terms like “invasion” to describe the migratory movement into the US from the border with Mexico. Immigrants, who include many families with children, are classified as criminals by the former president. His voters cheer, shouting “build the wall” and displaying signs that say “mass deportation”. 

Weapons are also a strong topic among Trump supporters. At the convention, there were a number of t-shirts with slogans about the right to own and carry weapons. An irony, since weapons are prohibited at the convention, except in the hands of the police and the secret service. More seriously, Trump was almost killed by a 20-year-old who had access to an AR15 rifle and still did not change his mind. 

It is surreal to see some smiling and friendly women and men transform when defending radical policies. I remembered when I interviewed Israeli settlers and Palestinian radicals in the past. They talk with sympathy about absurdities as if they were normal.

column3:
'NATO must not cross red line in Ukraine', says Slovak Defence Minister

Slovak Defence Minister Robert Kalinak rejects the idea of ​​sending troops to Ukraine, saying there is a "red line" that must not be crossed.

In an interview with Ta3 News, Kalinak said that Western politicians are exploiting the conflict and the suffering of Ukrainians to achieve their own goals.

The possibility of sending troops to Ukraine was recently raised by French President Emmanuel Macron, who said that the "option" could not be ruled out.

Macron's comments, however, triggered a wave of denials from high-ranking government representatives of NATO member countries, including the United Kingdom, the Czech Republic, Germany, Finland and Sweden.

The Slovak Defence Minister warned that sending soldiers from the bloc to Ukraine "would significantly increase the risk of a global conflict". Kalinak added that those “who are serious about supporting Ukraine” should call on “healthy Ukrainians” to return home. He also called for an end to hostilities between Kiev and Moscow and said a non-violent solution was needed. The world is already witnessing the consequences of the conflict “down to the last Ukrainian,” the minister said, stressing that “it is time for [the world] to seek peaceful solutions.” Russia has repeatedly stated that it is ready for talks as long as the situation on the ground is on the agenda. Ukraine insists that any negotiations should only begin after Russian forces withdraw from all territories it claims. Moscow, for its part, considers such demands “absurd.”

column3:
Russia: US position on Crocus City Hall attack is clearly biased

Russia considers the US position on the Crocus City Hall terrorist attack to be clearly biased, Washington is trying to defend Ukraine, Maria Zakharova, the official representative of the Russian Foreign Ministry, told Sputnik.

Earlier, the head of the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB) Aleksandr Bortnikov said that preliminary data on those arrested in the case of the Crocus City Hall terrorist attack confirmed the Ukrainian trail, and that the security services will continue to work on the information.

"They exposed themselves. They [the US] started shouting, not calling for an investigation, and started shielding Ukraine from the blow. Their involvement and involvement in this story is obvious," Zakharova said.

According to the diplomat, in the absence of Kiev's involvement, Washington's first statements should have been about the need for an investigation and presentation of facts.

It is worth noting that shortly after the attack on Friday (22), the White House National Security Council's strategic communications coordinator, John Kirby, said that there was no evidence that Ukraine or Ukrainians were involved in the attack in Moscow. The US has subsequently repeatedly stated that there was no "Ukrainian trail" in the case. In particular, the US State Department stated that "there was no Ukrainian involvement in the attack on Crocus City Hall, period." In response, Maria Zakharova expressed doubts that the Washington authorities would draw "conclusions about anyone's involvement in the midst of a tragedy." The attack on Crocus City Hall, located in the city of Krasnogorsk, on the outskirts of Moscow, occurred on Friday night (22), when a large number of people were preparing to attend a concert by the Russian rock band Picnic. A Sputnik correspondent who witnessed the attack reported that at least three camouflaged men burst into the theater, shooting people at close range and throwing firebombs.

column3:
West would condone ‘virtually any crime’ Ukraine committed, military analyst argues

One example is the silence on Ukraine’s illegal use of anti-personnel mines, which were banned by the 1999 Mine Ban Treaty. The military equipment that became common during World War II was designed to kill or injure several people who were near the devices after they exploded.

The West would likely condone any crime committed by the Kiev regime against Russia, argued Boris Rozhin, a military expert at the Center for Military-Political Journalism.

In one example, Rozhin pointed to the illegal use of anti-personnel mines by President Vladimir Zelensky’s government. The 1999 Ottawa Treaty, or simply the Mine Ban Treaty, was ratified by Ukraine at the time and prohibits signatory countries from using anti-personnel landmines.

Since the beginning of the Russian special military operation, Ukraine has been using the equipment in its combat operations, including against the civilian population in the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR). However, there has been no reaction from Western politicians.

"So any crime that Ukraine might commit, all of them would be approved," Rozhin said, adding that outrageous acts that the West could not openly approve would be "contained at the media level."

"There is no reason to believe that the West would in any way condemn or protest against such use [of landmines] by Ukraine. On the contrary, the West supplies [Kiev] with the same type of anti-personnel mines that are being used against civilians, and this is approved by the Western leadership," he condemned.

As for Washington's turning a blind eye to its allies' use of weapons prohibited by international treaties, such as Israel's use of white phosphorus munitions, Rozhin explained that "essentially none of the international treaties work today."

According to the analyst, Western powers choose to abide by treaties that they consider advantageous at the moment, while those deemed disadvantageous to their interests are used to accuse Russia of one or another crime.

The conventions in question are not subject to independent monitoring, while international organizations are used by the West for propaganda purposes.

"That said, when it comes to the use of certain prohibited munitions, such as cluster munitions, accusing Ukraine of this is laughable," Rozhin said. According to the expert, "the United States, in particular, has supplied Ukraine with a large quantity of cluster munitions that are being used by Kiev both in combat and against civilians, so there is no reason to expect any reaction."

column3:
Putin says Russia will treat US troops in Ukraine as interventionists

Russian President Vladimir Putin has said that Russia will consider any US troops sent to Ukraine as interventionists.

The remarks were made during an interview with Dmitry Kiselev, CEO of the Rossiya Segodnya media group, which Sputnik is part of.

Putin responded to the announcement that the US would not send troops to Ukraine, saying that Russia would not underestimate the seriousness of such an action.

"We know what US troops are on Russian territory, they are intervention troops, and that is how we will treat them, even if they appear on Ukrainian territory," the Russian president said.

Putin stressed that Washington understands Russia's position on the issue. Tensions between Russia and the West have been rising since 2014, and the US and its NATO allies have supported Kiev.

Putin, in the interview, also did not rule out the possibility of Russia conducting nuclear tests if the US does so. "If they conduct such tests, I do not exclude it, it is not mandatory, if we need it, we do not need it, we still have to think about it, but I do not exclude that we could do the same." He specified that Russian forces are prepared for a nuclear war: "From a military point of view, of course we are ready. Our forces are constantly on alert." "I said that [US President Joe] Biden is a representative of the traditional political school, and this is being confirmed. There, besides Biden, there are many other experts in Russian-American relations and deterrence strategy. Therefore, I do not believe that everything is heading directly towards this, but we are ready." He stressed that there is a treaty that prohibits such tests. The Americans have not ratified the Comprehensive Nuclear-Test-Ban Treaty (CTBT), and Russia has withdrawn its ratification in order to maintain parity, the Russian president recalled.

"Since the treaty has not been ratified by the United States, it has not entered into legal force, because it has not received the required number of ratifications. However, we are still observing these agreements," Putin said.

However, he added that the possibility of conducting such tests is being considered in the United States. "This is due to the fact that when new warheads appear, some experts believe that it is not enough to test them only on the computer, they need to be tested in real conditions."

"Such ideas are circulating in certain groups in the United States. We know about this. And we are also observing it," the Russian president said.

The multilateral treaty was adopted by the United Nations General Assembly (UN) on September 10, 1996, with the aim of preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons in all its forms.

On November 2, 2023, the Russian leader signed the law by which Russia withdraws its ratification of the CTBT.
