column3:
Putin congratulates Maduro on victory, Kremlin says deepening ties

Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulated Nicolás Maduro on his victory in Venezuela's election on Monday, and the Kremlin said it was deepening cooperation in all areas - including sensitive ones - with Caracas.

Maduro and his opposition rival Edmundo Gonzalez both claimed victory in the presidential election, with Washington and some other foreign governments casting doubt on the official results that gave the incumbent victory.

The national election authority said Maduro had won a third term with 51% of the vote.

Putin has backed Maduro, 61, an ally who accuses the United States and the West of fueling the war in Ukraine, saying Moscow enjoys a strategic partnership with the South American country and that Maduro is always welcome in Russia.

"Russian-Venezuelan relations have the character of a strategic partnership," Putin said in a message to Maduro, according to the Kremlin. "I am confident that your activities as head of state will continue to contribute to its progressive development in all directions."

"This fully serves the interests of our friendly peoples and is in line with the construction of a more just and democratic world order," Putin said. "I would like to confirm our willingness to continue our constructive joint work on current issues on the bilateral and international agenda."

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Washington had serious concerns that the results announced by the electoral authority did not reflect the people's votes. The authority is supposed to be an independent body, but the opposition says it acts as an arm of the Maduro government.

But Moscow sees Venezuela as an important partner in Latin America, and the two sanctioned states have cooperated over the past two decades in areas including oil, weapons and military exercises.

When asked whether Russia would deepen cooperation with Venezuela, including in the area of ​​defense, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said: "We are developing our relations with Venezuela in all areas, including sensitive ones."

"This cooperation is in the interests of both the Venezuelan people and the Russians, so we will develop our relations with Venezuela comprehensively," Peskov added.

column3:
More than 200 civilians killed in Russia's Belgorod region since invasion

"More than 1,100 civilians were injured and more than 200 people were killed," Viacheslav Gladkov told the Russian news agency TASS about the casualties caused by Ukrainian drone and artillery strikes on the region.

The Belgorod region shares a 540-kilometer border with Ukraine and is the Russian Federation entity most affected by Ukrainian military actions.

According to data from local authorities provided last April, more than 120 civilians had been killed in the region as a result of Ukrainian attacks since the beginning of the war.

In recent weeks, attacks have intensified against this Russian region, which borders the Ukrainian provinces of Sumy, Kharkiv and Lugansk from west to south, the latter of which was annexed by Russia in September 2022.

The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on 24 February 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

Ukraine has been relying on financial and weapons aid from its Western allies, who have also imposed sanctions on key sectors of the Russian economy in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort.

The past few months have been marked by large-scale Russian airstrikes against Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kiev's forces have targeted targets in Russian territory close to the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014.

Now in the third year of war, the Ukrainian Armed Forces have been struggling with a shortage of soldiers and weapons and ammunition, despite repeated promises of help from Western allies, which have now begun to materialize.

column3:
In the middle of summer in the northern hemisphere, the world records the hottest day in history

A month after the start of summer in the northern hemisphere, the world recorded the hottest day in history last Sunday, July 21, according to preliminary data from the Copernicus Climate Change Service, linked to the European Union.

The global average air temperature on that Sunday reached 17.09 °C – slightly above the previous record, set in July last year, of 17.08 °C.

It may not seem like much, but the rise in temperatures is part of a dangerous trend over the last 13 months, in which each consecutive month has broken its respective records compared to the same month in previous years.

In the northern summer, heatwaves have already begun to hit large areas of the United States, Western Europe – especially in the Mediterranean region – and Russia last week. In addition to causing fires in California and causing Greece to close public monuments, the heat has also raised ocean temperatures and caused the earliest and most intense hurricane season in the Atlantic.

Previous record

The Copernicus Institute confirmed to the Reuters news agency that the average daily temperature record set last year was broken on Sunday, according to its records, which date back to 1940.

Last year, four consecutive days broke this record, from July 3 to 6. This is the direct result of the effects of climate change, driven by the burning of fossil fuels, which has caused increasingly extreme heatwaves and progressively higher temperatures across the planet.

Some scientists suggest that 2024 could surpass 2023 as the hottest year in Earth's history, as climate change and the natural El Niño phenomenon – which ended in April – have further increased temperatures this year.

column3:
Climate change could kill up to 14.5 million people by 2050

Established in Portugal in 1998, this day draws attention to the preservation of natural heritage, which is essential for people's well-being and the sustainability of economies.

Prepared by the North American management consultancy firm Oliver Wyman, in collaboration with the World Economic Forum (WEF), the study "Assessing the impact of climate change on human health" analyses the consequences resulting from the gradual increase in the planet's average temperature on public health.

"Floods represent the greatest risk of mortality, with an estimated 8.5 million deaths by 2050, followed by droughts (3.2 million) and heat waves (1.6 million)," says a press release announcing the report, which estimates that "the total costs for health systems to treat diseases caused by climate change will exceed one billion euros" in the same year.

In addition, the study analyses the negative health effects of tropical storms, forest fires and rising sea levels, indicating that nearly 70% of these deaths will occur in high-risk regions, especially in Southeast Asia.

Asia is the region where the impact of climate change on health is expected to be greatest, with "economic losses of around 3.2 trillion euros" being calculated.

In terms of economic losses, it is followed by Europe (2.3 trillion), South America (1.9 trillion) and Africa (1.8 trillion euros).

Due to the lack of resources and essential medical equipment, as well as inadequate infrastructure, the African continent "is in a position of greater vulnerability to the impacts of climate change on health than other regions".

The study by the strategic consultancy Marsh McLennan Group "presents emission reduction strategies to avoid economic losses of up to 11.5 trillion euros by 2050", considering that the role of the private sector is crucial and "should be encouraged by governments".

In terms of direct economic incentives, measures such as "tax credits, subsidies or research grants to support initiatives that aim to mitigate the impacts of climate change" are mentioned, and the creation of regulations "that stimulate innovation" is also proposed.

"The public sector has another essential role in the resilience of health systems to the effects caused by climate and weather changes, such as infrastructure capacity building".

column3:
Moscow accuses Kyiv of wanting to open the Black Sea to NATO

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky signed a decree on Wednesday on the new Maritime Security Strategy, which envisages "changes and innovations", especially in the Black Sea, and which is accompanied by a strategy with international partners.

The Kremlin (Russian presidency) spokesman, Dmitry Peskov, commenting on the Ukrainian initiative, warned that Moscow will take measures to ensure the country's security due to the "additional threats" posed by the presence of NATO ships in the area.

"The concentrated presence of NATO ships - and we take into account Bulgaria and Romania, which are NATO littoral states - poses additional threats to Russia, especially in the current situation," he said.

Peskov referred, in particular, to the "direct involvement of NATO countries in the conflict over Ukraine", according to the Spanish news agency EFE.

"Of course, Russia will take all necessary measures to ensure its own security," he said.

Peskov also recalled that "the presence of non-Black Sea states" in those waters "is regulated very strictly by the Montreux Convention".

"Turkey is, in this case, the administrator and performs its functions very clearly", he added, quoted by the Spanish agency Europa Press.

Dated 1936, the Montreux Convention gives Turkey control of the Bosphorus and Dardanelles straits that connect the Black and Mediterranean Seas.

Merchant ships enjoy freedom of passage, but warships are subject to restrictions "that vary depending on whether or not these ships belong to the Black Sea states", according to the Turkish government.

The representative of Crimea in the Russian parliament, Mikhail Sheremet, also accused Zelenskyy today of wanting to prolong the conflict with Russia, according to the Russian agency TASS.

Sheremet said that Kiev's new maritime security strategy is aimed at building up Ukrainian naval forces and ensuring the presence of North Atlantic Treaty Organization forces in the Black Sea. According to the Crimean MP, if Ukraine's military pressure weakens, Zelensky will no longer be needed by the West and NATO countries will stop supporting him as Ukrainian leader. Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula from Ukraine in 2014 and, since the February 2022 invasion, has added the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Lugansk, Kherson and Zaporizhia to the list.

column3:
Russia says it is open to talks with Ukraine as long as Zelenskiy is in power, but needs more details

The Kremlin signaled on Thursday that it is open to negotiations with Ukraine to end the conflict while Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy remains in power, despite publicly questioning his legitimacy to rule.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba said on Wednesday during a visit to China that Kiev was prepared to hold talks with Russia as long as Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity were fully respected, though he said Ukraine saw no sign of that.

The Kremlin, while signaling its readiness for talks on its own terms, has publicly questioned Zelenskiy’s mandate to rule, noting that his five-year term expired in May and that he should have called an election.

Zelenskiy and the West argue that normal political rules must be suspended in wartime and that the Kremlin, given Russia’s tightly controlled political system, is in no position to criticize.

When asked on Thursday whether Russia would be ready to hold talks with Ukraine while Zelenskiy was in power, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters:

“Russia is generally open to a negotiation process. But first we need to understand how ready the Ukrainian side is for this and how much the Ukrainian side is allowed to do this by its handlers.”

Moscow describes Zelenskiy as a puppet of the United States, a characterization it rejects.

"Because so far we see very different statements being made, and this is still not very clear. Also, in addition to the problem with Zelenskiy's legitimacy, there is also a problem with the (Ukrainian) legal ban on having any contacts and negotiations with the Russian side. So there is still a lot to be clarified and clarifications to be heard," Peskov said.

Pressed during a conference call whether the Kremlin would consider the possibility of negotiating with Zelenskiy or whether it categorically ruled out such a possibility, Peskov said:

"The question is not easy. From a legal point of view, this problem (of his legitimacy) is on the agenda, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. So different options are possible here."

Reuters reported in May that Putin was ready to end the war in Ukraine with a negotiated ceasefire, but the Kremlin chief was prepared to continue fighting if Kiev and the West did not respond.

In June, Putin said Russia would end the war in Ukraine, what he calls a special military operation, only if Kiev agreed to abandon its NATO ambitions and hand over four provinces claimed by Moscow, demands Kiev quickly rejected as tantamount to surrender.

column3:
Climate activists or useful idiots?

“For the liberation of Palestine from the clutches of the Zionist state, for the end of genocide and for the end of fossil fuels.”

The pinnacle of useful idiocy. Historically, young people have always been pawns of certain ideological elites. Social movements are almost always inorganic, almost always artificial, created in universities and then amplified by the “owners” of the narratives and by the holders of the dominant instruments in the communication system, in this case the media.

It is no coincidence that social networks are completely attacked in every way, precisely because of this. What social networks came to do was to take away the monopoly of narratives from the owners of the communication system.

What is the main objective of these social movements?

The main or only objective, regardless of whether the activists are aware of it or not, some will be aware, others have no idea at all – they believe they are defending very important causes. But the main objective is the destruction of the infrastructure of Western society, or in Marxist terms, of “bourgeois capitalist” society.

They use numerous tools: the LGBT movement, instrumentalized to destroy the traditional family, which is the basis of any healthy and civilized society and is the basis of Western civilization. “Climate madness”, which aims to take away people’s freedoms. The end of fossil fuels, which is linked to climate change, ultimately aims to destroy the energy basis of the bourgeois capitalist model.

Regarding this action at the Faculty of Psychology – anti-Zionism. Zionism is a nationalist political movement. That is the problem. Communism is one of the globalist currents and is intrinsically internationalist, the Nation is to be destroyed and, therefore, the Zionist State of Israel is a problem (Jewish anti-nationalism).

All these instruments contribute to the destruction of the pillars that support the edifice of Western civilization, and the goal is to destroy them so that the way is paved for the end of the market economy. This makes it easier to pave the way for communist totalitarianism, which uses new instruments other than the orthodox or original class struggle – proletariat versus bosses.

The Nation is the “nemesis” of the globalists, and cultural Marxism is the new communism today, being one of the globalist movements we have at the moment, in addition to the liberal globalism led by the USA.

In short, this is useful idiocy, it is simply a copy of the inorganic social movements that arise in American universities and are then imported to Portugal, with the sole aim of destroying the foundations of Western civilization and diluting the Nations from within.

column3:
Western media instructed not to talk about victims of attack near Moscow, Russia says

The Russian Foreign Ministry has condemned what it said was an attempt by the West to cover up its role and demonize the Russian government following the tragedy at the concert hall.

Western media outlets have been instructed to keep quiet about the number of victims of the terrorist attack at Crocus City Hall, the Russian Foreign Ministry said on Monday (8).

"Particularly cynical are the attempts by the West to distract the international community from the real organizers and beneficiaries by categorically instructing them not to cover the true scale of the tragedy in the media: not to mention the number of victims of the terrorist attack, the number of dead children, or to show the reaction of ordinary citizens to what happened," the ministry said on its Telegram channel.

The foreign ministry explained this by a desire not to show sympathy and humanism towards the Russians.

The ministry added that immediately after the attack, Western media and authorities organised a PR campaign to deny the involvement of Ukrainian security services.

The media were instructed to spread the story that Daesh (a terrorist organisation banned in Russia and several other countries) was involved in organising the attack; they were instructed to deny the Islamists’ links to Kiev and Western secret services, as well as to discredit the results of the investigation and promote the theory that “Russian secret services were involved”.

On 22 March, several armed men stormed the Crocus City Hall concert hall and started shooting at people. The terrorists also set fire to the venue. The attack left 144 people dead, according to the latest figures from the Ministry of Emergency Situations.

The four main suspects in the case – all citizens of Tajikistan – tried to flee the scene by car, but were detained near the Russian border and charged with terrorism.

Russian authorities believe the suspects planned to flee to Ukraine, where the attack's organizers had a safe haven for them. An investigation into the case is ongoing.

column3:
Sending NATO troops to Ukraine is a "warning of an apocalypse", says Slovak Prime Minister

The Prime Minister of Slovakia, Robert Fico, said this Saturday (2) that the sending of military personnel from the European Union (EU) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) to Ukraine could precipitate a global apocalypse.

In a video posted on social media, he highlighted Ukraine's inability to resolve the conflict, despite the substantial financial and military aid provided by the West.

He stressed that, although the military presence of the EU and NATO could potentially change the dynamics of the conflict, it could also trigger catastrophic consequences. "The West sees that, despite significant financial and military aid, Ukraine is incapable of resolving this armed conflict".

"The situation could change with the arrival of EU and NATO military personnel to Ukraine, but then there would be nothing left but to wait for the arrival of the global apocalypse", said the Slovak Prime Minister.

Fico stressed the pressing need for modern air defence systems for Ukraine, but warned that the West cannot provide these systems without a commitment to maintain and operate them. He also argued that sending Western troops would only exacerbate the conflict rather than resolve it. Russia has been continuing its special military operation in Ukraine since February 2022. Russian President Vladimir Putin has justified the action as a measure to protect the population against “genocide” by the Kiev regime and to contain NATO’s eastward advance. Moscow has repeatedly warned against Western arms supplies to Kiev, saying that foreign convoys carrying weapons would be legitimate targets for its forces once they crossed the border. In addition, Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov accused the United States and NATO of already being directly involved in the conflict in Ukraine, not only through the supply of weapons, but also through the training of personnel in several European countries.

column3:
Russia held secret meetings with the US about the war in Ukraine

Sergei Lavrov confirmed “never-disclosed contacts” with Americans. They did not produce the desired result.

Russia held secret meetings with the US to try to end the war in Ukraine.

Sergei Lavrov, Russia’s Foreign Minister, confirmed that a group of Russian political scientists and experts met with American experts.

“We had never-disclosed contacts with Americans, through political scientists who knew and understood the governments’ policies,” Lavrov announced on the sidelines of the United Nations Security Council.

The statement was quoted this Thursday by Folha de S. Paulo, the newspaper that reported on these attempts at a peace agreement in March.

The meetings served as a sort of screening of what was acceptable to both countries – but Ukraine never had representatives at these meetings.

The governments of Russia and the US authorized these meetings, even though they were not official.

The negotiations lasted just over a year, but according to the Russian minister, they did not produce the desired result. In practice, they were of no use.

Sergei Lavrov only shared one more topic addressed in these meetings: the status of ethnic Russians within Ukraine.

It should be remembered that Russian President Vladimir Putin had said before the war that Russian culture was being pushed aside in Ukraine, for example with the law limiting the use of the Russian language in the Ukrainian education system.

Until now, there have only been official meetings between Russians and Ukrainians at the very beginning of the war.

But, like these, these negotiations, first in Belarus and then in Turkey, did not end with a peace agreement – ​​and they have never been held again.

column3:
Russia denies openness to negotiating Kiev's accession to NATO in exchange for territories

Citing sources close to the Kremlin, the Bloomberg news agency had reported that Russian President Vladimir Putin was trying to understand whether Washington was in favour of starting talks on ending the war in Ukraine.

Russia denied this Friday that President Vladimir Putin had expressed any willingness to the United States to negotiate Ukraine's entry into NATO in exchange for Russian control over the territories annexed in the neighbouring country.

"This information is wrong and does not coincide at all with reality", said the spokesman for the Russian Presidency (Kremlin), Dmitri Peskov, at the usual daily press conference.

Previously, and citing sources close to the Kremlin, the Bloomberg news agency had reported that Russian President Vladimir Putin was trying to understand whether Washington was in favour of starting talks on ending the war in Ukraine.

According to two sources cited by Bloomberg, the Russian leader had sent signals to the United States of America (USA) about a possible willingness by Moscow to engage in dialogue.

According to the news agency, the Kremlin leader may be willing to consider Ukraine's eventual accession to the Atlantic Alliance, provided that Kiev accepts the new "territorial realities", referring to the Ukrainian regions annexed by Moscow. 

Until now, Ukraine has always opposed making territorial concessions to Moscow or freezing the conflict because, according to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, this would only benefit Moscow. 

Russia wants international assessment of military plane downing 

The Kremlin also criticized Western countries for not condemning the downing of the Russian Il-76 military transport plane, which was carrying Ukrainian prisoners and which Moscow said was Ukraine's responsibility, during Thursday's meeting of the United Nations Security Council. 

"So far, there has been no categorical condemnation from Western countries of this horrific terrorist attack. We have not heard a single word of condemnation," Peskov said. 

According to the Kremlin spokesman, "this event requires a proper assessment by the international community", since, he claimed, "this is not the first time that Kiev has killed its own people".

Asked about the Russian presidency's willingness to present evidence to the UN or other international organisations that Ukraine was involved in the downing of the plane or that the Ukrainian authorities knew who was travelling on board the aircraft, Peskov replied only that, at this time, he had "nothing to add".

"Investigators are working and decisions will be made as they obtain all the necessary information", he added.

According to the Russian version, the Il-76 military transport plane was shot down on Wednesday by Ukraine with 65 Ukrainian prisoners of war on board, as well as six crew members and three Russian guards, which was allegedly travelling to Ukraine for a prisoner exchange.

For its part, Ukraine, which confirmed that an exchange was being prepared, claims that the plane was carrying weapons and not prisoners of war.

The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

column3:
Former Russian president says Ukraine joining NATO would mean ‘war’

Former Russian President Dmitry Medvedev said Ukraine joining NATO would be a declaration of war against Moscow and that only “prudence” on behalf of the alliance could prevent the planet from being torn apart.

North Atlantic Treaty Organization leaders pledged at their summit last week to support Ukraine on an “irreversible path to full Euro-Atlantic integration, including NATO membership,” but left open the question of when that membership might happen.

Medvedev, deputy chairman of Russia’s Security Council and a leading voice among Kremlin hawks, told the Argumenty I Fakty media outlet that Ukraine’s accession would go beyond a direct threat to Moscow’s security.

“This would essentially be a declaration of war – albeit a belated one,” he said in comments published on Wednesday.

“The actions that Russia’s opponents have been taking against us for years, expanding the alliance, are bringing NATO to a point of no return.”

In a standard Kremlin line since Moscow’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Medvedev said Russia was not threatening NATO but would respond to the alliance’s attempts to advance its interests.

“The more such attempts there are, the harsher our responses will become,” Medvedev said. “Whether this will tear the entire planet apart depends solely on the prudence of the (NATO) side.”

column3:
G20 Summit. The challenges facing world leaders in managing peace, debt and climate

G20 world leaders will meet for a two-day summit on 9 and 10 September, hosted by the Indian G20 Presidency in New Delhi. Under the slogan "One Earth - One Family - One Future", they will debate, in a tense atmosphere, the deep differences over Russia's war in Ukraine, debt restructuring and the phasing out of fossil fuels, which will make it difficult to reach a joint declaration on Sunday.

Joe Biden, Rishi Sunak, Emmanuel Macron and other G20 leaders will be in New Delhi for the 18th Group of 20 Summit.

Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin will not be present, leaving national representation to Li Qiang, the Chinese prime minister, who will lead the Chinese delegation, and Sergei Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, who will lead the Russian delegation.

Narendra Modi, the prime minister of India, the host country for the annual summit, hopes to assert his country’s growing diplomatic clout and facilitate dialogue on the issues that divide the G20: Russia’s war in Ukraine and climate change.

The lack of consensus on the war in Ukraine threatens to derail the summit, undermining progress on issues such as food security, debt restructuring and cooperation on climate change.

“The cost of inaction will be catastrophic”

The G20 Summit is taking place as “the world is on a knife-edge. The climate crisis is inflicting immense harm on people, and the human rights of billions of people are under threat,” said Agnès Callamard, Amnesty International’s secretary general, in a statement this week.

According to Amnesty International, “it is vital that the G20 recognises the magnitude and urgency of these crises and acts quickly to prevent the escalation of climate disasters and debt”, otherwise “the cost of inaction will be catastrophic”, she added.

At the previous G20 summit in November 2022, hosted by the Indonesian G20 presidency in Bali, leaders discussed the impact of Russia’s war on Ukraine on the global economy, and in particular food and energy security.

Despite issuing a joint declaration, Amnesty International believes that it has not been honoured so far and calls for its implementation and the adoption of new commitments.

This G20 summit comes ahead of other key occasions when countries will be meeting again, such as the UN General Assembly’s High-Level Week and the UN Secretary-General’s Climate Ambition Summit later this month, both in New York, as well as the COP28 climate meeting in Dubai, which starts on 30 November.

column3:
Humanity faces a “triple extinction” that will wipe out all life on Earth. But not for another 250 million years

For years, experts have been warning humanity about the impact of global warming: as temperatures rise, there is concern about the world’s food supply, rising sea levels and the fact that parts of the Earth will become too hot to live in.

Now, in a study published in the journal ‘Nature Geoscience’, scientists have predicted when humanity will witness the “triple extinction” that will wipe out human beings and what will cause it.

The study, led by the University of Bristol (UK), suggests that the Earth could become a hot, dry and largely uninhabitable supercontinent, with the entire land mass merging into one giant landmass – using the first supercomputer climate models of the distant future, it showed that the world will experience more volcanic eruptions that will emit huge plumes of carbon dioxide, further increasing temperatures.

The Sun could become hotter and brighter in the sky, warming the Earth more than ever before and causing average temperatures to reach between 40 and 50 degrees Celsius.

According to Alexandre Farnsworth, lead author of the study and senior research associate at the University of Bristol, “the newly emerged supercontinent would effectively create a triple whammy, comprising the effect of continentality, a hotter Sun and more CO2 in the atmosphere, increasing heat across much of the planet”.

The result is a hostile environment, with no food or water sources for mammals. Widespread temperatures of 40 to 50 degrees Celsius and even greater daily extremes, compounded by high humidity, would ultimately seal our fate. Humans — along with many other species — would die out due to their inability to release this heat through sweat, thereby cooling their bodies. According to the study, even if humanity were to stop using fossil fuels, it would not prevent extinction. Even if humanity survives until the event, there will be a total extinction. The only advantage is that the event is 250 million years away. Eunice Lo, a co-author of the study and a researcher in Climate Change and Health at the University of Bristol, said: “It is vitally important not to lose sight of our current climate crisis, which is a result of human emissions of greenhouse gases. Although we are predicting an uninhabitable planet within 250 million years, we are already experiencing extreme heat that is damaging to human health. This is why it is crucial to achieve net zero emissions as soon as possible,” he concluded.

column3:
Lula makes federal government available to help cities in Rio Grande do Sul affected by flooding

President Lula spoke about the flooding that hit several regions of Rio Grande do Sul between Monday and Tuesday. On the program "Conversa com o Presidente", he spoke about the situation in the municipalities of Serra and the North of the state and guaranteed federal aid.

"Now, we have excessive rain. It rained a lot in several regions, there are floods and from what I saw, there are deaths. I want to make a statement to the people of Rio Grande do Sul saying that the head of Civil Defense is going to Rio Grande do Sul. I would like to tell the people of Rio Grande do Sul that we are ready to help in whatever way is necessary. Wherever there is a problem, the federal government will be ready to help people", he assured.

Lula recalled that, in the first half of the year, a delegation of ministers visited the state to assess the losses caused by the drought that affected 400 municipalities and impacted agricultural production. In February, the federal government released 392.8 million euros for mitigation actions. In March, 12 cities in Rio Grande do Sul affected by drought received aid of over 360 million euros.

For the president, these extreme events are a warning that the climate issue is not a minor issue. “It is not a question of university professors, it is not a question of environmentalists, it is a question of humanity, of the planet suffering the consequences of human irresponsibility,” he said, reaffirming that he has a plan to include the topic of climate change in the school curriculum.

Earlier on Tuesday, Lula used Twitter to express his solidarity with the families who lost people in the floods in RS.

column3:
Fungi are more resistant to body heat, researchers say; find out what the risks are

There are millions of fungi in the world. Although 150,000 have been catalogued, scientists believe that the real number may vary between 1 and 5 million different species. However, a minority of them present a risk of infection.

The group of researchers investigated 98 infections caused by fungi between 2009 and 2019, registered in Chinese hospitals. They claim to have discovered a new species causing infections. “We identified two independent cases of human infection by a previously undescribed invasive fungal pathogen,” the study reads. Rhodosporidiobolus fluvialis was the species identified.

In general, high body temperature prevents fungi from surviving. The researchers then carried out laboratory tests on mice that were induced to a body temperature of 37ºC and discovered that this species of fungus not only remained alive, but also registered an increase in mutation rates, compared to milder temperatures.

As a result of the accelerated mutation, the fungi can become even more resistant to drugs, which would make it more difficult to treat any potential disease. “Temperature-induced mutagenesis can also trigger the development of pan-resistance to three of the most widely used antifungals (fluconazole, caspofungin and amphotericin B),” the researchers say.

The group also presented the theory that the increase in global temperature, as a consequence of the climate crisis, could favour the proliferation of infectious diseases. “Global warming can promote the evolution of new fungal pathogens,” the article states.

On the other hand, Toni Gabaldón, a biologist at the Institute for Biomedical Research in Barcelona, ​​says that caution is needed. “Direct evidence that these two observations are related is lacking and further research is needed,” he told German broadcaster Deutsche Welle.

column3:
Southern Region has 7 out of 10 cyclone alerts in Brazil in the last ten years

Submerged houses in Lajeado (RS) this Wednesday (6) after a cyclone passed through.

Recently affected by the formation of an extratropical cyclone in Rio Grande do Sul that killed more than 40 people, the southern region of the country registered 71 of the 92 alerts issued to the federal government in the last ten years due to this natural phenomenon.

G1 analyzed data from the Integrated Disaster Information System, which receives daily alerts from Brazilian municipalities about the effects of natural phenomena. The system is linked to the Ministry of Integration and Regional Development.

The South represents 77% of the alerts, due to the state of Santa Catarina, which registered 64 occurrences between January 2013 and August 2023. In the same period, five occurrences were registered in Rio Grande do Sul and two in Paraná.

The city with the most cyclones was Balneário Barra do Sul (SC), with 13 episodes. See below a map with all the municipalities that issued a cyclone alert to the federal government in the last decade.

Why in the South?

Climatempo meteorologist Fábio Luengo explains that the southern states are historically more affected by extratropical cyclones due to their location in an area where air masses meet.

"It is a region that has a greater thermal contrast between the hot and humid air (coming from the North) and the cold air that comes from the South [of the planet]", he explains.

What is not common, says Luengo, is the intensity and frequency that these natural phenomena have gained. This week's extratropical cyclone, for example, marked the greatest natural tragedy in the history of Rio Grande do Sul.

He mentions three factors that explain this increase in extreme weather events.

- Climate change, caused by human action on the planet, which increases the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events;

- Warming of the Atlantic Ocean, a process that is also more intense and frequent due to climate change;

- The action of the climatic phenomenon known as "El Niño", which, among other effects, causes excessive rainfall in the south of the country and in the southeast of the country.
column4: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears']
column5: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Other']

column3:
Tragedy in RS highlights the urgency of mitigating climate change

A new storm is hitting Rio Grande do Sul, with unprecedented amounts of precipitation. In two days, it rained more than three times the average for the month of May. The frequency of meteorological disasters requires authorities to change the way they deal with them.

This is the fifth climate disaster to hit the people of Rio Grande do Sul in less than a year. In June 2023, a cyclone swept through the state; from July to December, storms affected the lives of millions of people.

The state government has now once again declared a state of public calamity. As of Friday morning (3), 351,600 people and 235 municipalities had been affected. By the end of the afternoon, there were 39 deaths.

The support of the federal government is essential, as it has already announced the deployment of one hundred agents from the National Force and 31 transport vehicles.

However, given the scale of the tragedy, which has left thousands homeless and without a livelihood, in addition to the loss of loved ones, all the action seems insufficient to alleviate such suffering.

It seems clear that something abnormal is happening and that global warming is at its root. Although extreme events may result from natural climate variation, this seems increasingly unlikely.

The government therefore needs to prepare for the worst-case scenarios. Nothing that is happening now has been predicted by science.

It remains urgent to mitigate global warming by cutting greenhouse gas emissions more drastically and decisively than has been done to date — but in reality, they continue to rise worldwide.

In the short and medium term, adapting to climate change should already be a priority for managers.

The federal government, states and municipalities need to create integrated action plans to mitigate the effects of global warming and the fatalities caused by the events, in areas such as forestry legislation, since green areas are essential to contain floods, and basic sanitation, which is shameful in Brazil.

If there are obstacles to reducing and cutting carbon emissions on a global scale, local authorities must take precautions to ensure that extreme events do not become, at the very least, catastrophic events.

column3:
Activists who blocked the Segunda Circular and were arrested have been released. They will go to court tomorrow

The 11 climate activists from the Climáximo movement, who this Tuesday morning began a blockade of the Segunda Circular in Lisbon, from 9 am, in the middle of rush hour, on three of the four lanes in the direction of Benfica-Airport, have already been released by the authorities, after having been arrested during the protest.

The young people were released at 5 pm from the PSP police station in Benfica, where they were being held. As they left, there were some family members and colleagues from the movement, who clapped their hands and shouted new slogans, calling for government action to stop climate change. A poster was displayed that read “They are destroying everything you love”.

“Fires, floods, droughts, heat waves that kill thousands of people. They know this and continue to increase emissions. We need peace and a disarmament of the weapons that are pointed at all of us”, said Noah Zino, one of the activists.

The activists will appear before a judge tomorrow, at 10:00 am, at the Campus de Justiça, in Lisbon. Saying that they did not yet know the crimes they were accused of, they admit that they will most likely be charged with disobedience and disturbing public order.

“We have stopped accepting a normality that kills more people every two days than those who died in Pedrogão Grande, in the fires. We will support whoever wants to stop this genocide”, continued the activist, assuring that actions of this kind will continue to happen.

Nine of the arrested activists, who had been cutting off the Segunda Circular, were taken away by a vehicle from the special police unit, and the two hanging from the viaduct were eventually removed by the authorities, in particular the Lisbon Firefighters, and arrested.

Several ambulances from INEM, two firefighters from Lisbon with more than 10 officers, four special police unit vehicles and five officers from the Prevention and Immediate Reaction Team (EPRI) of the Lisbon Metropolitan Police Command were mobilized to the scene.

Watch the videos of the protest and chaos this morning in Lisbon here:

On social media, the group published several videos of the moment, including when the police were forced to intervene to remove two protesters hanging from a rope on the 2ª Circular viaduct, who were holding a banner that read “governments and companies have declared war on society and the planet”.

column3:
Is your favourite destination at risk of disappearing? Here’s what could happen if sea levels continue to rise

According to the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, climate change will lead to an average global sea level rise of between 32 and 84 centimetres by 2100.

Researchers at financial comparison service Money.co.uk have produced travel posters that imagine the impact of dramatic sea level rise on famous destinations.

Although exaggerated, the artworks are a way of drawing attention to the plight of many coastal areas due to rising sea levels.

However, there are a number of destinations that are likely to be affected by rising sea levels in the next hundred years. The team has created a map of tourist destinations around the world that are at risk of flooding and even disappearing altogether.

Fiji, a country whose economy is largely dependent on tourism, has already begun to see the effects of rising sea levels, with research showing that sea levels will continue to rise by 1-2 metres by 2100, putting the island at risk of being completely submerged. The Seychelles, Solomon Islands and Palau are also at risk of disappearing by 2100, which would be a devastating loss for the planet. 

Some of the world’s most popular tourist destinations, including London, Dubai, Tokyo and Rio de Janeiro, are vulnerable to extreme flooding by 2100. In Dubai, a three-metre rise would see the city lose much of its infrastructure. If sea levels rise by nine metres, Dubai could be completely submerged, making it the shortest-lived urban infrastructure in human history. The Maldives – famous for its iconic overwater villas – could lose up to 77% of its land area to the sea by 2100, according to some experts.
column4: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears']
column5: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Amplifying existing fears of global warming']

column3:
Russia restricts civilian access to villages in Ukraine-bombed border region

Access to 14 villages in the southern Russian Belgorod region bordering Ukraine will be closed to most civilians, Governor Vyacheslav Gladkov said Tuesday, citing the “extremely difficult” situation due to Ukrainian shelling.

Announcing the new restrictions in a video posted on his Telegram channel, Gladkov said that starting next week, only adult men accompanying military or government officials will be allowed to enter the settlements. Men must travel in armored vehicles and wear bulletproof vests and helmets, he added.

“I hope you will agree that it is unacceptable to allow women and children to enter the settlements that are shelled every day,” Gladkov said.

“We have already lost too many civilians, we have too many wounded. And of course, our task is to maximize security measures.”

The Belgorod region has come under frequent fire from Ukrainian bombers and drones. Air raid sirens sound almost daily in the regional capital of the same name, just 40 km (25 miles) north of the border. Ukraine says Russian shelling of Ukrainian cities has been devastating, and after nearly two and a half years of war, Russian forces now control about a fifth of Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin said in May that Russian forces were working to create a buffer zone in northeastern Ukraine to protect Russia from attacks launched by Kiev’s forces across the border. Gladkov’s announcement is a sign that the security situation in the region may have become more dire, prompting authorities to do more to protect civilians. More than 200 civilians have been killed in the Belgorod region since the start of what Moscow calls its “special military operation” in Ukraine in February 2022, Gladkov told the state-run Tass news agency on Tuesday. More than 1,100 were injured.
column4: ['URW: Blaming the war on others rather than the invader', 'URW: Russia is the Victim', 'URW: Russia is the Victim']

column3:
"Short-sighted policy" of the West helped Russia to get closer to the "global south"

"The plans of the Western minority to isolate Russia and create a kind of cordon sanitaire around us have failed. The promoters of these initiatives themselves are forced to admit this," said Sergei Lavrov, during a speech in the Russian State Duma (lower house of parliament), quoted by the official news agency TASS.

In his speech, Lavrov considered that the West, led by the United States, used the "Kiev regime" to achieve these objectives, in addition to having made available "a wide arsenal of hybrid warfare tools", including economic and diplomatic sanctions, which also covered the sectors of information, culture and sports.

However, he stressed that the "collective hostility" of the West also allowed the emergence of "new opportunities" to direct Russia's relations in "various geographical directions", giving as examples China and Africa, which has become "one of the poles of the emerging multipolar".

Lavrov, who will visit Cuba, Venezuela and Brazil next week, noted that during his visit to Rio de Janeiro on Wednesday and Thursday – where he will participate in the summit of G20 foreign ministers (the 20 largest economies in the world) – Russia will continue to oppose the “selfish objectives” that have emerged within the group, including “the ‘Ukrainianisation’ of the agenda”.

Also regarding Ukraine, Lavrov once again noted that Russia is willing to start negotiations, as long as its “legitimate interests” are respected, which are completely contradictory to Ukrainian demands, which are committed to recovering the entire territory.

These words from the Russian Foreign Minister follow statements from other Russian sources who, on Tuesday, assured that Russian President Vladimir Putin’s suggestion of a ceasefire in Ukraine and negotiations, following contacts between intermediaries last December, was rejected by the United States of America (USA).

An anonymous US official denied that there had been any formal contact and said that Washington would not engage in negotiations that excluded Ukraine.

The Russian military offensive on Ukrainian territory, launched on February 24, 2022, has plunged Europe into what is considered the most serious security crisis since the Second World War (1939-1945).

Ukraine's Western allies have supplied arms to Kiev and approved successive packages of sanctions against Russian interests in an attempt to reduce Moscow's ability to finance the war effort.

column3:
Ukraine has already received Western F-16s, but Zelensky says they are insufficient

Ukraine has received its first Western F-16 fighter jets, which have been expected for more than two years, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced today, showing them to journalists and stressing that their number is “insufficient”.

“We have held hundreds of meetings and negotiations” with allies to obtain these planes and strengthen the country’s air defense and “we often hear the words ‘it is impossible’ in response,” Volodymyr Zelensky said during a ceremony at a secret location in Ukraine, according to AFP.

“Now it is reality, reality in our skies. The F-16s are in Ukraine,” he said.

Since the beginning of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Kiev has been begging for the delivery of F-16s in the hope of ending Russian dominance in the air and better protecting its cities and military against incessant bombing by Moscow’s forces.

Made in the United States, the planes are considered the crown jewel in the extensive list of military equipment that Ukraine has requested from its allies in an attempt to repel the advance of Russian forces on its soil.

The Ukrainian president did not reveal the number of aircraft received by Kiev, saying only that it was “insufficient”, nor the number of Ukrainian pilots trained in the West to fly these aircraft.

The delivery date and the country that supplied this first batch were also not revealed.

“What is positive is that we expect more F-16s” and that “many of our men are being trained”, Zelensky assured.

AFP journalists saw at least two F-16s flying over the site during the ceremony.

Behind Volodymyr Zelensky, two other grey aircraft similar to F-16s were placed on the ground, partially covered by camouflage nets and with their tails emblazoned with the national coat of arms, the trident.

In mid-May, President Zelensky declared in an interview with AFP that he needed 120 to 130 of these aircraft to reach parity with Russian aviation.

column3:
Hungarian party wants to annex Ukrainian region if Ukraine loses the war

The leader of the Hungarian far-right party 'Our Homeland Movement', Laszlo Toroczkai, said on Saturday that he would claim the Ukrainian region of Transcarpathia, which borders Hungary in western Ukraine and is home to around 150,000 Hungarians, if the country invaded by Russia loses the war.

According to the Reuters news agency, Toroczkai's words were spoken at a party press conference, which was also attended by leaders of the far-right parties Alternative for Germany (AfD) and the Forum for Democracy, from the Netherlands, among others.

"Regarding the war, our message is very simple: an immediate ceasefire, peace and a resolution through talks," the politician said.

"If this war ends with Ukraine losing its statehood, because that is also happening, then, as the only Hungarian party to take this position, let me signal that we will reclaim Transcarpathia," he stressed. 

It should be noted that Russia invaded Ukraine on February 24, 2022, with the argument of protecting the pro-Russian separatist minorities in the east and "denazifying" the neighboring country, independent since 1991, after the disintegration of the former Soviet Union, and which has been moving away from Moscow's sphere of influence and closer to Europe and the West. 

The war in Ukraine has already caused tens of thousands of deaths on both sides, but has not seen significant progress in the theater of operations in recent months, with the two belligerents remaining inflexible in their territorial positions and not open to concessions in negotiations. 

Recent weeks have seen large-scale Russian airstrikes targeting Ukrainian cities and infrastructure, while Kyiv's forces have targeted targets on Russian territory near the border and on the Crimean peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014.

column3:
Russia threatens to shoot down F-16s promised to Kiev

Russia threatened on Thursday that the F-16 fighter jets promised to Ukraine by the West will be shot down, arguing that these aircraft will have little effect on the battlefield.

"There is no magic pill or panacea, and the Kiev regime's air force will not have such a panacea," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, adding that "these planes (...) will be shot down."

"But it is clear that these deliveries cannot have a significant impact on the course of events on the front line," he added.

For almost two years, Ukraine has been asking its Western allies for the supply of F-16s, considered the 'crown jewel' of the extensive list of military equipment that Kiev has requested from its supporters.

According to some media, the American-made fighter jets have already been delivered. Several NATO countries have pledged to supply varying numbers of fighters and have been training Ukrainian pilots and crews for months. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has made improving air defences a priority in meetings with allies, following Russia’s heavy air campaign in recent months. In an interview with Agence France Presse in May, Zelensky outlined the need for around 130 F-16s to ensure parity with the Russian air force. However, Ukraine’s partners have pledged to send fewer than 100 F-16s so far, with most of the aircraft likely to arrive over several years, after pilot training.

column3:
Beware of El Niño and ocean anomalies. It came late but summer is here: August is going to be hot

August is starting to get closer but summer still seems far away. Pedro Sousa, a meteorologist at the Portuguese Institute of the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA), confirms that this week, “we are witnessing an episode of hot weather” and, last week, “there were also some”. The heat that is being felt at the end of July is “relatively normal” and the meteorologist classifies these periods as typical “summer heat”.

“With no records and no very prolonged episodes of heat, it has been a calm summer”, admits the meteorologist. And that is indeed the case, especially since there have been many complaints that the heat arrived late.

August is expected to have above-average temperatures in the interior and below-average on the coast, says Pedro Sousa. The weeks are therefore expected to be dry and hot, with cooler temperatures on the coast.

“August is very likely to be hot,” he explains, due to the trend of global warming over the years and also the El Niño phenomenon, which “whenever it happens, the planet experiences high temperatures.” In addition, there are above-normal ocean anomalies that make the sea warmer, which also reduces the influence of the sea breeze on the temperature.

Despite this, the IPMA meteorologist warns that this is not an absolute certainty, since “forecasts are becoming less reliable” and a “forecast for three weeks from now can always change.” “Forecasts change quickly,” he concludes.

Comparing the temperature of August 2024 with the last three decades, he stresses that the weather forecast for next month should be higher, but “nothing guarantees that it will be hotter than last year or 2018,” which were marked by temperature phenomena.

“The predicted and observed temperatures are higher than in the last thirty years, which does not mean that they are very high,” he explains.

The end of July and the first week of August are expected to be hot and dry, with above-average temperatures inland and negative anomalies on the coast. “This is normal for summer,” says the expert.

As for this week, everything indicates that it will be “quite hot.” ​​Next week, however, temperatures should continue to be above average.

column3:
Extreme heat, fires and rain that never falls: Water-stressed Greek islands are banning swimming pools and resorting to desalination

Water shortages have led some Greek islands to ban swimming pools and resort to desalination. Just weeks after Greece experienced its earliest heatwave ever in June, parts of the country are now dealing with a new crisis: severe water shortages.

A state of emergency has been declared in Sifnos, the Cyclades, Leros, the Dodecanese islands, Sami, Kefalonia and parts of Crete.

Inhabitants in these regions are demanding urgent action as water supplies run low. Water levels are also low on the Attica peninsula, which includes Athens.

On the southern Aegean island of Naxos, the largest reservoir has dried up due to low rainfall and hot weather, according to Reuters news agency.

The lack of rain in recent months, combined with scorching temperatures of up to 40°C (104°F), has caused this situation. Inadequate infrastructure and lack of maintenance of desalination plants on the islands have further exacerbated the problem. 

Wildfires have also contributed to the crisis. In June, a fire on Serifos destroyed part of the island’s water supply network, which is now facing its lowest water reserves in 20 years. 

With the greatest need for water for water supply and irrigation, farmers are the worst affected. Many are being forced to rely on wells contaminated by seawater due to low water levels, Reuters reports. 

With the tourist season in full swing, visitor infrastructure is putting further pressure on water resources. Increased construction and the uncontrolled use of swimming pools have contributed to the water shortages on the islands, Elissavet Feloni, a hydrologist and professor at the University of West Attica, told Greek broadcaster Naftemporiki. 

Last month was the hottest June on record globally and the 13th consecutive month of record temperatures, according to Europe’s Copernicus climate service. It was also the 12th month in a row that the world has been 1.5C warmer than in pre-industrial times, extremes blamed on man-made emissions. With dry conditions expected to persist in the coming months, Feloni called for controls on water consumption and tighter government monitoring. Some islands have already taken action of their own. Karpathos and Serifos have imposed restrictions on the refilling of swimming pools. Viannos on Crete has imposed strict limits on the use of water for irrigation. The small Dodecanese island of Lipsi has stepped in early and banned the construction of swimming pools for the hot summer of 2023 to encourage a more sustainable approach to tourism. The northern island of Thassos is investing in a desalination plant to make seawater safe for drinking, according to Reuters. In places where a state of emergency has been declared, processes for transferring water, improving supplies and accessing government funds have been accelerated.

Three new wells are planned for Crete, while the navy has transported water to Leros, according to local media reports.

The water crisis on the Greek islands highlights the urgent need to adapt to climate change and manage natural resources more sustainably.

column3:
Green paint in the eyes, or the courage to tell the truth

In recent years, with the recognition of climate change as a global phenomenon, a form of protest has become widespread among young ‘climate activists’. Integrated into the anti-establishment vanguard parties, they believe that they are saving the world from the apocalypse and consider themselves above the law.

The protests of these activists or radicals take many forms.

All over the world, they stick themselves to works of art to draw attention to their causes, usually forgetting that these works of art represent the best that the human spirit has produced over thousands of years of existence.

Another form of protest they find is sticking themselves to the ground in the most diverse places, occupying a space that is not theirs, believing that they can freely impose themselves on others.

We have already had some episodes like these here, some of them involving the pretense of believing that they are the only ones who care about the future of the planet and of Humanity, claiming to represent the vanguard of contemporary society.

They interrupted a private event where the Minister of Economy was present.

They invaded and stuck themselves to the floor of the Ministry of Economy.

They blocked access to the building where the Council of Ministers was to meet.

In another case, the leader of the JS of Oeiras, after insulting the Municipal Executive at a session of the Municipal Assembly of Oeiras, went to the Executive bench and threw a 10 euro note, in order to increase the municipal budget for the fight against climate change.

This week, those who hold the truth and are above good and evil invaded a CNN conference where the Minister of Environment was present, attacking the minister with bags filled with green paint, protesting against the minister's presence at an event supported by companies in the energy sector.

All of this is possible and all of this is tolerated because the poor 'young free radicals' are drawing attention to a greater cause, and because they want to save Humanity from itself.

In reality, all this is tolerated because the vast majority of the political class, as well as other institutions, live in a state of cowardly surrender to political correctness. Politicians are insulted or subjected to insinuations and are afraid to react. Fear is the worst advisor to decision-makers.

Governments, and the President of the Republic, have been particularly responsible for the establishment of this state of affairs. Portugal is a country completely conditioned by these groups, and by the hand that rocks their cradle.

A substantial part of the blockage of national decisions is due to the imposed public conditioning (with strong support from editorial offices), and this conditioning afflicts our society with fear. Yesterday it was made public that 40% of judges admit to being conditioned by the media. How many of the remaining 60% are still not telling the truth?

By reacting softly to these arrogant protests, we are tolerating the intolerable and recognizing legitimacy where it does not exist. In a free society there are no vanguards, nor does any group have moral superiority over others. It is unfortunate that today, saying so is an act of courage.

column3:
Climate activists dye Venice canal green in protest against COP28

Italian environmentalists used dye to dye Venice's Grand Canal green on Saturday (9) in protest against what they considered a lack of progress at COP28, the UN Climate Change Conference taking place in Dubai until next Tuesday (12).

Hanging from the Rialto Bridge over the canal, with the help of climbing ropes, activists from the group Extinction Rebellion also displayed a banner that read: "COP28: While the government talks, we are hanging by a thread".

Short stretches of rivers and canals in other Italian cities have also been dyed green in similar protests. "In a few hours, these waters will be back to what they were before," the group said in a statement. "In the meantime, we count the damage and victims of the constant floods and fires."

According to the protesters, the visual effect was created by a dye used by companies to track items in the water. Boat traffic was halted during the protest, and the canal water and columns had to be checked for safety reasons, according to Venice Mayor Luigi Brugnaro. The politician criticized the activists' actions, calling them "eco-vandals," and called on Italian authorities to punish them. "Venice is a fragile city that must be loved and respected! Enough is enough," he said. Brugnaro borrowed the nickname given to the protesters from figures such as Italy's current culture minister, Gennaro Sangiuliano. The minister has been waging a crusade against environmental protests targeting monuments and works of art — acts that have become more common in recent years. In April, the government of Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni announced a bill that would impose stricter fines, between 10,000 and 60,000 euros, for those who destroy, tarnish or disfigure, in whole or in part, cultural and landscape assets. The measures were added to sanctions already included in the penal code for this type of crime, which currently amount to five years in prison and a fine of 15,000 euros. "Those who damage our artistic heritage cannot and should not get away with it," the far-right politician said on social media at the time.

column3:
Young people take centre stage in environmental discussions

Three out of four young people aged 16 to 25 consider the “climate future frightening” and fear that world leaders will not be able to implement effective measures. This is according to the survey Young People’s Voices on Climate Anxiety, Government Betrayal and Moral Injury: A Global Phenomenon, which interviewed 10,000 people from countries such as the USA, India, France, Nigeria and Brazil in September. The survey also showed that 45% of these young people feel distressed, overwhelmed, anxious and guilty about the environment.

These figures explain and reflect the leading role that young people are demanding – albeit by force – in decisions to combat the climate crisis. “Our leaders are not our leaders. This is what a leader should look like”, said Greta Thunberg, pointing to the thousands of young people listening to her in Glasgow.

In Glasgow, young people from all over the world called for greater participation and representation in the negotiations. A declaration signed by 40,000 of them was delivered to the COP presidency and other leaders. “The actions and scrutiny of young people are essential to keeping the 1.5 degrees Celsius target alive and creating a zero-emissions future,” said Alok Sharma, president of the Conference. 

The Brazilian delegation included around 80 young people, the largest youth representation to date. And the only Brazilian to participate in the COP-26 opening ceremony was Txai Suruí, a 24-year-old indigenous woman. She shared the stage with António Guterres, UN Secretary-General, and Boris Johnson, British Prime Minister, and addressed diplomats from more than 190 countries. 

In her speech, Txai mentioned the murder of Ari Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau, her friend and indigenous guardian killed in 2020 for protecting nature, and warned of the urgency of change. “Today the weather is warming; animals are disappearing; rivers are dying; Our crops do not flourish as they used to. The Earth is speaking. It tells us that we no longer have time.”

TESTIMONIAL

Eduarda Zoghbi, Political Scientist from UnB and Master’s student at Columbia (USA)

The search for more space by the new generations

“When I was 16, I was at COP-15, in Copenhagen. I couldn’t get in, I was left outside. There was no space for young people. In 2016, there were ten of us in the Brazilian youth delegation. This year, there were 80 of us, the most diverse youth delegation we have ever had. There was not one indigenous youth, there were ten. There was not one black youth, there were ten. We had trans women, young people from different regions of Brazil.”

column3:
UN event brings together young people in Porto Alegre to address climate change

Young people from all over Rio Grande do Sul will gather in Porto Alegre next weekend, August 17 and 18, at the LCOY - Local Conference of Brazilian Youth on Climate Change. The event, which will be held at the Caixa Econômica Federal Staff Association in Rio Grande do Sul (APCEF), is an initiative of YOUNGO, the official youth group of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).

The event seeks to engage young people in discussion and action on climate change. During the conference, a document will be prepared to be sent directly to the Youth Conference (COY 19) and the Conference of the Parties (COP 29), international discussion events on climate change that will take place in Azerbaijan this year.

"Having an international event here in the state is incredible, as it is an opportunity for us to show the world the challenges we face here, such as the increase in extreme weather events, the rampant degradation of the Pampas and the dismantling of environmental laws. At the same time, we created solutions collaboratively, together with other young people from the state", says Thais Yutori, a climate activist who is organizing the event and is part of Eco Pelo Clima.

For her, the presence of young people from Rio Grande do Sul at LCOY reinforces the importance of community involvement and collaboration in initiatives that seek immediate solutions to climate challenges. "Rio Grande do Sul has been highly impacted by the climate crisis. We recently experienced the worst flood ever seen in the history of our state, we need to involve young people in building solutions that will impact the future that is already ours", says Thais.

column3:
Global appetite for bigger cars is growing, making the fight against global warming harder

The significant negative impact of passenger vehicles on the climate could have fallen by more than 30% in the past decade if it weren’t for the world’s appetite for big cars, a new report from the Global Fuel Economy Initiative suggests.

Transportation is responsible for about a quarter of all climate-warming gases from energy, and much of that can be attributed to passenger transport, according to the International Energy Agency.

But the negative environmental impact of SUVs could have been cut by more than a third between 2010 and 2022 if people had continued to buy the same size cars, according to the initiative, a global partnership of cleaner vehicle groups.

One solution could be electric vehicles (EVs).

George Parrott, a 79-year-old avid runner who lives in West Sacramento, California, decided to switch to cleaner vehicles in 2004 when he bought a Toyota Prius hybrid. Since then, he has owned several pure electric cars and currently owns a Genesis GV60 electric SUV and a Tesla Model 3. 

Not all consumers feel the same way about energy consumption and environmental benefits, especially in the US. While EV sales accounted for 15% of the global auto market last year, that share was just 7.3% in the US. 

Meanwhile, smaller vehicles, or sedans, have lost a lot of ground in the US market over the past decade. In 2012, sedans accounted for 50% of the US auto retail space, with SUVs at just over 30% and trucks at 13.5%, according to car buying firm Edmunds. By 2022, sedans’ share in the US had fallen to 21%, while SUVs reached 54.5% and trucks grew to 20%. 

“People don’t want to be limited by space in their car,” said Eric Frehsée, president of the Tamaroff Group of dealerships in southeast Michigan. “Everybody wants a seven-passenger car.”

“This was a combination of broad environmental concerns,” he said.

More efforts are underway by the U.S. Department of Transportation, the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to improve the fuel economy and tailpipe emissions of gasoline-powered vehicles. Some initiatives could include SUVs, which have the industry buzzing.
column4: ['CC: Criticism of climate policies']

column3:
Drought in Manaus: Rio Negro reaches 3rd lowest level in history

The Rio Negro, in Manaus, reached its third lowest level this Friday, the 13th, at 13.93 meters. The level is 28 centimeters away from breaking the record low level recorded in 2010, when the river reached 13.63 meters.

With the low level, the city government of Manaus issued a statement reinforcing the closure of Ponta Negra beach, which has been closed to swimmers since October 2nd.

The decision to close the beach for swimming, for reasons of safety and to prevent drowning, is due to the proximity between the end of the perennial landfill and the natural riverbed, which may present changes in the terrain, such as holes, unevenness and depressions.

Last Monday, October 9th, the beach was fenced off to physically delimit the area where bathers are prohibited, with signs measuring 1.20 meters high and 1,500 meters long. This physical restriction is intended to prevent people from passing through and to raise awareness among those who insist on bathing in the river in the restricted section.

Climate change is altering the landscape in several parts of the country

The Negro River has seen a very rapid decline, with a reduction of more than 7 meters in water column in just 20 days in September. The explanation lies in the El Niño phenomenon, which has prolonged the intensity of the drought in Amazonas.

The capital of Amazonas declared a state of emergency on September 28th due to the drought.

In addition, the local authority also recommended that the population not engage in physical activities. This is because Manaus was once again covered in smoke.

“I recommend not practicing sports. “We cannot breathe carbon monoxide, which causes problems. As a result, we are going to postpone our city marathon, which was scheduled for the weekend. We also need to avoid exposure to smoke, close our windows, and hydration is essential at this time. Unfortunately, this is what we are going through as a result of climate change,” said the Mayor, David Almeida.

column3:
Ethiopia and FAO sign programme to combat climate change

The Regional Livestock and Pastoralism Programme for Climate Adaptation in the East/North Africa region will be implemented in four transboundary group areas, including Mandera and Karamoja (Ethiopia), Mara-Serengeti (Tanzania) and Bahr Al Arab (Sudan and South Sudan).

Kenya, Somalia and Uganda are other countries targeted by the €47 million EU-funded project, of which €6.25 million is for Addis Ababa, the local state portfolio revealed.

Fikru Regasa, Ethiopia’s Minister of State for the sector, highlighted the fight against climate change and local efforts to deal with its effects, particularly in pastoralism.

FAO Country Representative Farayi Zimudzi said the programme is aligned with the UN agency’s strategic framework for “Better Production, Better Nutrition, Better Environment, Better Lives”. Zimudzi added that the Ethiopian Ministry of Agriculture is the main implementing partner of the initiative and plays a coordinating role at federal, regional and cluster levels (a group of interrelated and geographically concentrated companies and institutions competing in the same business). The regional programme is also expected to improve resilience to man-made disasters in pastoralist and farming communities in the target areas. It was noted that livestock in pastoral areas perform a variety of functions, including economic, social and cultural. Over the centuries, livestock keepers have also provided ecosystem services that are difficult to translate into commercial and intangible values, encompassing many interrelated environmental benefits.

column3:
“Apocalyptic” fires force evacuation of tourists on Greek islands: five firefighters injured

Several tourists have been forced to be evacuated from hotels in Greece due to the threat posed by the numerous forest fires spreading across the country: according to the British ‘The Independent’, firefighters fought fires on the islands of Chios and Kos, in the eastern Aegean Sea, this Monday, which injured five people.

Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has already warned of a dangerous summer ahead, stressing that the help of the population was essential to limit the impact of forest fires: it is worth remembering that in 2023, 20 people died in forest fires during the summer months.

Greece has recently experienced several forest fires: however, the hotter, drier and windier weather, which scientists associate with the effects of climate change, has increased their frequency and intensity.

On Monday morning, emergency services issued evacuation orders for people in the Metohi area of ​​western Chios to move to a nearby beach – by the evening, more than 140 firefighters, along with eight specialist forest fire teams, seven aircraft and three helicopters were battling the blaze.

According to fire department spokesman Vasilis Vathrakoyiannis, two firefighters were slightly injured: state television ‘ERT’ later reported that two other firefighters and a volunteer suffered non-life-threatening burns. “The situation remains difficult in Chios, and all Civil Protection forces will make every effort to limit it,” Vathrakoyiannis assured.

Further south in the Aegean, another fire broke out on the tourist island of Kos, forcing the evacuation of several people, including tourists from hotels as a precaution: the blaze was tackled by more than 100 firefighters, including reinforcements sent from Athens, as well as six planes and two helicopters, Vathrakoyiannis added. Greece has seen 52 wildfires break out in the past 24 hours, 44 of which were tackled in the early stages, Vathrakoyiannis noted: the fires come a day after firefighters managed to control two major wildfires near Athens that were fuelled by strong winds. “We had an exceptionally difficult June in terms of weather conditions, with high levels of drought and exceptionally strong winds for this season,” Kyriakos Mitsotakis said on Monday, adding that this summer “is set to be particularly dangerous” for wildfires. Clare Smith, who is on holiday in Kos with her husband and nine-year-old daughter, told Sky News that the situation had “worsened significantly” throughout the day, with “thick clouds of black smoke”. “It’s very windy here, it’s going to be like a powder keg. The sky is covered in smoke and it feels like you’re in the apocalypse, or some kind of war movie.”
