column3:
Study concludes that recovery of biodiversity in European rivers stagnated in the 2010s

An international study involving Maria João Feio and Manuel Graça, researchers from the Centre for Marine and Environmental Sciences (MARE) at the Faculty of Science and Technology of the University of Coimbra (FCTUC), published in the journal Nature, concluded that, despite the positive trends of the 1990s, the recovery of river biodiversity stagnated from 2010 onwards.

In Europe, over the last three decades, and particularly since the publication of the Water Framework Directive in 2000, several mitigation measures have been implemented to combat the degradation of rivers and their ecosystems. However, the number of factors that threaten these ecosystems continues to increase worldwide.

Thus, “this study aimed to analyse whether, over the last few decades, there has actually been a recovery of aquatic biodiversity in riverine systems over time, as a result of the mitigation measures implemented in Europe, and what factors determined this”, explains Maria João Feio, adding that it was possible to conclude “that there was indeed a small increase in the number of species (0.73% per year), functional richness (2.4% per year) and abundance (1.7% per year) in aquatic macroinvertebrate communities”. However, the researcher continues, “despite these positive trends, the number of species still decreased in 30% of locations. The riverine ecosystems where the least recovery was observed were those located downstream of dams, in urban areas and agricultural lands. Furthermore, invertebrate communities located in areas with faster warming rates had less recovery, which shows the impacts of climate change, namely the effect of rising temperatures”, she warns. According to experts, the increases in biodiversity occurred mainly before the 2010s and have stagnated since then. The gains in biodiversity in the 1990s and 2000s reflect improvements in the physical and chemical quality of water, due to the implementation of more effective treatment systems and ecological rehabilitation or restoration projects. The slowdown in the recovery of riverine biodiversity in the 2010s shows that current measures are not sufficient, and are increasingly resulting in fewer positive results in the recovery of biodiversity.

This stagnation, the researcher adds, “occurred because new threats have also emerged, namely emerging pollutants, such as pharmaceuticals and microplastics, climate change and invasive species. In fact, the number of non-native species (found in 69% of the sites analyzed) has been increasing sharply (4% per year)”, she states.

In view of these results, the researchers consider it “urgent to continue ecological restoration based on renaturalization and recovery of species, not merely aesthetic, or focused on runoff, or the removal of nutrients from water, but also on new planning focused on new impacts, such as emerging pollutants, climate change and invasive species. In addition, the research also shows the importance of continuing ecological monitoring of rivers so that studies can be carried out that address temporal developments”, they conclude.

This research, which involved 96 European researchers from 70 institutions, was coordinated by researchers from the Senckenberg Research Institute and the Natural History Museum Frankfurt, Germany.

column3:
Climate crisis could impact insects’ sex lives, study finds

In cold weather, an insect with a darker body is better at capturing a mate than a rival with a brighter structure. Darker males can warm up more easily in the early morning and therefore have more time to mate while others are still warming up.

This is one of many examples of how temperature affects insects’ coloration and, in turn, can affect their ability to mate, according to a new review paper published in the journal Ecology and Evolution and reported by the Guardian.

Scientists are still trying to figure out what will happen to insects’ sex lives now that man-made climate breakdown is pushing temperatures to unprecedented levels.

“On the one hand, we could be happy and say, ‘How are the insects? They’re responding to climate change. We don’t need to worry about them,” said Mariella Herberstein, a behavioural ecologist at Macquarie University in Sydney, Australia, who is one of the study’s authors.

The prevailing theory among scientists, Herberstein says, is that as temperatures rise, insects largely evolve to produce less of the pigment that regulates their hue, becoming lighter and brighter. That’s because darker objects absorb more heat and warm up more quickly, while lighter objects reflect more radiation and can stay cooler for longer. 

For example, the wing colors of some North American mountain butterflies have faded over time as temperatures have risen—their bright sulfur-yellow wings have become paler, according to a 2016 study. 

Between the 1980s and 2000s, it became increasingly unlikely that the two-spotted ladybug would be black with red spots rather than red with black spots. 

But Herberstein’s team found that the pattern isn’t always that simple. A follow-up study of Meadii butterflies, which looked at more than 800 animals collected for museum collections between 1953 and 2013, found that in some areas, their yellow wings became richer and darker in color over time. “The mechanism is not so clear—it’s confusing,” said another of the study’s authors, Tonmoy Haque, a PhD student at Macquarie University. That may be because the researchers are working with a limited set of data from similar studies of similar insects, he says. It’s also likely because melanin doesn’t just have a heat-related function, but is involved in immune defenses and helps protect against ultraviolet radiation from the sun.

column3:
Russia ready to talk to Ukraine to end war

Russia said Thursday that it is ready to talk to Ukraine, but warns that it first needs to understand to what extent Volodymyr Zelensky's government is willing to negotiate.

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters that Moscow is ready to start negotiations.

"This is a difficult issue. From a legal point of view it is a problem, but from a practical point of view, we are open to achieving our goals through negotiations. Therefore, several variants are possible," the presidential spokesman said.

Zelensky's legitimacy as president of Ukraine has been an issue raised by Russia, which argues that the Ukrainian leader's term ended on May 20. The Russian spokesman said that in addition to "problems with Zelensky's legitimacy", there is also "the problem of the ban on establishing any contact or negotiations with the Russian side, as this ban remains in force".

"Russia is generally open to the negotiation process, but it is necessary to understand to what extent the Ukrainian side is prepared. So far, as you can see, we have heard very different statements. Things are not very clear," he added.

Peskov's statements come after Ukraine announced on Wednesday that it was ready to negotiate with Russia, demanding "good faith".

The Ukrainian president has recently held talks with political representatives in favour of an immediate ceasefire, such as Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump and Vatican Secretary of State Pietro Parolin.

Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba also travelled to China this week to discuss potential peace talks between Ukraine and Russia.

column3:
Ukraine accuses officials of embezzling money earmarked for arms purchases

According to the Ukrainian security services (SBU), five people have been charged, one of whom was detained while trying to cross the Ukrainian border and faces a sentence of up to 12 years in prison.

The investigation comes as Kyiv tries to crack down on corruption in a bid to fast-track its accession to the European Union and NATO, one of the conditions set by its European partners.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was elected on an anti-corruption platform in 2019, long before Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Both the president and his aides have pointed to the recent dismissals of senior officials, including Ivan Bakanov, the former head of the State Security Service, in July 2022, as evidence of their efforts to crack down on corruption.

Security officials say the current investigation dates back to August 2022, when officials signed a contract to purchase artillery shells worth 1.5 billion hryvnias (37 million euros) from the arms company Lviv Arsenal.

After receiving payment, the company's employees were supposed to transfer the funds to a foreign-registered company, which would then deliver the ammunition.

However, the goods were never delivered and the money was instead sent to various accounts in Ukraine and the Balkans, according to investigators.

The Ukrainian Prosecutor General's Office says the funds have since been seized and will be returned to the country's defense budget.

In the meantime, Ukraine today reported a wave of Russian attacks on its infrastructure in several regions of the country, and Russia announced that it had repelled new Ukrainian advances in Kharkiv and Donetsk.

Zaporizhia was one of the worst-hit regions, with at least 130 Russian shellings in the past 24 hours, according to the head of the Ukrainian regional administration, Yuri Malasko. At least 24 communities were hit by shelling in 33 drone strikes. Another 15 communities in the Sumy region were hit by Russian shelling, according to the Ukrainian military administration in the region, in a message also posted on its Telegram account. "Ninety-one explosions were recorded at the regional level," according to the authorities. Russia, for its part, said today that its forces repelled five attacks and counterattacks by assault groups of two brigades of the Armed Forces of Ukraine in the direction of Kupiansk, near Sinkovka in the Kharkiv region, and Terniv in Donetsk. "The motorized rifle units of the group, in cooperation with artillery, repelled two attacks and three counterattacks by the assault groups of the 32nd mechanized brigade and the 103rd Ukrainian territorial defense brigade in the Sinkovka and Ternov areas. All attacks and counterattacks were repelled. The enemy was forced to withdraw to the south and west," military spokesman Sergei Zibinsky told the Russian news agency TASS.

column3:
Russian Defense Ministry: Russian troops advanced towards Donetsk, killed 175 enemy servicemen

The Russian military has killed nearly 500 Ukrainian personnel over the past 24 hours and destroyed military vehicles and self-propelled artillery systems, according to the Russian Defense Ministry.

Russian troops in the Donetsk direction have taken advantageous positions with the Yug (South) grouping of troops, the losses of the Armed Forces of Ukraine have reached 175 servicemen, the Russian Defense Ministry reported on Monday (25).

At the same time, it said that Russia destroyed six military vehicles, including a Bradley infantry fighting vehicle, as well as a Krab self-propelled artillery system, a Rapira anti-tank gun and two Nota and Anklav-N radars.

In the Kupyansk and Kherson directions, Ukrainian casualties in the last 24 hours amounted to about 60 men in combat with Russian forces, and an attempted attack on Russian troops failed, which used the efforts of units from the Zapad (West) and Dnieper troop groups to destroy two cars, nine pick-ups and a Gvozdika self-propelled artillery system.

Meanwhile, according to the Russian military body, in the Avdeevka and south of Donetsk directions, the Armed Forces of Ukraine conducted ten unsuccessful counterattack attempts and lost some of their positions, but Russia, with the Vostok (East) and Tsentr (Center) troop groups, destroyed about 230 personnel, 13 military vehicles, an Akatsiya self-propelled artillery system, an AN/TPQ-48 radar and other Ukrainian weapons.

In addition, Russia successfully shot down 103 drones and 31 Himars, Vampire and Uragan rocket launchers.

In total, during the special military operation, 577 aircraft, 270 helicopters, 17,011 unmanned aerial vehicles, 489 anti-aircraft defense systems, 15,598 tanks and other armored combat vehicles, 1,256 multiple rocket launchers, 8,521 field artillery pieces and mortars, and 20,192 units of Ukrainian special military vehicles were destroyed, the Russian Defense Ministry summarized.

column3:
Earth's core is slowing down and may rotate in the opposite direction; understand how this affects the planet

Radical natural phenomena and events caused by climate change scare people about the future. Concerns apparently grew after a group of scientists recently suggested that the rotation of the Earth's core is slowing down and may start rotating in the opposite direction.

The theory was presented in a study published in the scientific journal Nature Geoscience. According to the publication, the process began in 2019 and the new cycle may last up to 70 years, with the possibility of changing the length of days. However, the researchers reinforce that this is a structural phenomenon of the Earth and not a catastrophic event.

The authors of the research used seismic records to understand the change in the rotation of the Earth's core, and claim that this process may be related to some natural disasters.

After analyzing data on the planet's inner core between the 1990s and 2020, scientists have identified a noticeable change in recent years. However, this hypothesis does not come from these researchers alone. Professor John Vidale, dean of Earth Sciences at the California Dornsife College of Letters, Arts and Sciences (USC Dornsife), explained in an article in Nature Geoscience that the planet has undergone a slowdown until it began to rotate in reverse in recent years. This new movement would cause major changes in the functioning of all forms of life on Earth. The scientific community has concluded that the rotation of the core is not completely consistent, as it seemed to be constantly slowing down. Even so, experts emphasize that understanding the Earth's core is extremely difficult due to the impossibility of making direct observations. "Here we analyzed repeated seismic waves from the early 1990s and showed that all the paths that previously showed significant temporal changes showed little change over the last decade. This globally consistent pattern suggests that the differential rotation of the inner core has recently been interrupted,” the study says.

Why is the Earth’s core spinning backwards?

The first discovery about how the Earth’s inner core works was made in a study conducted by seismologist Inge Lehmann in 1936. At that time, the Danish scientist realized that this region worked like a “solid metal ball.”

On the other hand, research into the variation in the core’s rotation speed occurred in the 1970s and 1980s. Then, in the early 1990s, the first seismological evidence was released.

Researchers used data from seismic waves and earthquakes to understand the interactions with the planet’s inner core. Even so, there are disagreements among scientists about this theory. Some of them argue that the data is still limited due to the difficulty of collecting samples and making precise observations.

column3:
Russia takes control of another town in eastern Ukraine

The Russian Defense Ministry announced Saturday that Russian forces had taken control of the town of Lozuvatske in the Pokrovsk sector of Ukraine’s Donetsk region, the site of some of the fiercest frontline fighting in the 29-month war.

The Ukrainian General Staff did not mention the town in its report, but noted that the area around it had been engulfed in heavy fighting. Unofficial military sources reported the loss of at least two other towns in the sector.

Russian forces have been advancing slowly through the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, making steady, incremental gains since taking the key town of Avdiivka in February.

The Russian Defense Ministry said the “central” group of Russian forces had captured Lozuvatske, northwest of the Russian-held regional center of Donetsk.

Russia also said its forces launched strikes in other locations in the sector and repelled three Ukrainian counterattacks. Ukrainian authorities have reported for several weeks that the Pokrovsk sector is experiencing the heaviest fighting along the 1,000-kilometer frontline. President Volodymyr Zelenskiy discussed the sector twice on Thursday with his top commander, Olexandr Syrskyi. The Ukrainian General Staff reported on Saturday that Ukrainian forces had repelled 17 attacks in the area, with 10 clashes still ongoing. “The situation is difficult, but under the control of the armed forces,” the report said. Ukraine’s popular unofficial military blog DeepState did not mention Lozuvatske in its latest report, but in the past two days it reported the fall of two villages in the sector — Prohres and Vovche.

column3:
Climate change? A lie of socialism, says Argentina's President-elect

Javier Milei believes in property rights and the privatization of natural resources to solve environmental problems. Why are whales becoming extinct but chickens are not?

Global warming? “Nothing, it's another lie of socialism. There's a whole agenda of cultural Marxism,” said Javier Milei, the anarcho-capitalist President-elect of Argentina, with a hairstyle that reminds one of an out-of-fashion football player. He doesn't believe in climate change, wants to abolish the Ministry of the Environment (among many others), privatize the Ministry of Science and believes in private property as a way to regulate pollution.

Climate change is not the fault of humans, he said, against all scientific evidence. “The world has had other peaks of high temperatures. It's a cyclical behavior, independent of the existence of man. Therefore, all these policies that blame humans for climate change are false and only serve to raise funds to finance lazy socialists who write fifth-rate documents,” he said in the second debate with Sergio Massa, the defeated candidate. 

Milei’s speech became famous in which he said that “a company can pollute a river however it wants.” Pause: “And? Where is the damage?” The problem, said the far-right politician, is that property rights are poorly defined. 

An economist, former rock singer and former football goalkeeper, among other colorful biographical details, Javier Milei defines himself as a libertarian who believes in defining property rights to solve potential environmental problems. 

“A company can pollute a river however it wants, and do you know why? Because this is a society in which there is plenty of water and the price of water is zero. Consequently, who is going to claim the right to property of that river? Nobody, because they can’t make money,” he said. Now, if someone owns the water in this river, they will be interested in negotiating with those who pollute it. “They will see how the contamination will end,” said Milei.

These policies that blame humans for climate change are false and only serve to raise funds to finance lazy socialists who write fifth-rate documents.

His main advisor, Alberto Benegas Lynch, illustrated the idea that involves the broad privatization of resources and state assets using whales. “Why are whales on the brink of extinction, while chickens and cows are not? The difference is in the fence that protects them. Where there is an owner, there is economic benefit, and this protects the fauna,” he said, suggesting privatizing the sea.

column3:
India: Heatwave may have killed at least 24 people in 24 hours

A severe heatwave in the eastern Indian states of Bihar and Odisha is believed to have killed at least 24 people due to heatstroke, local authorities said. The extreme weather event is expected to last until Saturday.

India has been lashed by an extremely hot summer and a part of the capital, Delhi, this week recorded the highest temperature ever in the country, at 52.9 degrees Celsius, although this figure may be revised after the meteorological department checks the sensors at the weather station that recorded the reading.

While temperatures in northwest and central India are expected to cool in the coming days, the heatwave prevailing in eastern India is expected to continue for two days, said the India Meteorological Department (IMD), which declares a heatwave when the temperature is 4.5 to 6.4 degrees Celsius higher than normal.

Fourteen people died in Bihar on Thursday, officials said, including 10 people who were working to organise the seven-phase national elections that are underway. Citizens in parts of Bihar will vote on Saturday. Officials told Reuters that 10 people died at a government hospital in Odisha’s Rourkela region on Thursday.

The Odisha government has banned outdoor activities for its employees between 11 am and 3 pm, when temperatures peak.

Three people have died of suspected heatstroke in Bihar’s neighbouring state of Jharkhand, local media reported.

Animals in distress

In Delhi, where high temperatures have caused wild birds and monkeys to faint or fall ill, the city’s zoo is using pools and sprinklers to provide relief to its 1,200 occupants.

“We have switched to a summer diet, which includes a more liquid diet as well as all seasonal fruits and vegetables that contain more water,” Sanjeet Kumar, the zoo’s director, told the ANI news agency.

New Delhi, where temperatures are expected to reach 43 degrees Celsius (110 degrees Fahrenheit) on Friday, recorded its first heat-related death this week and is facing severe water shortages.

Thousands of people across Asia, including in neighbouring Pakistan, have been battling rising temperatures – a trend that scientists say has been exacerbated by human-caused climate change.

India, which is holding its national elections amid the heat, is the world’s third-largest emitter of greenhouse gases but has set a goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2070.

As the heat grips parts of the country, the northeastern states of Manipur and Assam were hit by heavy rains following Cyclone Remal, with several areas flooded on Friday.

Monsoon rains also hit the coast of the southernmost state of Kerala on Thursday, two days ahead of schedule.

column3:
Brazil is among places that could become uninhabitable in 50 years, says NASA

Wet bulb temperatures are rising around the world, and the Earth's climate has begun to exceed the 35ºC limit.

A study by NASA, the US space agency, has shown that some parts of the world could become uninhabitable in the coming decades due to climate change. According to the report, areas of the Center-West, Northeast, North and Southeast of Brazil are included in a study that mapped five regions.

Colin Raymond, from NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory and author of a 2020 study on extreme heat and humidity, says that "climate models tell us that certain regions are likely to exceed these temperatures [35ºC] in the next 30 to 50 years."

In addition to Brazil, Raymond cites southern and parts of Southeast Asia, eastern China, the Persian Gulf and the Red Sea. The US is not immune either: within 50 years, midwestern states such as Arkansas, Missouri and Iowa will likely be in a critical situation as well.

The 35°C figure in the survey refers to the wet-bulb temperature used as a standard for measuring heat and humidity, especially in long-term global climate surveys.

According to Raymond, this is the highest wet-bulb temperature that humans can survive when exposed to it for at least six hours.

Wet-bulb temperatures are rising around the world, and the Earth’s climate has begun to exceed this 35°C threshold. This means that the hotter it gets, the more strain our bodies feel, and the more we need to sweat to cool down.

column3:
Brazil's first protest at COP28 uses a giant pink dolphin against oil exploration in the Amazon

A 4-meter-long pink dolphin, made by artist Gil Reais, was the protagonist of Brazil's first protest action at COP28, in Dubai, held this Sunday (3).

The initiative, entitled “Boto Alerta: Queremos nadar na água, não no petrol!”, was carried out by the youth organization Engajamundo, in partnership with Greenpeace Brasil, in the Blue Zone of the UN climate conference.

The objective was to denounce the socio-environmental impacts that oil exploration in the Amazon region can cause, one of the issues that is clouding Brazil's presence at the first COP of the Lula government.

Brazil's protest at COP28 inspired by the death of dolphins

The inspiration for the sculpture was the death of dolphins impacted by the severe drought of the last period, representing the fauna and oil exploration in the Amazon River Basin.

For Marcelo Laterman, spokesperson for Greenpeace Brazil, the action carried out in partnership with Engajamundo denounces the contradiction of the Brazilian government in defending the expansion of the country's oil frontiers, especially in sensitive areas such as the Amazon, while at the same time seeking to reposition the country as a leading player in the climate agenda.

“In a creative way, these young activists are sending an important message: there is no virtuous future for the Amazon with the expansion of oil in the region. The opening of this new frontier could be marked as President Lula's worst socio-environmental legacy. The government must fulfill its promises and defend the Amazon, its people and face the climate crisis responsibly.”

Between 2012 and 2020, according to Engajamundo, the number of oil fields in the Amazon increased by 13% and, if this new frontier on the Amazon coast is opened, this number will increase exponentially.

Brazil is the 9th largest oil producer in the world. Engajamundo and Greenpeace criticize Basil's entry as an observer at OPEC+ (Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries), in the middle of COP28, "which shows that the country and its leaders still have oil as an economic priority, despite speeches in defense of decarbonization".

Jaciara Borari is one of Engajamundo's indigenous activists and is part of the delegation that organized this action.

"We want the protest at COP28 to somehow express the urgency of this agenda reaching decision-makers, and for the process of oil exploration in the Amazon River Basin to be rethought and blocked.

"We still have time to avoid a major disaster!" warns the activist.
column4: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities', 'CC: Amplifying Climate Fears']
column5: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities: Criticism of national governments', 'CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Other']

column3:
Emirates oil company chairman to lead COP28

The head of the United Arab Emirates oil company was appointed on Thursday (12) as chairman of the annual UN climate conference, scheduled for the end of the year in the Gulf country, drawing criticism from environmentalists.

The UAE's Industry Minister, chairman of oil giant ADNOC (Abu Dhabi National Oil Company) and special envoy for climate change, Sultan Ahmed al Jaber, is the "chairman-designate for the 28th Conference of the Parties (COP28)," the official WAM news agency reported in a statement on Thursday.

It will be the first time that a company chairman will lead the COP, which this year will be held in Dubai between November and December.

"We will bring a pragmatic, realistic and solution-oriented approach," Sultan Ahmed al Jaber said after his appointment. "Climate action represents a major economic opportunity to invest in sustainable growth. Financing is key," he added.

Sultan Ahmed al Jaber has headed the UAE’s national oil company since 2016, as well as Masdar, the country’s renewable energy company. His dual role has drawn criticism from environmentalists. “The appointment of Sultan Ahmed al Jaber to the COP28 presidency as chairman of Abu Dhabi’s national oil company is an outrageous conflict of interest,” said Harjeet Singh of Climate Action Network International. “The constant threat of fossil fuel lobbyists at UN climate talks has always undermined the outcome of climate talks. This has now reached a dangerous and unprecedented level,” he added. Oil and gas lobbyists were plentiful at COP27 in Egypt last November, up 25% from the previous meeting in Glasgow, according to environmental groups. The largest contingent of lobbyists were from the UAE, followed by Russians. The United Arab Emirates, one of the world’s largest oil exporters, is advocating a phase-out of hydrocarbons and has pledged to achieve carbon neutrality by 2050. The country has experienced rapid economic growth since the 1970s, fueled by oil, but its economy has gradually diversified. “Limiting warming to 1.5°C [as set out in the 2015 Paris Agreement] will require significant emissions reductions, a pragmatic, practical and realistic approach to the energy transition, and increased support for emerging economies,” the statement released today said. Climate change is a sensitive issue in the Gulf states, where temperatures regularly reach 50°C in summer.
column4: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities']
column5: ['CC: Criticism of institutions and authorities: Criticism of international entities']

column3:
Austrian climate activists 'Last Generation' end protests due to lack of results

The 'Last Generation' movement has demonstrated in many different ways over the years, often in disruptive ways, in an attempt to gain media and public attention.

The most high-profile actions have included road closures, disruptions to motorsport and winter sports events, confrontations with politicians, disruptions to theatre performances, cementing cars, disrupting shareholder meetings of fossil fuel companies, disrupting marathons and, most recently, protests at airports.

The group has now announced an end to the protests, at least until it finds new ways to make its voice heard. 'Last Generation' says that the government is not responding and that society itself has come out in favour of the use of fossil fuels.

"The form of protest was absolutely necessary at the time we decided to do it. We also needed a certain amount of everyday disruption,” says Anja Windl, an activist with the “Last Generation”. “But ultimately the problem of failure is more that few people dared, did not have the courage to actually peacefully confront the government.”

Activist Afra Porsche is calm about facing the authorities’ investigations into the protests the group has already held. She also believes that the protests will return, but in a different form.

“We need to shake things up. Civil resistance is legitimate and democratic. There will be resistance again, but in a different form,” says Afra Porsche.

Group succeeds in attracting attention

Communications expert Jakob-Moritz Eberl believes that the group has at least achieved its goal of attracting attention.

"The aim was to generate awareness and draw attention to the fact that the situation is unpleasant," says Jakob-Moritz Eberl. "There is scientific evidence that the importance of the climate crisis or climate change increases significantly after such actions, even for a short period of time, but the issue becomes important for society." Meteorologist Michael Staudinger from the group "Scientists for the Future" argues that scientists also have an important role to play in raising awareness of these concerns. "Well, it was an attempt to convey a certain message. It wasn't very successful, but we understand that young people expressed their concerns in their own way," says Eberl. "Now we have to see what happens next. Science has to communicate these issues in the right way." The scientist stresses that the situation is "very serious" and that young people are the ones who will be most affected. "The next generation and the generation after that will be affected ten times more than ours," he concludes.

column3:
Faced with wave of fires, Lula announces creation of Climate Authority

The creation of the new structure was a campaign promise made by Lula, when Marina Silva, current Minister of the Environment, joined his candidacy in 2022.

— Our focus needs to be on adaptation and preparation to face these phenomena (extreme climate risks). To this end, we will establish a climate authority and a technical-scientific committee that supports and coordinates the implementation of the federal government's actions — said the president, during a meeting with mayors to announce measures to combat drought in the state, in an excerpt read from his speech.

Lula added that the "objective is to establish the conditions to expand and accelerate public policies based on a national plan to face extreme climate risks".

According to the proposal presented in the election, the National Authority for Climate Change would have the objective of monitoring the measures taken by the government to reduce the emission of gases that contribute to the greenhouse effect. After the victory, the proposal was put aside. One of the reasons given was budgetary constraints.

Lula traveled to Amazonas accompanied by ministers Rui Costa (Chief of Staff), Marina Silva (Environment), José Múcio Monteiro (Defense), Nizia Trindade (Health), Wellington Dias (Social Development) and Silvio Costa Filho (Ports and Airports).

The president announced an investment of 81.8 million euros in dredging interventions in the rivers of the state of Amazonas, to facilitate navigation in the midst of the drought. The paving of a 20-kilometer stretch of the BR-319 highway was also promised, at a cost of 25.8 million euros.

During his speech, Lula also criticized the administration of his predecessor Jair Bolsonaro (PL).

"The previous plan for the environment was clear; it was to open the gate to let the cattle through. And we think that we can even raise cattle, but we don't need to destroy the forest and our planet in order to raise cattle. And that's why we're treating it with great decency."

The Amazon has been recording below-average rainfall since July. In recent weeks, fires have left cities and even indigenous territories covered in smoke. On August 27, 1,516 fires were recorded in the Amazon, according to the monitoring panel of the National Institute for Space Research (INPE): 39% in Pará, 29% in Amazonas, 12% in Acre, 10% in Rondônia and 8% in Mato Grosso.

In July, the Amazon experienced its worst July since the beginning of the historical series of fires, in 1998. In addition to deforestation, the biome is suffering from a severe drought for the second consecutive year.

column3:
World sets record for hottest day for second consecutive year

The world had its hottest day on record again on Monday (22), surpassing Sunday (21), which also broke a record, according to preliminary data from a European Union monitoring agency.

With heatwaves raging around the world and wildfires raging in parts of the Mediterranean, Russia and Canada, the global average surface air temperature rose to 17.15 degrees Celsius (°C) on Monday. That was 0.06°C higher than Sunday's record, according to the European Union's Copernicus Climate Change Service, which has been tracking such data since 1940.

That includes temperatures in the Southern Hemisphere, which is currently in winter, lowering the global average.

Scientists said it was possible that Tuesday and Wednesday this week could surpass Monday's record again.

Previously, the record hot day was set in July 2023, when the average daily peak was broken for four consecutive days – from July 3 to 6. Before that, the record was set in August 2016.

El Niño

What makes this year’s record unusual is that, unlike in 2023 and 2016, in April the world exited the El Niño weather pattern, which typically boosts global temperatures due to warmer-than-normal waters in the Eastern Pacific.

Karsten Haustein, a climate scientist at the University of Leipzig in Germany, said it was remarkable that the record had been broken again now that the world was in the “neutral” phase of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation.

This points to climate change, driven by the burning of fossil fuels, having a greater influence than ever on rising global temperatures.

"Last Monday may have set a new world record for the hottest absolute global average temperature ever recorded, that is, in tens of thousands of years," Haustein said.

China has issued a series of heat alerts this week, with dozens of weather stations in parts of the central and northwestern part of the country recording temperatures above 40°C.

Extreme events

Taiwan braced for the impact of Typhoon Gaemi on Wednesday, with factories and financial markets closed amid forecasts of torrential rain.

Scientists say climate change is making typhoons — tropical cyclones that gain energy by feeding on ocean heat — more intense, capable of reaching higher wind speeds and dumping more rain.

Japan has also been experiencing record heat throughout July. Heatstroke alerts were issued in 39 of the country's 47 prefectures on Monday, with temperatures above 37°C.

More than 40 million Americans were facing dangerous temperatures on Tuesday, especially in the western United States, where gusty winds and dry conditions have fueled dozens of wildfires. Even the Arctic is experiencing a heatwave. Fairbanks, Alaska, is expected to reach 31°C on Wednesday, approaching previous records, while temperatures in parts of the Canadian, Russian and Norwegian Arctic were reaching temperatures more than 9°C above the 1979-2000 average for this time of year.

column3:
Bad weather and climate change affect sugar production in Mozambique

"We are experiencing a drop in our sugar production due to some difficulties caused by the bad weather in the country in recent years," Pascoal Macule, director of Tongaat Hulett, the group that owns Açucareira de Mafambisse, told reporters on Thursday.

The director said that the company's annual production of 75,000 tons had fallen to 40,000 in the last two years, causing significant losses to the factory.

Another factor that influenced the sharp drop in production was the loss of around 8,000 hectares of sugar cane, the raw material for sugar production, due to the effects of climate change: "This is happening in Nhamatanda, due to the drought in our fields and the El Niño phenomenon."

Located in the administrative post of Mafambisse, in the district of Dondo, in Sofala, the sugar mill has the installed capacity to produce 92 thousand tons of sugar per year.

Mozambique is considered one of the countries most severely affected by climate change in the world, cyclically facing floods and tropical cyclones during the rainy season, which runs from October to April.

The 2018/2019 rainy season was one of the most severe in living memory: 714 people died, including 648 victims of cyclones Idai and Kenneth, two of the largest ever to hit the country.

The province of Sofala, in the center of the territory, has been one of the most affected by storms.

In the first quarter of last year, heavy rains and the passage of Cyclone Freddy caused 306 deaths, affected more than 1.3 million people in the country, destroyed 236 thousand homes and 3,200 classrooms, according to official government data.

Tongaat Hulett recently announced an injection of 500 million rand (25 million euros) into the Mafambisse and Xinavane sugar mills, both in Mozambique and in which the South African group is the majority shareholder.

The challenges faced by the two sugar mills in recent times include countering a continuing decline in sugar sales and obtaining support to prevent low-priced sugar imports from entering the domestic market and affecting domestic production.

To turn the situation around, according to the director of Tongaat Hulett, Mafambisse Sugar Mill has adopted several strategies, including seeking more financial partners to leverage the company.

"We have recovered, although we did not meet expectations. We are currently serving the markets of West Africa, the United States, Mauritius and Mozambique, and we are planning to expand the export market for our product to neighboring Malawi," concluded Pascoal Macule.

column3:
Climáximo protesters throw red paint at Navigator headquarters

The group accuses the “cellulose industry” of being responsible for the fires and seven deaths this week. The protesters were arrested and the company will file a criminal complaint.

Two members of the Climáximo group threw red paint at the Navigator headquarters in Lisbon this Friday, accusing the paper manufacturing company of being responsible for the forest fires and the resulting deaths.

The two people then sat down in front of the entrance on Av. Fontes Pereira de Melo and were subsequently arrested by the PSP, according to a source from this police force who confirmed to PÚBLICO, for committing the crime of damage.

An official source from Navigator told PÚBLICO that it “vehemently repudiates this and all acts of vandalism” and that it “will file a criminal complaint against those responsible for this act of vandalism.”

In a statement from Climáximo, protester Alice Gato, 22, declared that “the seven deaths this week” in the fires that ravaged the center and north of Portugal “are the direct result of a coordinated offensive between the State, the pulp industry and the fossil fuel industry to turn the interior of our country into an incineration chamber. This is the second time this week that Climáximo has targeted Navigator’s facilities. On Tuesday, members of the group had pasted posters on the company’s doors, accusing it of “increased responsibility for the deaths” during the fires. “In the hottest summer on record, the current plans of governments and companies like Navigator to increase greenhouse gas emissions and continue to sell the interior of our country to the paper industry are a violent crime,” argues the climate collective.

column3:
F-16s have arrived in Ukraine. But they are not arriving

Ukrainian forces have been waiting for these reinforcements for more than two years. But this is “not enough”, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has warned.

Ukraine has received its first Western F-16 fighters, which have been expected for more than two years, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy announced today, showing them to journalists and stressing that their number is “not enough”.

“We have held hundreds of meetings and negotiations” with allies to obtain these planes and strengthen the country’s air defence and “we often hear the words ‘it is impossible’ in response”, said Volodymyr Zelenskyy, during a ceremony at a secret location in Ukraine, according to AFP.

“Now it is reality, reality in our skies. The F-16s are in Ukraine”, he said.

Since the Russian invasion began in February 2022, Kiev has been begging for the delivery of F-16s in the hope of ending Russian dominance in the air and better protecting its cities and military from incessant bombing by Moscow's forces.

Made in the United States, the planes are considered the crown jewel in the extensive list of military equipment that Ukraine has requested from its allies in an attempt to repel the advance of Russian forces on its soil.

The Ukrainian president did not reveal the number of aircraft received by Kiev, saying only that it was “insufficient”, as well as the number of Ukrainian pilots trained in the West to fly them.

The delivery date and the country that supplied this first batch were also not revealed.

“What is positive is that we expect more F-16s” and that “many of our men are being trained”, Zelenskyy assured.

AFP journalists saw at least two F-16s flying over the site during the ceremony.

Behind Volodymyr Zelenskyy, two more gray aircraft resembling F-16s were placed on the ground, partially covered by camouflage nets and with their tails emblazoned with the national emblem, the trident.

In mid-May, President Zelenskyy said in an interview with AFP that he needed 120 to 130 of these aircraft to achieve parity with the Russian air force.

column3:
The injustice of climate justice

The climate justice discourse is yet another nonsense in the debate led by groups on the watermelon left: green on the outside, red on the inside.

The combination of the two ideas, justice and climate, is abhorrent. Opinions or policies with this level of absurdity must be denounced and rejected! Justice is a social concept. There is no justice without human beings in society. The climate, in turn, corresponds to a set of atmospheric conditions in a region over many years.

And most importantly, the climate does not depend on humans. The climate depends mainly on the Sun. Without the Sun, there would be no climate, no life on Earth, no human beings – watermelons or not.

The watermelon left replaces the family with the climate in the formulation of national and global policies. In the name of climate justice, draconian environmental measures are taken. They drive industry out of Europe and make fuel prices unsustainable. Our tax burden on diesel is 44% and gasoline is 51%. We all know the consequences. More expensive transport and products. Fewer job opportunities. Fewer jobs. Less justice.

And with everything getting more expensive, we still have to pay for a poorly conceived energy transition. We are forced to bear environmental costs ignored by countries like China, which has almost 200 times more emissions than ours. In Portugal, the left’s climate justice campaign is making the poorest and most vulnerable suffer. These Portuguese people are the ones who suffer the most in their daily lives from the increase in the price of basic food. They are the ones who have to survive in cold, unheated homes, forgotten by climate watchdogs.

column3:
Italy's Deputy Prime Minister Suggests Macron Wear Helmet and Go to Ukraine

Italy's Minister of Transport and Infrastructure Matteo Salvini has suggested that Emmanuel Macron go to Ukraine and take part in hostilities.

"I will tell Macron: go to Ukraine to fight, put on a helmet and don't mess with the Italians," Salvini said at a campaign event for his League party's candidate for mayor of the city.

The League leader has repeatedly criticized NATO and EU leaders for their stance on increasing military support for Kiev and their willingness to lift restrictions on Ukraine's attacks with Western weapons on the territory of the Russian Federation. EU foreign minister Josep Borrell Salvini has called the Demoman and NATO Secretary General Stoltenberg "Mr. Dangerous."

Macron has previously said he does not rule out sending troops to Ukraine if Russia breaks through the front lines and Ukraine asks for it. According to him, "many countries" agreed with France's approach to the possible deployment of troops.

According to the newspaper "Monde", Macron wants to create a European coalition to send military instructors to Ukraine.

Russian President's spokesman Dmitry Peskov called the rhetoric of Paris and London on the possibility of sending troops to Ukraine dangerous. The Kremlin also said that it drew attention to Macron's words on the topic of sending troops to Ukraine in Europe, his position on inflicting a "strategic defeat" on Moscow is also well known. They noted that a number of countries maintain "a rather sober assessment of the potential dangers of such an action and the potential danger of directly getting involved in a hot conflict", that this "is not at all in the interests of these countries, they should be aware of this".

column3:
The former ambassador who received 2 sailboats, was against the Ukrainian government and revealed a “state secret” is the head of Chega’s list in the European elections

António Tânger Corrêa, who was the general secretary of the Juventude Centrista (CDS) and deputy to the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Diogo Freitas do Amaral, in the original AD government, was confirmed in the press this weekend as the head of Chega’s list in the next European elections.

The former ambassador is the protagonist of several controversies, with a long history of 30 years of treading the line, according to the newspaper Público, where the “gift” of a sailboat stands out, but in fact there were two (you can read the full story on Facebook here).

According to the same newspaper, “António Ranger’s” career is a catalogue of “cases” that included breaking into a house and being suspended by the MNE with an unprecedented sentence in the profession — the first for an active ambassador serving abroad.

António Tânger, who followed in his father’s footsteps in the diplomatic career, was suspended in 2009 for 90 days due to several irregularities found in the management of the Portuguese embassy in the Lithuanian capital, Vilnius.

But the controversies of Chega’s No. 1 in the European elections of June 2024 do not stop with situations when he was representing Portugal, more recently, and as vice-president of André Ventura’s party, he adopted a position contrary to the party leader, accusing President Zelensky’s government of having responsibility for the invasion of Ukraine, using a copied message.

In February 2022, days before Russia's invasion of Ukraine began, António Tânger began by making an incorrect prediction and criticizing the "commentators who are pitiful for their ignorance" because "will there ever be a war?"

After making this comment, he "copied" a text on Facebook that accuses the president of Ukraine and justifies Russia's position. This text was posted on his page without identifying the author, later identified after the person responsible contested the copy, and was later deleted from his page after it was also reported in Expresso.

Months earlier, in September 2021, the vice-president of Chega revealed a conspiracy theory to the press that was later not confirmed, when he announced a "state secret" before the elections, because according to the former ambassador, a "working group had been created between the secret services and the Judicial Police to incriminate Chega" in an alleged connection with the deniers.

In January 2023, on the second day of the 5th Chega Convention in Santarém, António Tânger Corrêa recalled the times when he was leader of the Centrist Youth to ask for greater presence and dynamism for the Chega Youth: 

I don't want the Chega Youth to be like the others. I wanted to see the Chega Youth, call me nostalgic or whatever you want, fighting in the streets with blows against the MRPP and the PCP. 

He was greatly applauded by the nostalgic supporters, which led the former ambassador to also state: “In my time, it was a clean sweep”.
column4: ['URW: Discrediting Ukraine']
column5: ['URW: Discrediting Ukraine: Other']

column3:
"Many armies are not ready to fight Russia". In NATO, there are those who fear that they will not be able to withstand an invasion beyond Ukraine

Donald Trump's entry into the US presidency could mess everything up and leave Europe vulnerable

"If anyone thinks this is just about Ukraine, they are completely mistaken." The warning was made by the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

The Ukrainian president's objective is not new: the idea is to continue pressuring the West, particularly the United States, to continue providing financial and military support to Kiev, at a time when Congress is at an impasse in approving more aid.

And if the situation is complicated with Joe Biden's administration, behind the scenes there are fears that a possible election of Donald Trump will only make everything worse. The former president and likely Republican Party candidate has said, on several occasions, that he wants to leave NATO and stop providing military assistance to Western allies.

If this were to extend to Ukraine, Kiev would have a hard time resisting Moscow's advances, and it is possible that sooner or later it would fall.

This scenario has left several European countries on edge, and many of them fearful that they would not be able to resist a possible Russian advance beyond Ukraine, especially if the United States were not available to provide support.

“We always thought there was a threat like this,” said Major General Veiko-Vello Pal, commander of the Estonian army, speaking to The New York Times about a possible Russian invasion.

But the problem is not just the possible lack of American aid. The official from Estonia, one of the countries of the former Soviet Union, which borders modern-day Russia, was merely echoing what the country has been saying for a long time.

Because of its geographical location, Estonia is one of the most vulnerable countries. For this reason, it is also one of the countries that has contributed the most to NATO, having one of the largest armies in terms of size, but it will never be enough to defend the country from a power like Russia.

The problem is, according to Veiko-Vello Palm, that many other countries do not have this capability either. “In the last few years we have made it very, very clear that, as a military alliance, many NATO countries are not ready to conduct large-scale operations,” he said.

“Simply put, many NATO armies are not ready to fight Russia,” he concluded, admitting great discomfort with the situation.

column3:
Ukrainian drone strike causes fire at Russian refinery

A drone strike launched by Ukraine overnight caused a fire at an oil refinery and killed one person in southern Russia, Russian and Ukrainian authorities reported on Monday (22).

Kiev and Moscow have stepped up their cross-border attacks on each other, both with missiles and drones, in recent months, targeting mainly energy infrastructure.

The Russian regional authorities of the Black Sea and the town of Tuapse, in the Krasnodar region (south), explained that the fall of drone debris caused a fire at a refinery, which required the mobilization of a hundred firefighters.

The governor of Belgorod, another region in southern Russia, reported that a person driving a tractor died after being hit by a Ukrainian drone, and that his wife was injured.

A Ukrainian defense source said that drones related to military intelligence services were used and that the damaged refinery is operated by Russian state-owned giant Rosneft.

“The extent of the damage to the military-industrial complex of the aggressor state is being verified,” the source said in a written statement.

According to the Russian Defense Ministry, 75 Ukrainian drones were shot down overnight, 47 of them in the southern region of Rostov, another in Belgorod, two more in Voronezh and Smolensk, and eight in the skies over Krasnodar.

Another 17 drones were shot down while flying over the Black Sea and the Sea of ​​Azov, according to the ministry.

Russia announces, almost daily, that it has shot down Ukrainian drones on its territory.

According to Kiev, these attacks are a response to Russian bombings as part of the invasion of the country, launched by Moscow in February 2022.

Ukraine said that its forces shot down 16 drones overnight.
column4: ['URW: Blaming the war on others rather than the invader', 'URW: Russia is the Victim']
column5: ['URW: Blaming the war on others rather than the invader: Ukraine is the aggressor', 'URW: Russia is the Victim: Other']

column3:
Around 20 countries call for tripling global nuclear power by 2050

The announcement was made by John Kerry, the United States' climate envoy, during the 28th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP28) which runs until December 12 in Dubai.

China and Russia, the world's largest builders of nuclear power plants, are not among the signatories.

In addition to the United States, France and the United Arab Emirates, the declaration was signed by Bulgaria, Canada, the Czech Republic, Finland, Ghana, Hungary, Japan, Moldova, Mongolia, Morocco, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Sweden, Ukraine, South Korea and the United Kingdom.

"The declaration recognises the key role of nuclear energy in achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 and in maintaining the goal of (limiting global warming to) 1.5°C", the text states.

"We know from the science, the facts and the evidence that we cannot achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 without nuclear power," said John Kerry.

Romanian President Clausus Johannites explained that nuclear power represents for the European country "a stable energy source that contributes to energy security and decarbonisation".

The signatory countries also call on international financial institutions, such as the World Bank, to include nuclear power in approved financing.

"There are statutory provisions, sometimes in certain international lending institutions, that exclude nuclear power. I think that is completely obsolete," the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), Rafael Grossi, told Agence France-Presse.

Proponents of nuclear power say that it is flexible, emits virtually no greenhouse gases and is an unparalleled means of producing clean and abundant electricity.

On the other hand, some environmentalists point out negative points, such as the risk of accidents and the high cost of this energy.
column4: ['CC: Controversy about green technologies']
column5: ['CC: Controversy about green technologies: Other']

column3:
Southeastern Europe experiences an unusually hot summer: Greece records its hottest July on record

July 2024 has gone down in history as the hottest month on record in Greece, according to preliminary data analysed by the scientific team at meteo.gr and the National Observatory of Athens. This record heat not only exceeded the average July temperature for the period 1991-2020 by 2.9°C, but also surpassed the previous record set in July 2012 by 0.3°C.

July 2024: a month of historical records in Greece and around the world

Analysis of climate data has revealed that July 2024 was marked by long periods of exceptionally high temperatures, significantly exceeding seasonal normals across the country. This pattern of extreme heat is in line with a worrying trend observed in recent decades: since 1960, the average July temperature in Greece has increased by 2.5°C.

Furthermore, over the past four years, three of the four hottest Julys in the past 80 years have been recorded in Greece, highlighting a growing trend of extreme temperatures attributed to climate change. Furthermore, the persistent heat of July 2024 was compounded by one of the longest heatwaves since 1980. This heatwave occurred between 8 and 23 July.

But anyone who thinks this trend is limited to Greece is mistaken. In fact, globally, 21 July 2024 was considered the hottest day on record, with a global average temperature of 17.1°C, as reported by the European Union’s Copernicus Climate Change Service. This record was surpassed again the following day, 22 July, with the global average temperature reaching 17.2°C.

Adaptation and mitigation measures: Greece’s response to extreme heat

The inherent concerns cannot be ignored. The Greek authorities have been taking steps to adapt and mitigate the impacts of extreme temperatures. During peak heat waves, several cities have opened air-conditioning centres to help vulnerable populations.

In addition, there has been an increase in preparedness and response to forest fires, which are a greater threat during periods of extreme heat. For example, civil protection personnel have been concerned about closing Greece’s most visited monument, the Acropolis in Athens, between 12pm and 5pm when the heat is at its highest.

The data for July 2024 reinforce the urgency of concrete measures to adapt to climate change. Record temperatures, not only in Greece but globally, are a clear sign of the intensification of extreme weather events, which have been spreading throughout the month of August.

Note, by the way, the days with very high temperatures that have continued at the beginning of this month throughout Europe and in Greece, in particular, and which will continue for at least the next few weeks.
column4: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears']
column5: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Amplifying existing fears of global warming']

column3:
Fundo Brasil supports projects for traditional communities

The Traditional Communities Fighting for Climate Justice call has been open since Monday (27) and interested parties may submit projects until January 31, 2024. Applications must be submitted on the organization's website. Proposals may involve topics such as land rights, productive alternatives, training activities, among others.

Culturally distinct groups characterized by their own forms of social organization and which relate to their territories and natural resources as a fundamental condition for their cultural, social, economic and spiritual reproduction will be considered traditional communities. This includes indigenous people, andirobeiras, everlasting plant gatherers, caatingueiros, mangaba gatherers, quilombolas, extractivists, riverside dwellers, caiçaras, gypsies, terreiro peoples, cipozeiros, chestnut trees, faxinalenses, fundo and fecha de pasto, geraizeiros, islhéus, isqueiros, morroquianos, pantaneiros, artisanal fishermen, piassava growers, pomeranos, babassu coconut breakers, retireros, rubber tappers, vazanteiros and veredeiros.

The Fund indicates that these communities have been greatly affected by the advance of the exploitation of biomes observed in Brazil in recent years, with the growth of illegal occupations and agrarian conflicts. In addition, it notes that they are also impacted due to their vulnerability to the consequences of climate change, such as drought or excessive rainfall depending on the region and time of year.

"Supporting the ways of life of traditional communities also means ensuring sustainable practices, preserving biodiversity and promoting the resilience of ecosystems, in a broad strategy for climate and environmental justice covered by this notice," the organization maintains.

New calls for proposals

According to the Brazil Human Rights Fund, the call for proposals is the first to be launched by Raízes - Climate Justice Fund for Traditional Peoples and Communities, a support line that should allocate at least R$6 million over the next 3 years to strengthen grassroots groups, communities and organizations that work to defend their rights and protect territories and natural resources. New calls for proposals should be announced later.
column4: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears']
column5: ['CC: Amplifying Climate Fears: Other']

column3:
Water shortage in Espírito Santo: drought can no longer take anyone by surprise

From 2015 to 2017, the water crisis in Espírito Santo required tough measures, such as the prohibition of irrigation of plantations during the day in municipalities in critical situations, with economic impacts on the agricultural sector. Industries also committed to reducing consumption. The population had to commit to a culture of rationing.

The state government then began a program to build multipurpose dams. The Reis Magos supply system, in Serra, was also inaugurated in 2017, in this context, reducing the overload on the Santa Maria da Vitória System. And, in 2018, the construction of the Jucu River dam between Domingos Martins and Viana was announced, with the capacity to store 23 billion liters of water: accumulating the resource in the wet season for use in the dry season, as the little ant teaches in the fable. This important project, which is progressing slowly, is included in the PAC. Its urgency is undeniable.

In this atypical month of November, with no rain, in which Espírito Santo is one of the states affected by the heat wave, the alert for a new water supply crisis is sounding. In the Metropolitan Area, the Jucu and Santa Maria rivers are approaching the critical level, as reported by Leonel Ximenes in his column.

Cesan also reported that the rivers from which the company collects water to supply the population have had their water levels reduced due to the recent drought and warned that the situation affects the 53 municipalities served by the company. In Pinheiros, in the north of the state, the water supply has been compromised in the district of São João Sobrado for 15 days, requiring the use of tanker trucks. Neighborhoods in Marataízes, on the South Coast, have also been suffering from a lack of water since last week.

As previously stated, this is still only a warning, which requires the government to prepare contingency actions. No government has the ability to control when it rains or shines, but experience in previous critical scenarios should teach what needs to be done to avoid or face future supply crises. Without standing idly by.

Dry periods, like rainy ones, are cyclical and unpredictable, but will become increasingly common with climate change. Governor Renato Casagrande chairs the Green Brazil Consortium, created in 2021 to develop coordinated actions among federative entities, obtaining external financial resources and seeking good practices to mitigate the climate effects in the country.

Investments are needed not only in large-scale projects, but also in less grandiose rainwater harvesting projects, as well as projects for the industrial reuse of water and the conservation and recovery of riparian forests, which are responsible for the health of rivers.

Amid warnings of global climate change, we need to prepare for what lies ahead, with planning that integrates municipal, state and federal levels. We already have enough experience to learn how to deal with extreme weather events and reduce damage. There is no turning back.

column3:
COP28: Brazil resumes central role in climate negotiations, but Congress approves absurd coal subsidy

Brazil is an environmental powerhouse. Period. It is large, has a voice, has the largest tropical forest on the planet, and has an efficient diplomacy that has already found several solutions to real problems. This year, the country returns to the table at COP28, after four tragic years of denialism, with data on emissions and deforestation reductions.

Brazil at COP28: Lula and Marina with ideas and solutions

Environment and health: Approval of the 'Poison Bill' goes against new trends and happens at the worst time

I spoke this morning with Minister Marina Silva, who is already in Dubai for the conference, and she told me that Brazil will present the new financing mechanism for forest countries tomorrow.

This is a new path, in addition to those that already exist and that could prosper in the negotiations over the next few days, such as the 91.4 billion euros per year for mitigation and adaptation, which, in COP jargon, means that rich countries with older industrialization will finance policies to reduce the impacts of climate change and also to adapt to irreversible changes in developing nations.

There is another path, which is the agreement on losses and damages. Speaking from there today, the minister stated that the agreement is being reached to make compensation for vulnerable countries concrete.

COP28: Survey shows that workers would like to contribute to sustainability, but are unaware of the companies' strategy

The problem is that here in Brazil, Congress is sending a signal that is completely contrary to the agenda presented by Brazil at COP28. By approving a subsidy for coal, what Congress is doing is subverting the meaning of the green agenda, corrupting the meaning of the wind power law to serve the lobbies and transferring to itself, the reader, the cost of this contradiction. Subsidizing coal also means adding this cost, estimated at 4.6 billion euros per year, to the electricity bill.

There is also a contradiction in Dubai, of course. There is an expectation of progress on the climate change agenda at COP28, despite the fact that it is being held in the United Arab Emirates, the heart of the oil industry, which is the largest emitter of greenhouse gases and therefore a large part of the problem.

Minister Marina Silva told me that the great victory would be to leave the conference with a commitment to reduce the use of fossil fuels, which will be challenging since the president of COP28, Sultan al-Jaber, also heads the local oil company.

Contradictions: On the way to the COP, Lula will go to the birthplace of oil and tyranny in the Middle East

This meeting is expected to provide the first assessment of the commitments, national targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions established in the Paris Agreement. But it will be in Brazil, at COP30, ten years after the agreement signed in the French capital, that the great adjustment and the reestablishment of goals will be made.

Now, one detail: at COP28, everyone is looking towards COP30 in Belém. But where will COP29 be? There is a stalemate. It has to be in a European country, but Russia's war against Ukraine has confused that choice.

column3:
Lula's message on fossil fuels after OPEC+ invitation

President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva said this Friday, the 1st, that world economies need to address the debate on fossil fuels and reduce their use. The president's speech was given at COP 28, in the United Arab Emirates, one day after Brazil received an invitation from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and Allies (OPEC+) to join the group.

“The world is already convinced of the potential of renewable energy. It is time to address the debate on the slow pace of decarbonization of the planet and work towards an economy less dependent on fossil fuels,” he said. In his opening speech, Lula drew attention to the increase in global temperatures on the planet and extreme global events, such as the historic drought in the Amazon and cyclones in the southern region of Brazil. “The bill has come early,” said the president, stating that the planet is “fed up” with climate agreements that are made and not fulfilled, and reiterated that Brazil is willing to lead “by example.”

The day before, Brazil received an invitation to join OPEC+, the organization that controls oil prices through a cartel of large producers such as Saudi Arabia, Iran, Iraq, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela, as well as other allied countries, such as Mexico and Russia. The organization, which uses increased fuel production to control the value of the commodity on the international market, has a different view from that defended by Lula in his speech at the COP, which is that fossil fuels should continue to be used.

This Friday, Petrobras CEO Jean Paul Prates told Reuters that Brazil should join the OPEC+ group of oil producers. According to him, the country should play a role of cooperation and observation of decisions, but without participating in the production quota system.

“They call on other countries that do not have the right to vote and are not subject to quotas. We would never participate in an entity that established a quota for Brazil, especially with the support of Petrobras, which is a publicly traded company and cannot have a quota,” the executive stated.

In addition to defending the use of renewable energy, and the obvious awkward situation that the country is in by accepting to join OPEC+, Lula said in his speech that spending on weapons and wars should be used to combat hunger and climate change. “How many tons of carbon are emitted by missiles that cross the sky and fall on innocent civilians, especially children and women?”

The president also said that “the world has naturalized unacceptable disparities in income, gender and race and that it is not possible to confront climate change without combating inequality.”

In his speech, Lula also criticized the UN’s stance on its inability to maintain peace, “simply because some of its members profit from war.” The United Nations has Russia, Ukraine and Israel as member countries, for example. “Governments cannot be exempted from their responsibilities. No country will solve its problems alone. We are all obliged to act together, beyond our borders. Brazil is willing to lead by example. We have adjusted our goals, which are now more ambitious than those of many developed countries,” he said.

column3:
United Kingdom: The country has been invaded by a new species of jumping spider!

Scientists have recently discovered a new species of spider in the south of England. It is believed that its migration has been facilitated by climate change. Researchers assure that this species is not poisonous to humans. However, it is attracting a lot of attention.

But what is happening? Several cities in the United States have recently been on alert for invasions of giant exotic spiders. It is enough to make people panic. Now it is the turn of Europe, more specifically, the southern regions of the United Kingdom.

During a biological census carried out by the British Arachnological Society in Penryn, west Cornwall (England), in 2023, researchers identified for the first time a species of spider native to the Caribbean. Far from the giant exotic spider invading the United States, this species is tiny, measuring no more than 3 to 4 mm in length.

Scientifically called Anasaitis milesae, this species of jumping spider is completely harmless. Like most spiders, this one is not venomous, but like all animals, it defends itself by biting when it feels threatened. Given its size, its bite seems insignificant. But how did it get from the Caribbean to England?

According to scientists, it travelled thanks to international trade. Due to its tiny size, it could easily fit into suitcases or be transported in international containers. And it clearly liked the Anglo-Saxon climate. It is not the only animal and insect to travel this way; the Asian hornet was also introduced this way.

As a result of climate change, insect invasions are becoming more frequent. The milder climate of the UK's port areas is favouring the establishment of these new specimens. Anasaitis milesae is not the only species to have recently arrived in the European country.

Experts have also observed a Mediterranean spider called Zoropsis spinimana, or 'false wolf spider', in London. Another species identified in the south of the UK is Segestria florentina. This spider has the particularity of having green fangs. Unlike the Caribbean species, these two species are imposing in size and have a painful bite. And just like Anasaitis milesae, they are not dangerous to humans.

column3:
"The fight against climate change is not on the ballot". Young man from Climáximo interrupts debate between party leaders

The debate between the eight party leaders with seats in parliament had begun four minutes ago when it was interrupted by a young man from the Climáximo activist movement. "The fight against climate change is not on the ballot, it is in the hands of the people", shouted the protester, who invaded the studio that RTP had set up at the Nova SBE university in Carcavelos and stood in front of the moderator, journalist Carlos Daniel.

The young man was immediately removed by a member of the production team, at a time when Pedro Nuno Santos, leader of the PS, was explaining the scenarios he advocates for governability for the country after the legislative elections on 10 March.

Shortly afterwards, when the PSD president, Luís Montenegro, was being questioned, more voices from climate protesters could be heard in the background, which led Carlos Daniel to mention that some protests were still ongoing “from some people who understood that this was the moment to bring their message to the public space”. “This is no longer a novelty in the country, but we will keep the debate within what was planned”, he added.

The Climáximo protesters also painted the windows behind the candidates with red paint. In a statement to which Observador had access, the group stated that the protest “aimed to interrupt the normality of electoral debates that ignore the climate crisis and whose plans” lead “to climate collapse: water shortages for people, losses in agriculture and food production, deaths due to unbearable heat waves, displacements due to deadly fires”.

António Assunção, spokesperson for Climáximo, says that “in these elections, not only is stopping the climate crisis not the main issue, but no party — with or without seats in parliament — has presented a plan that is compatible with the limits of nature”. “Failing to implement” cuts of “at least” 75% of emissions by 2030 is “guaranteeing climate and civilizational collapse”, he believes.

“We cannot allow them to continue to lead us to climate hell. All parties are deliberately reiterating their declaration of war against people. Society must resist and fight to stop the climate crisis”, adds the spokesperson, who reiterates that the group believes that an “alternative” to stopping the climate crisis is “on the streets, not at the ballot box”.

In the statement released this Friday, Climáximo recalls that over the last week it has been altering the billboards of several parties, by placing the phrase “with your vote we guarantee climate collapse”.

Observador awaits a response from RTP to the questions posed. Authorities are already at the scene, about an hour after the incident. The PSP of Carcavelos, in a previous telephone contact, said it could not provide any information about the possible arrest of the protesters.

column3:
EU pulls out of Hungarian foreign ministers' meeting over country's stance on Ukraine war

The European Union's top diplomat Josep Borrell on Monday pulled out of Hungary a meeting of EU foreign ministers that was due to take place in Budapest, in a response to the bloc's rapprochement with Russia over the war in Ukraine.

Borrell said the meeting in late August would now take place in Brussels, after Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán visited Moscow and Beijing without EU support and said his government had defined European policy as "pro-war".

"We have to send a signal, even if it is symbolic," Borrell told reporters in Brussels at the last meeting of foreign ministers before the summer break.

Orbán began the trip, which also included a visit to US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump, just days after Hungary took over the rotating EU presidency on 1 July. At Monday's meeting, several foreign ministers expressed strong condemnation of Hungarian Foreign Minister Peter Szijjarto, officials said. "This was done very clearly and repeatedly to leave no room for doubt," Portuguese Foreign Minister Paulo Rangel said. Several European countries see Hungary as too close to Moscow, undermining EU efforts to isolate Russia politically and diplomatically over its invasion of Ukraine. Hungary says it seeks to bring peace to Ukraine as quickly as possible.
