column3:
The new bonfires of the Inquisition

1. The rector of the University of Coimbra believes he can fire the director of the Russian Studies Centre at that University with the same arbitrariness with which any boss of a small company fires a young person on probation. There is no disciplinary process, there are no facts to justify it. There is the fact that the dismissed director is Russian and there is the report made by two Ukrainians that the director recommends books by Russian authors and has an opinion on the war in Ukraine that does not coincide with that of the informants.

In all the news that has come to light about this dismissal, carried out outside of any legal process, which is serious in a public institution, there are no other facts to justify it other than the author's nationality and the report about his opinions.

It is clear that we are facing a gross violation of Article 13 of the Constitution of the Portuguese Republic, according to which no one may be harmed or deprived of any right on the grounds of their language, territory of origin, religion, political or ideological beliefs.

That the Ukrainian whistleblowers ignore the Portuguese Constitution and the democratic rights it enshrines does not surprise me, but that the rector of a university should be the one to promote the summary dismissal of a professor based on his nationality and for a crime of opinion is something that surprises me, outrages me, and which I consider to be a disgrace to a university whose prestige should be defended. If we were not living in the climate of witch hunt that has been imposed on this western corner of the world, the news of a rector who, in an act of total arrogance, summarily dismisses a professor, violating his fundamental rights with the same degree of carelessness with which he bans beef in canteens, would be the cause of national and international scandal.

2. Manuel Pires da Rocha is a prestigious Portuguese musician and music teacher. He is publicly known as the violinist of the Victor Jara Brigade, but he has a past and present of great prestige in music education, namely as a teacher and director of the Coimbra Conservatory. He studied in Moscow, where he obtained a higher education degree in violin and, unlike others, he respects the country where he studied and the people who welcomed him. Last week, Manuel Pires da Rocha was the target of a snitch who identified himself as a “Jew of Ukrainian origins”, who sent an email to the teachers of the Conservatory denouncing his presence at the celebrations of Victory Day over Nazi-fascism in Lisbon. The response to this ignominy was given by Manuel Rocha himself with the intellectual brilliance for which he is renowned and whose reading I highly recommend.

3. These two episodes are added to the one in the Setúbal City Council, where Russian citizens were vilified and even accused of being spies simply because they were Russian and offered to support Ukrainian refugees in Portugal. They are added to the demonstrations by Ukrainian citizens in Portugal displaying flags of Nazi organizations and advocating the outlawing of the PCP. They are added to a drift of political and cultural intolerance that is very dangerous for democracy. As Manuel Rocha wrote in his text, citing the vampires sung by José Afonso who are back, if someone is fooled by their serious appearance and opens the door for them upon arrival, they eat everything and leave nothing.

column3:
Russia is giving up on Kharkiv after ‘failure’

Russia is now “throwing everything it has” at the eastern front, Zelenskyy says. Kremlin denies: “Operation is ongoing”.

Just months after Moscow launched the operation, Kharkiv is preparing to see the Russians leave after the “failure” of the offensive with more troops in northeastern Ukraine, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said.

According to Zelenskyy’s recent interview, Russia is now “throwing everything it has” at the eastern front, where fighting has intensified near the city of Pokrovsk.

“Their main focus is no longer the entire east, although Sloviansk [a city in northern Donetsk that borders the Kharkiv region] is not excluded,” the Ukrainian leader added.

In June, Zelenskyy had already described the failure of the operation.

“I spoke with the commander-in-chief about the general situation. A very significant result is that the Russian army failed in its operation in Kharkiv. Now we are holding them back as much as possible and destroying Russian units that enter our territory and terrorize the Kharkiv region,” the Ukrainian president said. 

Russia, however, has already denied giving up the territory, according to The Moscow Times. 

“This operation is ongoing and will continue until it is successfully completed,” Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said on July 17. 

In fact, in an update on July 24, Ukrainian forces near the city described the fighting as “tense and difficult.” 

Ukraine’s second-largest city, Kharkiv was stormed by about 30,000 Russian troops, who entered several villages and thus reopened the northeastern front of the war. The city lacked the necessary defenses that should have been prepared by now, experts and commanders in the war that has dragged on since 2022 said.
